歌!"

"是不是一只黑色的鸟?"
"是不是一只棕色的鸟?"

"是一个..."
"啦啦, 啦, 啦, 啦, 啦, 啦..."

"
是
一头驴!"
"
是
一头驴!"

"
是
一头驴,   接着唱!
"
每当我试着睡觉，
叮咚 门铃响起。
我转过另一边时，
铃铃手机响起。
我再次尝试睡一下，
这一次，董！
丁 丁!那是什么？
一辆自行车冲过来！
“什么？”妈妈看我还醒着，她问我“你还没睡着吗？”
我用眼睛告诉她，“但妈妈，我怎么睡得着？”
叮，铃，咚，丁！整个房子好多声！ #1000books
eng: TingTongThe doorbell rings.

Now
I turn
the other side, and...
BUZZ, BUZZ the mobile goes.

Once again, I give
it a try,

and this time
it’s a...   
DONG!

TRING TRING!
What was that?

A bicycle
rushing by!

“What?”
says
Mamma seeing me up, “Aren’t
you asleep still?”

“But
Mamma,” I tell her
with my eyes, “How can I sleep?”

“TING, BUZZ, DONG, TRING!
The whole house is full of rings!”

zho: 从前，有一个小姑娘叫拉姆亚。拉姆亚喜欢耳环。所有人送她礼物都送她耳环。她有红色的耳环，蓝色的耳环，绿色的耳环和所有颜色的彩虹耳环。那么，你知道她生日的时候，她的奶奶送给她什么吗？
奶奶送给拉姆亚一对漂亮的星星钻石耳环！拉姆亚非常喜欢它们。“哦，奶奶，你从哪里找到的这对漂亮的钻石星星？”她问。
一个没有星星的夜晚，奶奶指着天空说：“看，天空中没有星星了。我把天上的星星都摘了下来，挑出了最好的做成了你的耳环。”
这让拉姆亚非常伤心。“一闪一闪亮晶晶，你们都在哪啊小星星。那么高的天空，请回到天空来！”拉姆亚很不开心地唱。
那天晚上，拉姆亚取下那对耳环，然后小心地把它放在枕头底下。 她希望这样能把星星送回天空。那天晚上， 拉姆亚做了一个美丽的梦。
在那个梦里，一个漂亮的星女来到拉姆亚面前说“别担心，我有一千个新的星星在天空上。”拉姆亚醒来，你知道她看见什么了吗？
那天晚上天上满是星星！
拉姆亚的眼睛又变得像钻石星星一样善良。
现在拉姆亚好开心哦！
eng: Ramya was a little girlRamya loved earrings.All her friends and family gave her earrings.Ramya had red earrings.Ramya had blue earringsRamya had Green earrings.Ramya's earrings were like a rainbow.

In June it was Ramya's Birthday.Everybody gave her presents. Everybody gave her earrings as presents. Ramya's Grandma gave her star earrings.Ramya loved Grandma's star earrings.Ramya asked Grandma, "Where did you get such pretty stars?"

Grandma took Ramya to the window.Grandma showed Ramya the sky.There were no stars in the sky.Grandma said, "there are no stars in the sky now." Grandma said, "I took the stars from the sky and put the best stars in your earring."
Ramya was very sad.Ramya sang a sad song.Twinkle, twinkle little star,How I wonder where you are?Up above the world so high ,Please come back like diamonds in the sky!"
At night Ramya was tired.Ramya took off her diamond earrings.Ramya put the earrings under her pillow.Then Ramya went to sleep.Ramya said to the fairies, "Please return the stars to the sky."
Ramya had a nice dream.In the dream a pretty fairy came.The fairy said to Ramya, "Don't worry Ramya, I have lots and lots of new stars for the sky."Ramya woke up."Do you know what Ramya saw?
The Sky was filled with stars!
Ramya was so happy!Ramya's eyes were shining like stars.Ramya put on her diamond earrings again.
Now, Ramya loves all her earrings again.

zho: 扎玛准备去上学。
爸爸准备早餐，做麦片粥。
“妈妈做的麦片粥更好吃！”扎玛说道。
上学前来一顿麦片粥能让扎玛一天都有精神。
麦片粥做好了。
爸爸爱意满满地加了奶。
“爸爸，我觉得这粥里的糖不够。”扎玛说。
“妈妈做的麦片粥比爸爸的好吃。”扎玛心想。
“爸爸请给我再加点糖好吗？”扎玛问。
爸爸给扎玛又加了点糖。
“呕！爸爸！你把盐加到粥里啦！”
“爸爸你说，妈妈什么时候才能回来啊？”扎玛问道。
eng: zama is getting ready for school.
Papa is preparing porridge﻿.
He wished he would get porride from mmother
Porridge will give him energy
Here you go.
He adds milk in the porridge.
He finished his porridge quickly
Finish it quickly
there was a lot left
they added salt into the porridge
OH, papa give him too much porridge
WDad, when will mom come home? asked zama
Cat.                                                        Cat.
Big cat.                                                     Little cat.
Cats with spots.
Two cats are up.One cat is down.
These cats are cold.
These cats are hot.
Two cats with tall ears.
Two cats with short legs.
Mad cat.                                           Sad cat.
Funny cats.
Fast cats!
zho: 有些野生貓科動物身上有條紋，例如：老虎！
有些野生貓科動物有鬃毛， 例如：獅子！
有些野生貓科動物身上有斑點，例如：花豹和豹貓！
有些野生貓科動物有極佳的爬樹能力，例如：雲豹和紋貓。
有些野生貓科動物生活在高山上，例如：雪豹和兔猻！
有些野生貓科動物生活在沙漠中，例如：沙漠貓！
有些野生貓科動物有雙多毛的耳朵，例如：獰貓和猞猁！
有些野生貓科動物喜歡捕魚，例如：漁貓！
有些野生貓科動物的體型非常小，例如：鏽斑豹貓！
有些野生貓科動物的外貌像家貓，例如：叢林貓和金貓！
但他們都是野生貓科動物！

eng:
Muzi loves to
build things. He dreams of building the best thing ever.

Once, he built a
shelter for his toys.

But it wasn’t the
best thing ever.

Yesterday he
built a bridge for his animals. 
 
It was a good
thing. 
But not the best…

Today Muzi is
going to visit uGogo.
He is sad. Without his toys, how can he build the best thing ever?

At the bus stop,
Muzi is amazed.
He sees red things and blue things.Small things and big things.New things and old things.

Muzi has a new
idea for building the best thing ever.

On the road to
uGogo’s, 
Muzi finds many
things.

Long things and
short things.
Round things and
square things.

By the riverside, Muzi finds more
things.

Soft things and
pointy things. 
Green things and
brown things.

"Look, Muzi! We
are here."

While uGogo bakes
for 
the hungry
travellers…
Muzi builds.

Look uGogo, a new
house for you. 
Oh, Muzi, laughs uGogo.

This is the best thing ever!

uGogo, uGogo! says
Muzi. 
The world is full
of toys. 
Look what I can
build.
zho: 木子很喜欢建造东西。 他梦想着建造最好的事物。
有一次，他为他的玩具建了一个避难所。
但那不是一个最好的建筑。
昨天他为他的动物建了一座桥。 这是件好事。但不是最好的。。。
今天木子要去看乌戈戈。
他不开心。没有了他的玩具，他怎么可以建立最好的东西？
在巴士站，木子感到惊讶。
他看到红色的东西和蓝色的东西。小东西和大东西。新东西和旧东西。
木子有了一个新的想法，去建立最好的东西。
去往乌戈戈的路上，木子发现了很多东西。
长的东西和短的东西。圆的东西和方形的东西。
在河边，木子发现更多的东西。
柔软的东西和尖刻的东西。绿色的东西和棕色的东西。
看，木子！我们在这儿。
当乌戈戈为饥饿的旅客们烘烤着食物。。。
木子建造着。
看乌戈戈，这是给你的一个新房子。哦，木子，这是最好的建筑！乌戈戈笑着说。
乌戈戈，乌戈戈！木子说。世界充满玩具。看看我能够建造着什么。

eng: There was a time when all the animals lived together as friends. One day they decided to have a meeting to elect a king.
Rooster wanted to be king. So he lied to the other animals. He told them, “The red comb on my head is fire! Don't touch the comb on my head!”
The other animals believed Rooster. They decided to elect Rooster as their king. The animals hoped that Rooster's fire would help them in cold weather.
Then came a day when it rained. And rained. And rained. It was cold. Everything was wet and cold.
“Where can we get fire to warm our bodies?” Rabbit asked the other animals.
“We can get fire from the comb on Rooster's head,” replied Monkey. “Rooster is our king because he has fire on his head,” said Monkey.
The animals agreed with Monkey. They sent Fox to collect fire from king Rooster.
Fox found Rooster in a deep sleep. So he decided to take fire without asking Rooster.
Fox collected some dry grass. He put the grass next to the comb on Rooster's head. Nothing happened. The grass did not catch fire.
“Wake up king Rooster!” yelled Fox. “We need fire now.”
But Rooster could not give fire to Fox.
Fox was angry. He went back to the other animals. He told them the truth about the comb on Rooster's head. From that day, no one was afraid of Rooster. And foxes eat roosters and their families.
zho: 曾经有一段时间，所有的动物都作为朋友生活在一起。 有一天，它们决定开会选举国王。
公鸡想当国王。 因此，它对其他动物撒谎。 它告诉它们：“我头上的红色鸡冠是火团！ 不要碰我头上的鸡冠！”
其他动物相信公鸡。 它们决定推举公鸡为国王。 动物们都希望公鸡的火能在寒冷的天气帮助它们。
这一天下雨了。 雨一直下。 一直下。 天变得很冷。 一切都变得潮湿寒冷。
“我们可以在哪里生火来温暖我们的身体？”兔子问其他动物。
猴子回答：“我们可以从公鸡头上的鸡冠取火。” 猴子说：“公鸡是我们的国王，因为它的头上有火。”
动物们都赞同猴子的提议。 它们派狐狸向公鸡国王取火。
狐狸在发现了在深度睡眠中的公鸡。 因此，它决定不叫醒公鸡就取火。
狐狸收集了一些干草。 它把干草放在公鸡头的鸡冠旁边。 可是什么事都没有发生。 干草没有着火。
“公鸡国王醒一醒！”狐狸大喊。 “我们现在需要火。”
但是公鸡没办法给狐狸生火。
狐狸很生气。 它回到了其他动物身边。 它把公鸡鸡冠的真相告诉了其他动物们。 从那天起，再也没有人害怕公鸡。 从此，狐狸就吃公鸡和它的家人。
畢瑪很愛睡覺，而且很難早起。洗衣工拉姆因此而經常大罵畢瑪。
一天，一隻名叫高力的牛問畢瑪：『畢瑪，你在傷心什麼？』畢瑪說：『我每天都無法早起，拉姆因為這樣天天對著我大罵。可以請你每天早上叫我起床嗎？』『當然好啊。』高力回答。隔天清晨，高力很大聲的哞哞叫，但畢瑪還是沒有起床。
一天傍晚，在從河邊回去的路上，畢瑪遇到一隻名叫莫提的狗。『我每天早上都無法準時起床，可以請你以後叫我起床嗎？』畢瑪問莫提。『當然好啊。』莫提答應，並在隔天早上一直汪汪叫。但，畢瑪起床了嗎？並沒有！

當天傍晚，畢瑪遇到一隻名叫基努的公雞。他對基努說：『你在早上啼鳴時大家都會起床。你也可以一起叫我起床嗎？』基努答應了。隔天早上，基努

啼鳴地又長又響，但畢瑪仍然沒有起床。
隔天傍晚，畢瑪看到一隻名叫卡嚕的烏鴉，開心地在啼叫。『卡嚕，可以請你在早上叫我起床嗎？』他問。卡嚕說：『有什麼不可以的呢？我會用啼叫讓你起床的。』隔天早上，卡嚕用盡全力地啼叫，但畢瑪還是沒有起床。
畢瑪很難過。隔天早上，一隻蒼蠅飛到畢瑪地鼻子上。『哈啊......啾......哈啾！』畢瑪起來打了個大噴嚏。
『哇！我起床了。我是怎麼起來地？』他納悶地問。『是我叫你起來的。』蒼蠅說道。『可以請你每天這麼早叫我起床嗎？』『當然。』蒼蠅答應。畢瑪好開心。現在早早起床對他來說不是一個問題了！
eng: Bheema is Ramu washerman's donkey.his problem is that he is not able to wake up on time.this is why he gets scolded.

One day, Gauri, the cow, asked him, “Bheema, why are you so sad?”Bheema said, “I cannot get up early and Ramu shouts at me every day. Will you wake me up every morning, please?”“Yes, I will,” said Gauri. Early next morning, Gauri mooed loudly, but Bheema did not wake up.

Coming back from the river in the evening, Bheema met Moti, the dog.“I can never get up in the morning on time. Will you wake me up?” Bheema asked Moti.“Yes, I will,” said Moti and the next morning he barked and barked but did Bheema did not wake up.

That evening Bheema met Cheenu, the rooster.He said to Cheenu, “You crow in the morning and everybody wakes up. Will you wake me up too?” Cheenu agreed. The next morning, Cheenu crowed long and loud, but Bheema did not wake up.

The next evening, Bheema saw Kalu, the crow, cawing away happily.“Kalu, will you wake me up in the morning, please?” he asked.Kalu said, “Why not? I will caw and wake you up.”The next morning Kalu cawed all he could but Bheema did not wake up.
Bheema was sad.The next morning, a fly came and sat on his nose.“Aaah…chhoooo… ahchhoo!” Bheema got up with a big sneeze.

“Wow! I woke up. How did I wake up?” he asked in wonder.“I woke you up,” said the fly.“Will you wake me up like this early every morning?” “Sure,” said the fly. Bheema was happy. Now he would have no problem getting up early every morning!

zho:
「數字就在你的身邊。」大家都這樣跟莎麗莉說。
可是，無論她怎麼努力，她都找不到身邊的數字朋友。
莎麗莉請婆婆來幫忙。 婆婆指着架上的瓶子說：「1,2,3,4......」
但這令莎麗莉很懊惱。
「這些是瓶子，可不是數字啊！」

莎麗莉又請媽媽來幫忙找數字朋友。
媽媽指着田裏的蘿蔔說：「1,2,3,4.....」
這令莎麗莉更懊惱。
「這些是蘿蔔，不是數字呢！」
這時候，莎麗莉碰見蓮娜在點算小雞，看看牠們是否全都回家。
莎麗莉看得一頭霧水，十分懊惱。

「牠們明明是雞，

牠們不是數字朋友！」
晚飯前，莎麗莉又看見阿姨在計時。
她感到相當苦惱。
「時間就是時間，不是數字！」
莎麗莉仍然未找到數字朋友，於是她去問問八歲的姊姊：菇菇。她覺得菇菇一定會知道！
菇菇說：「如果你用一個對的方法去看事物，數字朋友便會出現。」菇菇給了莎麗莉一對魔法眼鏡，讓她可以看見數字朋友。
eng: Everyone tells Zanele that numbers are all around her.But no matter how hard she tries, she can’t see them.
Zanele asks Gogo tohelp her see somenumbers. Gogo points to the jarson the shelf and counts, “one, two, three, four.”
But Zanele is unhappy.
“Those aren’t numbers. Those are jars!”
Zanele asks Mom to help her see some numbers.Mom points to thecarrots in the gardenand counts, “one, two,three, four.”
But Zanele is unhappy.
“Those aren’t numbers.Those are carrots!”
Zanele sees Linda counting the chickens, to see if they have all come back home.
But Zanele is unhappy.
“Those aren’t numbers.Those are chickens!”
Zanele sees Auntie counting the hours until supper.
But Zanele is unhappy.
“Those aren’t numbers.Those are hours!”
Zanele can’t see thenumbers in the world.She goes to speak to her sister, Gugu, who is eight years old and knows everything.
“If you look at anything in the right way, you can see a number in it,” says Gugu.Gugu gives Zanele a pair of magic glasses and tells her to go look for numbers in the world.
When the last school bell rang, all the children laughed and screamed with joy.                                                    All, except Akku. Akku was ANGRY!
"Akku! Akku! Look at the pretty sunflowers!" said Appa, as they rode   through a field."Oh no! They’re TOO YELLOW! They’re making my eyes hurt!" said Akku.
Akku! Akku! Look! Look at all the monkeys!" said Appa, pointing at the roof of their house.                              "oh no!" said Akku. Go AWAY!

"Here, drink some buttermilk," said Appa. "It’ll cool you down.""NO!" said Akku. "I DON’T WANT ANY!""Try a sip, at least?""OKAY! FINE!" said Akku, and tried a sip.It wasn’t all that bad.She had another sip.  And another.In no time, the glass was empty.

"Would you like a vada?" asked Appa.  "NO" said Akku."Just one little bite?""Okay, FINE!" said Akku, and took a bite. It  was quite good.She took another bite.And another.In no time, the plate was empty.

"Good girl," said Appa. "Now will you tell me why you’re so angry?"    "NO!" said Akku."Was it something I did?""NO!""Was it something Amma did?""NO!""Did something happened in school today?"     "MAYBE!"        "Oho."

"Would you like to draw it?" asked Appa. "Here’s a nice sheet of paper and some crayons."                                                                                                                                     "Okay, FINE!" said Akku.
Akku drew a brick… "This is the BRICK that I tripped over this morning," said Akku.                   "You’re right. That is a  brick!" said Appa.
And Akku drew a boy…"This is Bikku, The BOY who laughed at me when I fell down!" said Akku.                 "You’re right," said Appa. "He shouldn’t have laughed at you."
And Akku drew an idli…    "This is my idli," said Akku. "It fell out of my lunch box when I tripped over the BRICK!"

And Akku drew a crow…                                              "This is the CROW that flew off with my idli," said Akku.                              "The crow must have been very hungry," said Appa.

And Akku drew her teacher…"This is my teacher, Amala Miss," said Akku."She helped me up when I fell down. And then she hugged me.""That’s nice of her," said Appa."And then she patted my back and said, you would be fine. I DON’T like to be hugged and patted."Are you alright now?" I’m okay now."     "That’s good."

"See how well you draw, Akku?" said Appa."You’re a real artist! Will you draw something for Amma too?""Okay!" said Akku, and      started drawing some more. "This is a little white mouse… and this is a boat…and this is a coconut tree…"

"And this is a sunflower…and this is your cycle, Appa… and this is a dog…and this is a frog…"In no time, Akku had forgotten all about the BRICK that made her trip and fall. And about the BOY who laughed at her. And about the IDLI-CROW.And Akku even forgot about being ANGRY.

10 Things to Do If You Feel ANGRY like Akku:1. Laugh loudly and jump around with your arms in the air!2. Slowly – very, very slowly – breathe in, and breathe out!3. Drink some water! Or buttermilk!4. Eat a piece of fruit! Or a vada!5. Tell a grown-up about how you’re feeling!6. Write about how you’re feeling!7. Draw it out! Paint it!8. Play with a pile of clay!9. Make up a song about your anger! Sing it aloud!10. Do the happy dance!
zho: 下课铃声响起的时候，所有的孩子都开心地大笑着，尖叫着。所有人，除了阿库。阿库此时非常生气！
“阿库！阿库！你看那些向日葵真漂亮！”他们骑车路过一片田野的时候，阿爸说道。“啊呀！它们太黄了！我看得眼睛痛！”阿库说。
“阿库！阿库！看！看那些猴子！”阿爸说着，指向了他们家房子的屋顶。“去去去！”阿库说，“一边去！走开！一边去！”
“这儿，喝点酪乳冷静一下，”阿爸说。“不要！”阿库说，“我不想喝！”“至少喝一小口？”“好吧！”阿库说着，试着喝了一小口。喝起来味道不坏。于是她又喝了一口，然后又喝了一口。不一会儿，整个杯子都空了。
“你要来点油炸圈吗？”阿爸问。“不要！”阿库说。“就吃一小口？”“好吧。”阿库说着，咬了一口。感觉还挺好吃的。于是她又吃了一口。然后又一口。不一会儿，盘子空了。
“好孩子，”阿爸说道，“现在你来告诉说，你为什么这么生气？”“不要！”阿库说。“是因为我做的什么事吗？”“不是！”“是因为阿妈做的什么事吗？”“不是！”“今天学校里发生了什么不好的事吗？”“我不知道！”“噢噢噢。”
“你想把这件事画下来吗？”阿爸问，“这里有一张纸和一些蜡笔。”“好吧好吧！”阿库说。
阿库说了一块砖。“这块愚蠢的砖今天早上绊了我一跤。”阿库说。“你说得对。这是一块愚蠢的砖！”阿爸说。
阿库又画了一个男孩。。。“这是比库，一个很讨厌的男孩！我摔倒的时候，他嘲笑了我！”阿库说。“你说得对，”阿爸说，“他不应该笑话你。”
阿库又画了一张饼。“这是我的饼，”阿库说，“我摔倒的时候，它从我的饭盒里掉了出来！”
阿库又画了一只乌鸦。“这只讨厌的乌鸦叼走了我的饼，”阿库说。“这只乌鸦肯定是饿坏了。”阿爸说。
阿库又画了她的老师……“这是我的老师，阿马拉老师，”阿库说，“是她把我从地上拉了起来，还给了我一个拥抱。”“她真好心。”阿爸说。“而且她还捏了捏我的脸。我不喜欢别人捏我的脸。”“噢噢噢。你被捏疼了没有？”“有一点点疼，但是我现在已经没事了。”“那就好了。”
“阿库，你发现你画得多好了吗？”阿爸说。“你真是一个了不起的小画家。你能为阿妈画点什么吗？”“好啦！”阿库说着，继续开画。“这是一只白色的小老鼠……这里有一艘小船……这是一颗椰子树……”
“这是一株向日葵……这是阿爸你的自行车……这是一条狗……还有这是一只青蛙……”不一会儿，阿库就忘了那块愚蠢的绊倒她的砖。也忘了那个嘲笑她的坏男孩。也忘了那只偷走她饼的乌鸦。阿库也忘记了她自己还在生气。
当你像阿库一样生气的时候，这里有十件事你可以尝试去做做：1. 双手举过头顶，大笑着跳来跳去！2. 慢慢地吸气呼气。3. 喝点水！或者喝点酪乳！4. 吃一片水果！或者一块油炸圈！5.  把你的感受告诉一个大人！6. 把你的感受写下来！7. 画出来！8. 玩粘土！9. 把你的愤怒写成一首歌！然后大声唱出来！10.  像猴子一样跳舞！

eng: Shanti and Arun were good friends. They had so much fun together.They shared secrets in class. They ran races on the way home.She was always cheerful.

One day, Shanti came into the classroom slowly. Her head was bent. She looked sad. “Did someone scold you?” asked Arun.Shanti shook her head. She sat down and did not look up. She did not answer ‘Present!’ when Sona Miss called her name. Sona Miss called again, louder this time, “Shanti Kumar!” Shanti raised her hand.

“Do you have a sore throat?” her teacher asked her. Shanti shook her head.Her cheeks were red and it looked like she had a fever.“Are you feeling okay?” Sona Miss asked.Shanti nodded, still not daring to look up.
“Why does Shanti look so sad?”“Is your little brother okay?”“Is your puppy okay?”“Is your grandmother okay?”Shanti kept nodding her head to each of her friends. But she did not look up.

Arun wanted to make her smile. He had an idea! He took out something from his bag.As he ran to show it to Shanti, it slipped out of his hands. Shanti saw something flying towards her and she grabbed it.

It was a BIG, green, rubber frog!Shanti's eyes flew open. Then she opened her mouth to laugh.THEN Arun and her friends saw why she had not smiled or talked all day!Four of her front teeth had gone missing!
zho: 珊蒂跟阿仁是好朋友。他們總是玩在一起。他們在班上分享彼此的祕密。放學回家的時候會賽跑。珊蒂一直都很開朗。
一天，珊蒂低著頭、緩慢地走進教室。她看起很難過。『有人罵你了嗎？』阿仁問珊蒂搖搖頭。她到位子坐下，但頭還是低低地。她沒有回應索娜老師地點名。索娜老師再一次大聲地點名：『珊蒂．厙瑪！』珊蒂舉起她的手。
『妳喉嚨痛嗎？』老師問珊蒂。珊蒂搖搖頭。她的臉頰紅紅的，看上去是發燒了。『妳還好嗎？』索娜老師問。珊蒂低著頭，點了點頭。
『為什麼珊蒂看起來這麼難過？』『妳弟弟還好嗎？』『你的狗狗還好嗎？』『你的外婆還好嗎？』珊蒂一律用點頭回應所有問題。但她仍然低著頭。
阿仁想讓珊蒂開心一點。他想到了一個點子！他從包包裡拿出了一個東西。當他跑去珊蒂面前，那個東西飛出了他的雙手。珊蒂抓住了那個飛向她的東西。
原來是一個又大又綠的塑膠青蛙！珊蒂睜大著眼，接著開口大笑。阿仁跟她朋友都知道了為什麼珊蒂今天都不笑也不講話了！她前排的四顆牙不見了！

eng: I wake up at night feeling thirsty. I want to get some water. I start looking for my slippers under the bed.
Oh my God! There is a tiger under my bed.
Now what should I do?
Should I call Ma? What if the tiger roars?
Should I just go back to sleep? But I am not sleepy any more.
Then someone turns on the light. Ma is standing at the door.
“What happened dear?Did you call me?” asks Ma.
I point towards the tiger. Ma bends and pulls the tiger out from under the bed!
Hey, this is no tiger. This is my thick yellow and black sweater. Its buttons shine like a tiger's eyes.
I got scared for nothing!Ma gets me some water.
Now I will sleep. And dream about real tigers in a jungle!
zho:
半夜
我口渴醒來，想要喝水。開始去找我床底下的拖鞋。
天呀！床下有一隻老虎。
我該怎麼辦呢？
要不要叫媽媽來？老虎吼起來怎麼辦？
還是回去睡覺呢？可是我已經不想睡了。
這時候燈亮了，媽媽站在門口。
「小寶貝怎麼了？你有叫我嗎？」媽媽問。
我指著床下那隻老虎，媽媽彎下腰，把老虎拖出來！

哎呀！没有老虎。是我

那件黑

黃
交錯的厚外套，外套上的釦子就像老虎的眼睛一樣閃閃發亮。
没什麼好怕的！媽媽幫我拿水來。

現在我可以好好睡覺了，做個叢林老虎

的好夢！

eng:
Summer is almost over. Mangoes will also get over.
Hashim loves mangoes.
He wants to keep the mangoes.How can he keep them for the whole year?
Baba says mangoes can stay the whole year. First we must dry them. "Germs die without water," he says."So dry mangoes do not go bad."
"How do we dry them?" asks Hashim."Add salt to them!" says Baba
Then Baba and Hashim add salt to the mangoes.They also spread them in the sun to dry.
When the mangoes are dry, they put them in a bottle. Then they add oil to it. Oil stops the air and the germs from reaching the mango.
"Baba, we have made pickle!" says Hashim.

How can we preserve our favourite fruits and vegetables?                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          What are some other ways?

Potato slice + boil + dry = potato chips (to be fried and eaten)
Any fruit + sugar + lemon + cook = jam

Tomato + salt + sun + oil = sun-dried tomatoes
Lemon + salt = lemon preserves
zho: 哈士姆喜欢芒果。这个夏天，芒果要烂了。哈士姆希望能保存它们。
爸爸告诉哈士姆，如果可以除去芒果里的水分，那么芒果就不会烂掉。“细菌没有了水，就不能生存了”他说。
“怎么能把水分从芒果里拿出去呢？”哈士姆问。“给芒果加一点盐！”爸爸说。
然后，爸爸和哈士姆把芒果拿到室外去晾晒。
他们把芒果放到罐子里，再放上一些油。油会阻隔芒果被细菌污染。
"爸爸，我们做好了的芒果干“ 哈士姆说。
我们如何把喜爱的水果和蔬菜进行保存呢？
土豆切片+煮熟+晒干=土豆片 （ 可以油炸吃）任何水果+糖+柠檬+煮熟= 果酱
西红柿+盐+太阳+油=  西红柿干柠檬+盐= 柠檬蜜饯

eng: Meera lives in a small village. It is right on top of a mountain in Himachal Pradesh. From her kitchen window, she can see snowcapped mountains. Huge eagles with golden wings often fly over their house. One day, when she is older and taller, Meera wishes to climb up to the highest peak and look down at the other side.

But today, Meera, her brother Rajesh, and Ma are walking downhill. They are going to the market to buy new shoes. The town is far but Meera does not mind. She walks an hour every day to go to school. They set out at dawn. They have to walk for two hours to reach the main road. Then they will take the bus.
Sometimes, the path disappears and they slide down the rocks. “Whee!” say Meera and Rajesh as they jump over the stones.
Crunch crunch, go the twigs and dry leaves under their feet."Cree ..ckrr..ckre!" a small green barbet calls from the shrubs. A gang of langurs watch them quietly from the pine trees.

Meera stops to drink water from a spring hidden behind rocks and ferns. Suddenly, she sees a little bird. It is lying in the ferns.“Poor thing. He has injured his wing,” says Ma. She gently picks up the bird.“Should we take him with us?” asks Meera.The bird is a spotted forktail. The bird watches them with his tiny eyes. He is scared. “Do not worry,” Meera tells him softly.
“First I must mend the wing,” says Ma. They put some wet earth on the wing and wrap the bird in a big leaf. Meera puts the bird in her cloth bag.

On the main road, the bus has just arrived. In the bus, Meera can feel the bird moving about in her bag. “Maybe he is hungry,” says Ma. “So am I,” says Rajesh. They eat some roasted gram. Meera crushes a few and gives it to the bird.


The old bus rumbles along on the winding mountain road.
The town is noisy and crowded. “Stay close to me, Meera and Rajesh!” Ma calls. They hold hands tightly.

When they reach the market, they buy Meera’s shoes. Ma also buys some hot jalebis for them from the sweet shop.Meera gives the bird a tiny piece but he does not like it. He instead tries to peck at the cloth bag.

Soon it is time to take the bus to go back home. As the bus sways from side to side, Meera can hear the little bird chirping in her bag.“We will soon be at the spring,” Meera whispers to the bird. When they reach the spring, Meera lets him out. He hops a bit, drinks some water and then sits on Meera’s feet. The bird likes the new shoes, too!
It is almost dark when they get home. Meera makes a soft bed with some straw for the bird. The bird goes to sleep in his new bed.
Meera and the bird become good friends. Meera gives him tiny rice and chana balls to eat. After a week, the bird suddenly flies away.
Now, every time Meera walks down the hill, she sees a black-and- white bird with a long tail.The bird always nods and chirps at her. Do you think he is the same bird?
zho: 米拉和家人一起住在一个小村庄里。 这个村庄坐落在印度喜马偕尔邦的一座山上。 从米拉家厨房的窗户往外看，她能看到一片片被白雪覆盖的山脉。 有时候，米拉也经常看见一只只拍打金色翅膀的巨大老鹰从他们的家飞过。有一天，当她长大又长高时，米拉许了一个愿望。她希望自己可以爬上山的最高峰，然后俯视山的另一侧。
然而今天，米拉和她的弟弟拉吉什与妈妈一起走下山。他们打算到山下小镇的超市购买新鞋子。 小镇离米拉住的村庄很远，但米拉并不介意。 这是因为她每天都花一个小时步行上学。米拉一行人在黎明时出发前往超市。他们必须步行两个小时才会抵达通往小镇的主要道路，然后再乘坐公共巴士前往小镇。
有时他们找不到小路时，他们会靠着石头往下滑。 “ 唷！”米拉和拉吉什跳过石头时兴高采烈地叫喊。
他们穿过丛林。小树枝和脚踩到的干树叶会发出嘎吱嘎吱的声响。 “ 斯克里，斯克里！”他们听见灌木中发出绿色的热带巨嘴鸟的叫声。 松树上有一群叶猴静静地看着他们。
米拉停止从藏在岩石和蕨类后面的泉水中取水来喝。 突然，她看到一只受伤的小鸟。 小鸟静静地躺在蕨类中。“可怜的小东西。 它的翅膀受伤了，”妈妈说。 她小心翼翼地捡起那只受伤的小鸟。“我们应该把它带上吗？”米拉问。这只鸟是斑背燕尾。 小鸟用它的小眼睛看着米拉他们。 它很害怕。 “别担心，” 米拉轻声地安慰它。
“我必须先治疗小鸟的翅膀，” 妈妈说。 他们在小鸟的翅膀上放了一些湿泥土，然后用一片大叶子包住。 然后，米拉小心地将小鸟放入她的布袋。
这时，公共巴士刚刚到达前往小镇的主要道路。 在公共汽车上，米拉感觉到小鸟在她的书包里移动。 “也许它饿了，”妈妈说。 “我也饿了，” 拉吉什说。 他们吃了一些烤豆。米拉压碎一些烤豆然后喂给小鸟吃。那辆老旧的公共巴士在蜿蜒的山路上隆隆作响。
小镇人山人海，非常喧闹和拥挤。“米拉和拉吉什，离我近一些！”妈妈说。 他们紧紧握住彼此的手。
抵达超市时，他们买了米拉的新鞋子。 妈妈还在甜品店买了一些刚出炉的蜜糖炸甜圈。米拉给小鸟一小块炸甜圈吃，可是它不喜欢。 相反的，小鸟一直在啄米拉的布袋。
很快，已经到该乘公共巴士回家的时间了。 公共巴士转弯非常摇晃，巴士从一边摇去另外一边。米拉可以听到小鸟在她的布袋里吱吱叫。“我们很快就要到泉水附近了，”米拉对小鸟低声说。 当他们到达泉水边时，米拉把它从布袋放了出来。 小鸟跳了一下，喝了些泉水，然后飞到米拉的脚上坐了下来。 小鸟也喜欢米拉的新鞋！
当米拉一行人回到家时，天已经快黑了。 米拉用一些稻草为小鸟做了一张柔软的床。 小鸟开心地飞到它的新床上睡觉。
之后，米拉和小鸟成了好朋友。 米拉每天喂它吃米饭粒和烤丸子。 一周后，小鸟突然飞走了。
现在，每当米拉步行下山时都会看到一只长尾巴，黑白色的鸟。那只鸟总是向她点头和对着她叫。 你觉得它和小鸟是同一只鸟吗？
“妈妈，我们帮你做个稻草人么？”Gauri问道。妈妈正在把一些稻草编织成稻草人。她把一件旧衬衫套在稻草上，然后把它们竖在草堆上。
Gauri 走到晾晒衣服的晾衣杆旁边。她挑选了一条裙子。“我要给稻草人穿上我的新裙子，给她的头发系上红丝带！她看上去会非常可爱的！"
“你真可爱！你不能有一个漂亮的稻草人。稻草人是用来吓走鸟群的，所以他们必须看起来很可怕！像这样！”妈妈说道，挥舞手臂做了个吓人的鬼脸。Gauri咯咯的笑道。“妈妈你看上去好好笑！”
妈妈把稻草人放到田地里，并将他们绑到高高的谷堆上面。“好了，做个称职的稻草人，吓走鸟吧。”Gauri一边拍拍稻草人的肩膀，一边说道。
Gauri和她的妈妈回到她们的小屋。Gauri走进屋里，躺在她的小床上。一轮大大的黄圆月亮缓缓升起，给田地沐浴一层柔软，浅白的光。
Gauri 看到一个稻草人低头看着自己的衣服。“为什么我们总是穿着破碎的旧衣服？”其中一个稻草人叹气说道。“我希望我们能有漂亮的衣服穿！”
一个稻草人试穿了那条可爱的有着亮片的红裙子。它们在月光下闪闪发光。她试了试漂亮的红丝带，他们在晚风中与她的稻草头发一起缓缓飘扬。她因为有了新衣服而高兴的翩翩起舞。
很快，其他的稻草人都忙着换新装！他们开始了盛大的游行。他们行走！旋转！跳跃！欢呼！他们抛起空空的泥罐脑袋，他们扬起笑脸，他们享受这欢乐的时光！
同时，成百上千的鸟儿飞到了田地里，到处都是，到处啄食！“太好吃了！”其中一只鸟一边用翅膀擦嘴一边说道。
“不是每天都能在田地里饱餐一顿，而不被稻草人轰走。”一个稻草人听到了声音并四处张望。他们吓坏了！“走开！快走开！”他们对鸟儿们大叫到，狂野的挥舞着他们的稻草手臂。
Gauri尖叫起来。她的妈妈急忙跑过来。“Gauri, Gauri,怎么了？快醒醒！”“噢妈妈，那些鸟！他们把粮食都吃光了！”她妈妈紧紧的抱着她，说道 “嘘，我的孩子！你看外面的田地。它们很安全！你一定是做噩梦了。”
Gauri朝外望去。她看到稻草人们，依然静静的站在原处。
哦，等一下，他们在朝她招手吗？她走近了看。她看到其中一个稻草人头上飘扬的红丝带。她眨了眨眼，又看了看，稻草人也朝她挤眼睛了吗？
eng: "Please Ma, may I help you make scarecrows?" asked Gauri. Ma was tying some sticks together to make a scarecrow. She put an old shirt over the sticks, and then stuffed it with hay.
Gauri walked to the clothesline where the washed clothes were drying. She picked up a dress. "I will dress her up in my new red frock and tie her hair with red ribbons too! She will look so lovely!"

“You silly girl. You can’t have a pretty scarecrow. Scarecrows have to scare the birds away, and so they must look scary! Like this!” said Mother, making a face and waving her arms. Gauri giggled. “You look so funny Ma!”
Mother took the scarecrows into the fields and fixed them amidst the tall stalks of grain. "There now, be good scarecrows and chase the birds away," said Gauri, patting them.
Gauri and her mother returned to their hut. Gauri went inside and lay on her cot. A big yellow moon was rising, bathing the field in a soft, white glow.

Gauri saw a scarecrow look down at its clothes. “Why do we always have to wear these tattered old clothes?” said a scarecrow with a sigh. “I wish we had something pretty to wear!” “Yes, me too!” said another. The scarecrows looked around the field. Suddenly, one of them called out, “Hey, look at those lovely clothes flapping in the breeze. Why don’t we wear those?” “Oo-oo! These clothes are so pretty. Let us try them on!” said another.

One scarecrow tried on a lovely red dress with sequins on them. It sparkled in the moonlight. She tied the pretty red ribbons that were flapping in the breeze on her straw hair. Thrilled with her new clothes she began to show them off.

Soon, all the scarecrows were busy dressing up! They began to parade. They walked! They turned! They twisted! They twirled!They tossed their empty mud-pot heads, and smiled their crooked mud-pot smiles. They were having a wonderful time!

At the same time, hundreds of birds flew down to the fields. Birds here, birds there, birds everywhere. Beaks smacking! Beaks munching! Beaks chomping!"Mmm! This is delicious!" said one, as she wiped her beak with her wing.

“It is not everyday that we can eat in the fields, without being shooed away by the scarecrows.” The scarecrows heard this and looked around. They were horrified! “Shoo! Be gone!” they shouted at the birds, waving their straw hands wildly, to and fro.

Gauri screamed. Her mother came running.“Gauri, Gauri, what is the matter? Wake up!”“Oh Ma, the birds! They are eating up all the grain.”Her mother held her tight, and said, “Shh, my child! Look at the fields. They are safe! It must be a bad dream.”
Gauri looked out. She saw the scarecrows, standing just where they were placed.
Oh, wait a minute, were they waving to her? She looked closer. She saw a red ribbon fluttering on a scarecrow's hair. She blinked and looked again. Did the scarecrow just wink at her?

Anaya’s most favorite thing in the world is her thumb. She loves her round, thick and blobby thumb as it sits in her mouth. She sucks it in bed, she sucks it in class and she sucks it on the swing. She sucks it all the time! Her parents don’t like it much and are always saying, ‘Your thumb smells’, ‘Anaya stop!’, ‘Anaya don’t!’

Anaya is at the zoo today. Her parents do not look at her thumb since they are busy looking at the animals. Anaya sees an elephant. She spots a calf that is not splashing with his mother. He is not trumpeting with his father. He is not eating bananas with his friends. What is the baby elephant doing? Sucking his trunk! CHUSK! CHUSK!

Just ahead are some deer. Anaya sees a fawn that is not munching with her mother. She is not looking at other animals like her father. She is not prancing with her friends. What is the baby deer doing? Sucking her hoof! CHUSK! CHUSK!

Next, the monkeys call out. Anaya spots an infant who is not clinging to her mother. She is not playing the clown with her father. She is not playing hide and seek with her friends. What is the baby monkey doing? Sucking her thumb! CHUSK! CHUSK!

Anaya spots hippos in the water. She sees a hippopotamus calf that is not yawning wide with her mother. She is not grunting with her father. She is not swimming with her friends. What is the baby hippo doing? Sucking her lip! CHUSK! CHUSK!

The tigers welcome her with a growl. And look at that tiger cub! He is not snoozing with his mother. He is not swatting flies with his father. He is not sneaking up on his friends. What is the baby tiger doing? Sucking his tail! CHUSK! CHUSK!

Anaya sits down and thinks of the baby animals that are missing all the fun. Anaya looks at the people around her. She sees a boy on his father's shoulders waving his arms. She sees a boy carrying cotton candy and a juice can.

She sees a girl clicking pictures with a camera. She sees a baby shaking her rattle. All the children are having fun! Anaya looks down her nose and sees her own hand curled up, with the thumb in her mouth. Could she put her thumb to better use?

Anaya pulls her thumb out of her mouth, runs ahead and stops between her parents. She holds onto their hands, counts 1-2-3, jumps up and swings high in the air . “WHEEE!” And the little baby monkey watching her from above does the same.
zho: 阿娜娅最喜欢她的大拇哥。她喜欢大拇哥在嘴里嘬起来圆鼓鼓的，软嘟嘟的口感。所以她睡觉时候吃手指，上课时候吃手指，打秋千的时候也吃手指，她总是在吃手指。她的爸爸妈妈不喜欢她的大拇指，他们总说，“你的大拇指臭臭的”“阿娜娅别吃手指了”“阿娜娅停下来！”
阿娜娅今天去动物园玩。爸爸妈妈光顾着看动物，没时间管阿娜娅的大拇哥了。阿娜娅看到一头大象，然后她看到一个小象，它没有跟象妈妈一起喷水，也没有跟象爸爸一起吹号，也没有跟伙伴们一起吃香蕉。小象在最什么呢？它在嘬自己的长鼻子！嗤！嗤！
一抬头，阿娜娅看到一些鹿，她看到一直小鹿，它没有跟鹿妈妈一起吃草，也没有跟鹿爸爸一起放哨，也没有跟小伙伴一起蹦蹦跳跳。小鹿在干什么呢？它在吸吮它的蹄子！嗤！嗤！
然后，猴子吸引了阿娜娅的注意力。 她看到一个猴宝宝没有勾在猴妈妈身上，也没有和猴爸爸一起玩小丑游戏，也没有跟其他猴宝宝玩捉迷藏。猴宝宝在做什么？她在吃自己的大拇指！嗤！嗤！
阿娜娅在水里发现河马一家。她看到河马宝宝没有跟她妈妈一起打呵欠，也没有跟爸爸一起打呼噜，也没有跟小伙伴一起游泳。河马宝宝在做什么？她在吮自己的嘴唇。嗤！嗤！
老虎们低声地咆哮欢迎阿娜娅。看那只虎宝宝！它没有跟虎妈妈一起打盹，也没有和虎爸爸一起拍苍蝇，它也没有偷偷爬到小伙伴的背上。虎宝宝在干什么？嘬他的尾巴！嗤！嗤！
阿娜娅坐下来，想想这些小动物们错过了好多有趣的事情。她看看四周的人们，一个小男孩坐在他爸爸的肩头挥舞着双臂，一个小男孩手里拿着棉花糖和果汁罐。
她看到一个小女孩用相机拍下美丽的照片；她看到一个小宝宝在晃自己的摇铃。所有的小朋友都好开心！阿娜娅低头看看她自己卷起来的小手，拇指塞在嘴巴里。她的拇指有没有更好的用处？
阿娜娅把她的拇指从嘴里拿出来，跑到爸爸妈妈前面。她一手拉着爸爸，一手拉着妈妈，数1-2-3， 跳起来在空中晃起来！“耶~”所有的猴宝宝都看着她模仿她。

eng: Ammu did not have a puppy.But she told everyone in school that she did.
"My puppy’s name is Simba," she told Venu."Simba eats bananas," she told Abdul."Simba is black," she told Kumari."Simba plays ball with me," she told Unni.
So Venu, Abdul, Kumari, and Unni told Ammu that they would come home.To see Simba. Ammu shook her head."You can’t," she said.
"Why?" they asked."Because Simba is scared of crowds," said Ammu."Then we’ll play with him one by one," said Kumari.
"You can’t," Ammu said."Why?" asked Unni."Because we’re going out today," said Ammu.
"Then we’ll come tomorrow," said Abdul."We’ll bring bananas for him," said Venu."We’ll play with him one by one," said Kumari."Okay," said Ammu.  She didn’t know what else to say.
That evening, Ammu asked Achan if he would buy a puppy for her."We’ll see," said Achan."But it’s urgent," said Ammu. Achan laughed. Ammu didn’t eat dinner. She felt sick.
She didn’t want to think about tomorrow.  In the morning, Amma said, "You look ill."She touched Ammu’s forehead. A fever!
"Stay at home today," Amma said.So Ammu skipped school.She lay in bed all day. She didn’t smile at all.All she ate was a slice of bread.
In the evening, Venu, Abdul, Kumari, and Unni came home."Why didn’t you come to school today?" asked Unni."I am sick," said Ammu.
"We saw Simba," said Abdul."Where?" asked Ammu."In the garden," said Kumari.
"He didn’t want to play ball," said Abdul.Suddenly, Ammu got up from bed. She ran outside.
It was true. There was a puppy in her garden. Simba!"But he’s not black," said Venu. "He’s brown.’""Oh," said Ammu. "I made that up!"
"He’s not afraid of crowds," said Abdul."Oh," said Ammu. "I made that up!"
"He doesn’t like playing ball," said Unni."Oh," said Ammu. "I made that up!"
"But he loves bananas," said Kumari."I told you, didn’t I?" smiled Ammu happily.
zho: 安姆没有小狗。但她对学校里的所有人说她有。
“我的小狗叫香卡，”她对维努说。“香卡吃香蕉，”她对阿卜杜勒说。“香卡是黑色的，”她对库玛里说。“香卡和我玩球球，”她对尤尼说。
所以维努、阿卜杜勒、库玛里和尤尼告诉安姆，他们会到家里来看香卡。安姆摇了摇头。“你们不可以，”她说。
﻿“为什么？”他们问。“因为香卡害怕人多，”安姆说。“那么我们会一个个跟它玩。”库玛里说。
“你们不可以，”安姆说。“为什么？”尤尼说。“因为我们今天要出门，”安姆说。
﻿“那么我们明天来，”阿卜杜勒说。“我们会带香蕉给它，”维努说。“我们会一个个跟它玩，”库玛里说。“好吧，”安姆说。她不知道该说什么。
那天晚上，安姆问爸爸要不要给她买一只小狗。“不一定，”爸爸说。“但是这很急的，”安姆说。艾肯笑了。安姆没有吃晚饭。她感觉不舒服。
她不想再想明天的事。第二天早上，妈妈说：“你看起来生病了。”她摸了摸安姆的额头。是发烧！
﻿“今天待在家里吧，”安姆说。﻿所以安姆没有去学校。她一整天都躺在床上。没有微笑。她只吃了一片面包。
﻿﻿晚上，维努、阿卜杜勒、库玛里和尤尼来到了家里。“你今天为什么没来上学？”尤尼说。“我生病了，”安姆说。
﻿“我们看到香卡了，”阿卜杜勒说。“在哪？”安姆说。“在花园里。”库玛里说。
﻿“它不想玩球球，”阿卜杜勒说。﻿突然，安姆从床上起来了。她跑到了外面。
这是真的。在她的花园里有一只小狗。香卡！“但是它不是黑色的，”维努说，“它是棕色的。”“哦，”安姆说，“我是编的！”
“它不害怕人多，”阿卜杜勒说。“哦，”安姆说，“我是编的！”

“它不喜欢玩球球，”尤尼说。

“哦，”安姆说，“我是编的！”
﻿“但是它喜欢香蕉，”库玛里说。“我跟你说过了，不是吗？”安姆高兴地笑了。
Kicchu 早早地起了床。“我要去捉魚了”，他打著哈欠說道。
他在去池塘的路上碰到了他最要好的朋友Choru。他們整天都在一起玩。
Munia看到他們拿著魚竿在趕路。於是他們問Munia“我們要去池塘捉魚，你一起來吧！”
Munia想了想說道“不要捉魚啦！”“沒有水，魚兒會死的。”
他們才不要聽Munia的話，徑直去了池塘。
Kicchu和Choru坐在池塘邊等著，有兩條魚游了過來，一條瘦瘦的一條圓圓的。
這時候游過來第三條魚，是他們見過最大的！Munia笑著說："這條魚比我爸爸的腳還大！"
Kicchu 和 Choru為了這條大魚爭了起來。Kicchu 叫道“這是我的魚！”Choru也教導“不！這是我的魚！”
Kicchu 使勁拉魚竿，Choru 也使勁拉魚竿。
啪! 魚竿斷了！咚！Kicchu摔倒了。嘩啦！Choru掉進了水裡。
想想看這是怎麼回事呢？原來魚兒們在水裡把魚線栓在一起啦！
eng: a warm morning , Raja woke up with a yawn and said to himself "lets go for fishing now".
While going to the pond,he met Ram,his best friend and invited him to go to the pond together.
Sita saw them going for fishing. The boys asked her if she wanted to come with them.
Sita thought for a moment and said "don't do this,fishes will die when separated by water"
They didn't paid attention to her and continued on their way to the pond.
Raja and Ram sat near the pond and saw to fishes jumping in water,one was a thin and second a fat one.
There came a third fish. They didn't saw any fish bigger than this! Sita said" This fish is even bigger than my father's foot!"
Raja and Ram took their fishing rods with and struggled for the fish.Ram said"its mine!"Raja said"no,its mine!"
Raja pulled the rod, Ram pulled stronger.
BOOM! They fell down as their rods broke.
Do you know why ?Any guesses ?fished tied their strings together!

zho: 奶奶叫醒賈尼斯：“起來，賈尼斯!”。賈尼斯起床。今天是她待在劉奶奶家的最后一天。
賈尼斯答應了居住在孟買的家人會帶些手信回去。但她什麼也沒買！賈尼斯問道：“劉奶奶，您能帶我去購物嗎？”。劉奶奶居住在加爾各答的Tiretti市集。這裡也稱作為唐人街。
賈尼斯和劉奶奶一起去探索唐人街。人力車在街上穿梭。 人力車的木輪發出咔噠聲。 人力車的鈴鐺叮當作響。空氣中彌漫著香氣。
第一站是李先生的店。“李先生 ，明天我就要回孟買。 我能買些什麼當手信？” “這些紫色梅子糖果怎麼樣？”賈尼斯贊道：“嗯！這糖果又甜又香！” “我的兄弟一定會喜歡。” “我的兄弟一定會喜歡。”
下一站是陳太太的店。“陳太太，明天我要回孟買。我能買些什麼當手信？。”“這種黑木耳怎麼樣？ 在湯中加入一些黑木耳，會減緩流鼻涕的症狀。”賈尼斯驚嘆道：“嗚！ 這看起來真像一個巨大的黑耳朵！”。“我母親一定會喜歡。”
接著她們去黃太太的店。“黃太太，明天我就要回孟買。我能買些什麼當手信？”“這盞美麗的燈籠怎麼樣？”賈尼斯贊嘆：“這盞燈籠的顏色是鳳凰花的顏色。我父親一定會喜歡。”
手信買齊了，賈尼斯也餓壞了！劉奶奶買了餃子湯和包子。嘖嘖！賈尼斯贊道：“這個好吃。” 。
賈尼斯和奶奶停留在一座寺廟裡。 寺廟裡彌漫著焚香的氣味。劉奶奶說：“當人們去世時，他們變成靈魂。我們啟程之前，會祈求他們的祝福。”
人們正在在大廳裡的桌子打麻將。 麻將牌咔嗒作響！奶奶說：“麻將牌上刻著龍，風和花的圖案。” 賈尼斯說：“那比跳房子更加刺激！。”
在回家途中，賈尼斯看見一位女士正在讀報紙。賈尼斯問道：“那是華文報章嗎？”。劉奶奶回答：“是的！”。
“這是印度唯一的華文報章。隻能在加爾各答找的到。”賈尼斯到了家，便開始包裝手信。劉奶奶問道：“賈尼斯，你已經為其他人買了手信，但你會帶回什麼？”。賈尼斯回答道：“我們的記憶呀，奶奶，”。 “那是最好的手信！”
eng: “Janice, wake up!” Grandma calls.Janice jumps out of bed. Today is her last day at Grandma Liu’s house.

Janice had promised her family in Mumbai that she wouldbring back gifts. But she has not bought anything yet!“Grandma Liu, can you please take me shopping?”  Janice asks.Grandma Liu lives in Tiretti Bazaar in Kolkata. It is also known as Chinatown.

Janice and Grandma Liu set off to explore Chinatown. 
Rickshaws zig-zag. Their wooden wheels go clackety-clack. Their bells go jingle-jangle.The air smells good enough to eat.

The first stop is Mr. Lee’s. “Mr. Lee, I am going home to Mumbai tomorrow. What can I take back?”“How about these purple plum candies?”“Mmmm! Sweet and tangy!” says Janice. “My brother will love them.”

The next stop is Mrs. Chen’s shop. “Mrs. Chen, I am going home to Mumbai tomorrow. What can I take back?”
“How about this black fungus? Put some in soup and it will cure sniffles.”“Oooo! That looks like a huge black ear!” says Janice. “My mother will love it.”

Off to Mrs. Wong’s shop. “Mrs. Wong, I am going home to Mumbai tomorrow. What can I take back?” “How about this beautiful lantern?”“It is the colour of gulmohar flowers” says Janice, “My father will love it.”
The shopping is done,and Janice is hungry!Grandma Liu buys dumpling soup and baozi buns. Slurrrp! “This is delicious,”Janice says.
Janice and Grandma stop at a temple. It smells like incense.“When people pass away,” Grandma Liu says, “they turn into spirits. We seek their blessings before we go on a journey.”

At a table in a big hall, people are playing mahjong. The tiles go click-clack!“The tiles are dragons and wind and flowers,”Grandma says.“That is a lot moreexciting than hopscotch squares!” says Janice.

On the way back home, Janice sees a woman reading a newspaper.“Is that in Chinese?” Janice asks.“Yes!” Grandma Liu says. “This is the only Chinese newspaper in India. You can only find it here in Kolkata.”

At home, Janice starts packing all her gifts.“Janice, you have bought gifts for everyone else, but what will you take back?” asks Grandma Liu.“Our memories, Grandma,” Janice says. “They were the best gift of all!”
Once upon a time, there were four friends and they decided to do a toy race.
﻿                  Rani has a shiny green car.         Pihu has a black and yellow auto.
﻿               ﻿Rohit has big red bus.      Aman has long blue lorry.
On your marks, get set, ready....  Go!!!!Here comes Lucky- the dog, joining the race.....
﻿ ﻿﻿Everybody staring at Lucky...                   The fastest of all..                         And so the winner is our Lucky!!!!
zho: 四个朋友准备赛车。
Venn有一辆绿色的汽车米娜有一辆黄色的汽车。
Sanju有一辆红色的巴士。Manju有一辆蓝色的卡车。
一、而、三，开始！Lucky来了，Lucky加入了比赛。
哇！ Lucky是最快的！ Lucky赢了！

eng: Every day after school, Manu plays hopscotch.She jumps and counts.1, 2, and 3.4, 5, and 6.7, 8, 9, and 10.
But today Manu is feeling itchy-scratchyon her tummy. She jumps and counts.1, 2, and 3.SCRATCH!4, 5, and 6.SCRATCH! SCRATCH!7, 8, 9, and 10.SCRATCH! SCRATCH! SCRATCH!
She sees tiny itchy-scratchy bumps.1, 2, and 3.On her tummy!4, 5, and 6.On her arms!7, 8, 9, and 10.On her back!Itchy-scratchy bumps everywhere!
“You have chickenpox,” says Amma.“You cannot go to school.”
Manu plops herself on the bed and goes,SCRATCH!SCRATCH! SCRATCH!SCRATCH! SCRATCH! SCRATCH!
“Do not scratch!” says Amma.It makes Manu evenmore itchy-scratchy!
When Amma and Baba are not looking,SCRATCH!After eating porridge,SCRATCH! SCRATCH!
“Do not scratch!”yell Amma and Baba.
But when she lies onthe bed, again she goes,SCRATCH!SCRATCH! SCRATCH!SCRATCH! SCRATCH!SCRATCH!
Manu tries and tries not toSCRATCH! SCRATCH!She plays snakesand ladders.She dreams up many stories.She forgets to SCRATCH! SCRATCH!

Slowly, the bumps disappear. Manu counts.10, 9, and 8. 7, 6, and 5. 4, 3, 2, and 1.
Until one day Manu pulls her shirt up.All the itchy-scratchy bumps are...GONE!
Now Manu can play hopscotch.She jumps and counts.1, 2, and 3.4, 5, and 6.7, 8, 9, and 10.
zho: 每天放學后，馬努都玩跳房子。她跳又數。1, 2 和 3。4, 5 和 6。7, 8, 9和 10。
但今天馬努的肚子感覺痒痒的。她跳起來並且很重要。 她跳起來，數數。1, 2 和 3。抓！4, 5 和 6。抓！ 抓！7, 8, 9 和 10。抓！ 抓！ 抓！
她看到小小，痒痒的痘痘。1, 2 和 3。在她的肚子上！4, 5和 6。在她的懷裡！7, 8, 9 和 10。在她背上！痒痒的痘痘到處都是！
“你有水痘，”奶奶說。“你不能去上學。”
馬努趴在床上而開始抓！抓！ 抓！抓！ 抓！ 抓！
“不要抓它！”奶奶說。這使馬努更痒！
當奶奶和爺爺沒在看的時候抓！吃完粥后，抓！ 抓！
“別抓！” 奶奶和爺爺喊。
但當她躺在床上時，她又，抓！抓！ 抓！抓！ 抓！抓！
馬努努力試著不去 抓！ 抓！他玩一個叫做蛇和梯子的游戲她幻想著許多故事。她忘了抓痒！ 抓！
痘痘慢慢的消失了。 馬努數著。10, 9 和 8。 7, 6 和 5。 4, 3, 2 和 1。直到有一天，馬努拉起她的襯衫。所有痒痒的痘痘都不見了！
現在馬努可以玩跳房子了。她跳又數。1, 2 和 3。4, 5 和 6。7, 8, 9 和 10。
我們全部都要去水果市集
爸爸買給星巴克一副星星眼鏡媽媽買給我一頂藍色帽子妹妹得到了一隻棒棒糖
在回家的路上，一陣強風，我的藍色小帽帽被吹走了！！！不~~~~~
我的藍色帽子卡在樹枝上面，拿不到怎麼辦？
我很傷心一直哭，一直哭，一直哭，吃不下飯。
夜晚來臨，月亮公公出來了，他看到我的帽子卡在樹上。
月亮公公戴上我的帽子，對我微笑，我也對他微笑。
隔天到學校，媽媽說月亮公公說要給你一頂新的紅色帽子。
夜晚，我戴上紅色帽子，月亮公公戴上藍色帽子，我很開心，他也很開心。
你覺得太陽叔叔也需要一頂帽子嗎？
猜猜我今天會戴什麼帽子！！！
eng: All of us went to the Dasara fair.
Papa bought Chintu fancy glasses. Mother bought me a bright blue cap. The baby got sugar candy.
On the way home, a very strong wind came.It blew my cap away.
My cap got stuck on a branch of the old Pipal tree.
I cried a lot. And I did not eat my dinner.
Later that night, the moon came up.It looked at my cap on the old Pipal tree.
It tried on my cap. The moon smiled happily. I had to smile too.
After school the next day, my mother gave me a shiny new red cap. “The moon sent it,” she said.
That night, both the moon and I wore our caps and smiled. We were happy.
Do you think the sun needs a hat?
Guess which cap I am wearing today!
Priya hears a sound.Srrr... Srrr...  Who is it?

Priya runs out. She
sees the cow chewing grass.
No, it is not the cow that is making the sound.

Is it the monkey in the tree?
No, it is not the monkey.

Is it the frog hopping in the
grass?
No, it is not the frog.

Is it the deer jumping along?
No, it is not the deer.

Is it the fish in the pond?
No, it is not the fish.

Then Priya sees the elephant!
The elephant is rubbing its back against a tree.
Now Priya has her answer! Srrr... Srrr...
zho:
普里亚听到声音。










嘘

... 










嘘

...

是谁？

普里亚跑了。她看到牛在嚼草。



不，发出声音的不是牛。

eng: Gappu's  class  is going to be performing a theater performance on Wednesday. Komal miss was teaching dance moves for the same.
"Thaka Thimi Thai" " Everybody lift your left hand." Komal miss told the class.
Oh dear! Gappu had raised her right hand. Gappu can't dance!
"Taka Taka Pap Pap Pum!" " Everyone, please run   around the room  fast " Komal miss told the class.
Oh dear ! Gappu is running slowly! Gappu can't dance.
"Thaka Thina Thin Tak. Everybody jump high"
Oh dear! Gappu is sitting down. Gappu can't dance.
"Thupi Thuup Thitli Thin ThinEverybody, bend your right leg inwards. "
"Oh dear! Gappu is lifting her leg in the opposite direction!Gappu can't dance.
Everyone noticed that Gappu was dancing incorrectly and started laughing at her. But, Komal miss knew the way to deal with the situation. " Everybody, follow Gappu's moves" Komal miss said.

"Thaka thimi thai. Some hands can move down, some hands can move up. Thaka Thaka Pap Pap Puum. Some run around the room fast, some run around the room slow. Thakka thina thin tak. It doesn't matter whether you sit or jump!Thop Thop Thaka Thin ThinEveryone dance together. That's all that matters!"
Gappu can dance! And you can dance too!
I have many friends.....
My some friends are elder than me and....
some are younger than me......
And my some friends are aged like my grand father....
And some are children too....
And some friends are such who have a tail......
And some are such who doesn't have legs.....
And some are such who even fly.....
Ohhhhhh Even books are my friends......
But do you know who is my best friend.... Who??? Who???? Who????
My MOM!!!!!
zho: 我有很多朋友。
有些朋友年紀比我大，而 ....
有些年紀比我小。
有些朋友們年紀很大了。
有些朋友們年紀很小。
有些朋友們有尾巴。
有些朋友們沒有腳。
有些朋友們會飛。有些朋友們會游泳。
喔！書本們也是我的好朋友。
但誰是我最好的朋友呢？是誰呢？是誰呢？是誰呢？
是我的媽媽！

eng: “Puchku! Have a bath!”              “Puchku! Eat your food!”
“Puchku! Go to class!”"Puchku! Get on the bus!”
“Where is Puchku?”
Puchku is busy.She has a book to read.Puchku reads all the time.
"Why are you always reading?"asks Boitu."Come, watch TV with us!"says Dodla.
"Books are more fun!” says Puchku. Words become stories and WHOOSH! You are in a new world!
But today, Puchku is sad.She has read all the booksin the library!
"No more books!"wails Puchku."What will I do?"
But, wait! What is that?Puchku looks up and sees..."More books!"
But the shelf is too tall.Puchku is too short.How can she get up there?
Maybe a wash line?How about chairs and tables?
If only Puchku had a giraffe.Or a monkey.
Puchku has a plan. She calls two boys for help.Up, up, upthey climb.Puchku has her hand on a book!But then, it all goes wrong.
AAAAAAAAH!
“What is this?” It is the Very Tall Librarian! She puts Puchku down. "Can I help?"
"I have run out of books,” says Puchku.The Very Tall Librarian smiles.May I pick you up?”Puchku nods.
“I will take this one," says Puchku. "Thank you!"“Take this one too,” says the Very Tall Librarian.
"I loved this book when I was small.You will grow too."she tells Puchku."Until you do, just ask for help."
But Puchku does not hear.
She has a new book!
zho: “Puchku！快去洗澡！”“Puchku！快吃你的饭！”
“Puchku！去上课！”“Puchku！赶紧上巴士！”“Puchku！做你的功课！”
“Puchku到哪里去了呢？”
Puchku非常忙碌。她非常喜欢读书。Puchku一天到晚都在读书 -- 在家，在学校，在公园，甚至在床上。一页一页，一篇一篇，她都把它们一本一本地读完了。
“Puchku，为什么每次都看到你在读书呢？”Boltu问到。“我们一起来看卡通吧！”Dodla说到。
“但是，读书比较有趣啊！”Puchku回答。”“你看到这个圆形！还有这个直线！这里一推，那里一拉，就变成了一个字母。把字母排在一起就变成了一个字。有些字很有智慧，有些很有趣，有些却很伤心，有些带着阳光。我们接着把字连起来，就变成了句子。把句子连起来就变成了故事！当你读故事时，哇～，最像是在另一个世界呢！”
不过今天，Puchku遇到了一个小状况。她已经没有新书读了！在图书馆里的所有书，她都读过一遍了，从 A 到 Z 都读完了。
“我该怎么办！已经没有书读了啊！”Puchku大声地哭泣。
等等！那是什么？Puchku抬头一看，数了数。一层，两层，错！三层装了满满的书。“原来还有书呢！”Puchku高兴地感叹。
不够还有一个非常大的问题。她的个子长得不高，书架却是非常的高。Puchku要怎么才能够拿到书呢？
可能他可以用洗衣线？或者用妈妈的萨莉来荡过去？或者把椅子和桌子叠起来，然后爬上去？
如果有一只长颈鹿或者一只猴子的话，那会多么的方便啊！
Puchku有了个计划，找来了Boltu和Dolda帮忙。静悄悄地，Puchku爬上了他们的肩膀上。“Boltu，你好重啊！”Dolda投诉着。“都跟你说别吃最后的那个饼了。”“不是我重，是Puchku！”Boltu反驳。“安静！差点到了！”Puchku说。就在这时候，不幸的事情发生了。
“这里到底发生了什么事？”一位非常高的图书管理员走了过来。她把Puchku救了下来。 Boltu和Dolda赶紧的逃走了。Puchku泪眼汪汪的看着书架上的书，管理员问了她：“我可以帮你什么吗？”
“刚才，我实在爬书架因为我想拿上面的书， 我已经没有书读了”Puchku伤心地说。“啊你怎么不早说啊？”管理员说到。“只要我在，你不需要自己爬，找我抱上你就行了。”
“我要这个，这个，还有那个！”Puchku很高兴地说。“谢谢！”“你也拿这个吧。我小时候非常喜欢读这本。”管理员说到。
“诶，你也有小过吗？”Puchku问。“那当然，比你还小呢。”管理员说。“不过我慢慢长高，你也会的。在你长高之前，只要找我，我就会抱你起来选书。”
Puchku已经没在听了！她已经投入在书里，这里圈，那里写。忙着在读书。
因为Puchku有一本新书了。

eng: I have a friend. She lives in my house.
When I am happy, so is she.
When I cry, she cries too.
But I cannot hear her voice. My friend lives inside the mirror.
“Come out,” I tell her, “we will play.” She does not come out.
I am not happy. I go to sleep.
She comes out of the mirror in my sleep! And we have fun.
We play, we run, we shout and scream together.
When I talk to her, she also talks to me.
In the morning, my friend will go back into the mirror.
But I don't mind at all. We will play again in my dreams!
zho: 我有一個朋友，她住在我家。
當我感到開心時，她也開心。
當我哭泣時，她也哭泣。
可是我聽不見她的聲音，我的朋友住在鏡子裡。
我對她說：「出來！我們一起玩！」但她沒有從鏡子裡出來。
我不開心。我睡著了。
在夢裡，她離開了鏡子。我們很開心。
我們一起玩耍，一起奔跑，一起大聲吶喊。
當我跟她說話時，她也跟我說話。
早晨來臨時，我的朋友會回到鏡子裡。
我一點也不介意，因為我們會再次在夢裡一起玩。
米拉和我是好朋友。她是这个世界上我最喜欢的人。你知道为什么吗？因为只有她能看见我。

她喜欢的我都喜欢，我喜欢的，她也都喜欢。我们的名字也很像。

米拉和

美拉。
在她身上发生的事情，同样也会在我身上发生。“我掉了一颗牙“，米拉说。当我掉了一根刺的时候。
有的时候，我们还有点不一样。米拉制造麻烦，我解决它们。

比如说有一天外面正在下雨——“噢我们今天不能出去玩了”

米拉说。
我知道了！我们可以做个纸船。
或者是当她开学的时候。“如果我交不到朋友怎么办？”米拉着急的说。“你和我成为了朋友啊，现在更交更多的朋友”我告诉她。
现在到我讲故事啦。美拉是这个世界上我最喜欢的人。你知道为什么吗？它总是能变换视角，所以我也能有不同的视角。
美拉从来不让我自己单独打架。虽然说她也帮不上什么忙。

她让每天都变成冒险。就像上次我们一起去了

姆鲁古迷宫。“让我们冲出去“美拉说。
就像美拉说的，我们是好朋友。
eng: Meera and I are a team. She’s my most favourite person in the world. Do you know why? She’s the only one who can see me!
Everything she likes, I like. Everything I like, she likes. Our names also sound the same. Meera and Ameera!
Things that happen to her happen to me too. “I lost another tooth,” Meera says. While I lost another quill.
Sometimes, we can be a little different. Meera makes up problems. I make them go away.
Like the other day when it was raining—“Oh no, now we can’t go out to play,” Meera cried.
But I had an idea! Off we sailed on a paper boat.
Or the time when she started school.“What if I don’t make any friends?” Meera was worried.“You made friends with me. Now go make one more friend,” I told her.
It’s my turn to tell the story now. Ameera is my most favourite person in the world. Do you know why? She turns stuff upside down, just so I have a different view.
Ameera never lets me walk into a fight alone. Even though she doesn’t help much.
She makes every day a BIG adventure. Like the time we had to get out of a murukku maze. “I know! Let’s eat our way out,” Ameera said.
Like Ameera said, we’re a team.

zho: 姐姐，姐姐，我想知道……你想知道什么，弟弟，想知道什么？我想知道，我想知道，太阳晚上去了哪里。你认为去了哪里呢，弟弟，你认为呢？我认为，我认为……告诉我，弟弟，你认为去了哪里呢？
我认为，说不定是妖魔。凶恶的、黑色的暗夜妖魔每天晚上吞下太阳当作晚饭你不见日落的时候，整个蓝天都被太阳的鲜血浸染？
然而太阳辉煌的、勇敢的、耀眼的金色太阳会和暗夜妖魔搏斗每夜，整夜直到清晨又恢复如初，继续照耀万物我认为太阳晚上是去了这里。在一番激烈的搏斗之后落进了恶魔嘴里。我聪明吧，姐姐？
是很聪明，弟弟，非常聪明而且或许你说得对……可是在我读的那些书里他们不是这么说的。他们怎么说呢，姐姐，他们怎么说？你认为呢，弟弟，你认为呢？我认为，我认为……告诉我，弟弟，你认为呢？
我认为，说不定当我们的地球进入夜晚的时候海底深处却是明亮的白昼。美人鱼从海底的洞穴跳着舞出来和鲨鱼尽情嬉游
我们去年夏天在孟买的时候亲眼见过。记不记得每个黄昏，太阳离开天空之后都静静地沉入海中？我认为太阳晚上是去了这里。让水底的世界被金色的光芒染透我聪明吧，姐姐？
当然聪明，弟弟，你当然聪明而且也许你说得对……但是在我读的那些书里他们不是这么说的。他们怎么说呢，姐姐，他们怎么说？你认为呢，弟弟，你认为呢？
我认为，我认为……告诉我，弟弟，你认为呢？我认为也许这并不神秘。也许太阳就像爸爸。每天晚上在工作了漫长的一天之后精疲力尽地回家。
而他的太太，就像妈妈一样，细心呵护他，不许孩子们闹他，替他盖上暗夜的星被暗自希望他的呼噜别又吵得她整夜睡不着。
每天早上，太阳掀开星被，倦眼把清晨的天空染成红色又上班去了。我认为太阳晚上是去了这里。它回家睡觉去了，一直睡到天亮。我聪明吧，姐姐？
你肯定很聪明，弟弟，肯定聪明，而且也许你说得对……但是在我读的那些书里他们不是这么说的。他们怎么说呢，姐姐，他们怎么说？过来，弟弟，我来告诉你他们是怎么说的。他们说，他们说……告诉我，姐姐，他们怎么说？
他们说，地球像个皮球，围着太阳转圈又像妈妈买给你的红陀螺那样旋转只是速度稍慢。
他们说，地球自转一圈要花一天一夜。可我问的是太阳啊，姐姐我问的是太阳。就快说到了，弟弟，耐心一点。
他们说，当我们所在的半球转向太阳我们就有了白天。而当另外一半，转向太阳而我们转向背后的时候就有了夜晚。
他们说，太阳晚上是去了这里。让地球的另一半沐浴在它的光辉下面。这有可能是真的吗，姐姐，有可能是真的吗？我不敢确定，弟弟，我不敢确定。但是在我读的所有书里，他们都是这么说的。

更多知识太阳晚上去了哪里？地球是一个球体，和太阳系的另外七个行星一起绕着太阳公转。地球绕太阳转一圈的时间是一年。在绕着太阳公转的同时，地球还绕着自己的轴线自传。每转一圈是二十四小时，也就是一天一夜。地球面朝太阳的一半是白天。与此同时，另一半（背向太阳的一面）是晚上。由于地球在缓慢地自转，原本的黑夜（背向太阳的一面）会转向太阳，成为白天；而原先向阳的半球就变成了晚上。所以，太阳在晚上其实哪儿也没去！
小实验通过这个简单的实验，可以了解到地球的自转是怎样造成了白天和黑夜。实验材料：- 一只小皮球- 一个大手电筒- 一些水笔- 一个朋友实验说明：把皮球想象成地球。用水笔在皮球上画出世界地图。把手电筒想象成太阳。请你的朋友打开手电筒。
把皮球（地球）放在手电筒的光束（阳光）下面，让中国面向太阳。慢慢地旋转橡皮球。你看见了什么？当中国面向太阳的时候，加拿大的东部就是黑夜。当中国向太阳背后旋转时，印度和欧洲会进入“白天”。接着，非洲和美国进入白天，而中国则进入夜晚。继续旋转，直到中国再次面向太阳。地球每绕轴线自转一圈，白天和黑夜就如此循环一次，中国（以及地球上其他任何地方）都度过了一天一夜。
eng: Sister, sister, I wonder...What do you wonder, little brother,What do you wonder?I wonder, I wonder,Where the sun goes at night.Where do you think, little brother,Where do you think?I think, I think...Tell me, little brother,What do you think?
I thinkThat maybe, a demon.The terrible black demonOf DarknessEats up the sun each nightFor dinner.See how the blue sky, at sunset,Is stained red with his blood?

But the sunThe glorious brave shining golden sunHe fights the Darkness demonAll night, every nightAnd by morning,He’s whole again and back to rule.That’s where I think the sun goes at night.Into the mouth of a monsterAfter a terrible fight.I’m clever, aren’t I, sister?

Oh yes you are, little brother, oh yes you areAnd maybe you are right, too...But in the books that I have readThat is not what they said. Then what did they say, sister,What did they say?What do you think, little brother,What do you think?I think, I think...Tell me, little brother, what do you think?
I thinkThat maybe, while it is nightHere on earth,It is a glorious day inThe ocean's darkest depths.And the mermaids come dancing outOf their undersea cavesTo frolic with the sharks.

We have seen it ourselvesWhen we went to Mumbai last summer.RememberHow the sun lets go of the skyEach evening at duskAnd slides soundlessly into the sea? That’s were I think the sun goes at nightTo flood the underwaterWith golden light.I’m clever, aren’t I sister?

Of course you are, little brother,Of course you areAnd maybe you are right, too...But in the books that I have readThat is not what they said.Then what did they say, sister,What did they say?What do you think, little brother,What do you think?
I think, I think...Tell me, little brother, what do you think?I thinkThat maybe there is no mystery.That maybe the sun is just like Father.He goes home tired each nightAfter a long dayAt work.
And his wife, like Mother,Fusses over him, shushes the kids,Covers him with a night-darkblanket of stars,And hopes his snoringwill not keep her awake all night.

And every morning, the sunShrugs off his star-blanket,Paints the dawn sky red with his sleepy eyesAnd gets back to work.That’s where I think the sun goes at night.Home to bed until it is light.I’m clever, aren’t I, sister?

I know you are, little brother, I know you are,And maybe you’re right, too...But in the books that I have readThat is not what they said. Then what did they say, sister,What did they say?Come here, little brother,I’ll tell you what they said.They said, they said...Tell me, sister, what did they say?
They saidThat the earth is like a ballThat the ball goes around the sunSpinning like the red topMother got you from the Saturday market,But slower.
And they saidEvery spin of the earthIs as long as a dayAnd a night.I asked about the sun, sister,I asked about the sun.I am coming to that, little brother,Be patient now.
They saidWhen our part of the earthThe half where we liveIs turned towards the sunWe have day.And when the other halfIs turned towards the sunAnd oursIs turned awayWe have night.

They saidThat’s where the sun goes at nightTo bathe the other half in glorious light.Can it be true, sister, can it be true?I can’t say, little brother, I can’t say.But in all the books that I have readThat is what they said.

FIND OUT MORE!Where does the sun go at night?The earth is a sphere that revolves around the sun, along with the seven other planets of the solar system. One revolution of the earth around the sun takes one calendar year.While it is going around the sun, the earth also spins on its own axis. Each ‘spin’ takes 24 hours, that is, a day and a night.Whichever part of the earth is facing the sun has day. At the same time, the other half of the earth (the part turned away from the sun) has night. Then the earth slowly spins around and the half that was in darkness (that is, the half that was turned away from the sun) now faces the sun. So this half has day, and the other half, which turned away from the sun has night. So, in reality, the sun does not really go anywhere at night!

Try this experiment!To understand how the earth’s rotation causes day and night, try this simple exercise.You need:A small rubber ballA big torchSome felt pensA friendWhat to do:Imagine that the rubber ball is the earth. Using the felt pens, draw the map of the world on the rubber ball. Now, imagine that the torch is the sun. Ask your friend to switch on the torch.

Place the ball (the earth) directly in the path of the torch beam (sunlight), so that India is facing the sun. Turn the ball around slowly. What do you see? When India is facing the sun, the Americas are in darkness.As India begins to turn away from the sun, Europe and Africa come into the ‘sunlight’. Then, as the ‘earth’ continues to turn, the Americas come into the light and India becomes dark.Keep turning the ball till India faces the sun again. This is what happens every time the earth turns around on its axis. During each rotation, India (and every other place on earth) has one day and one night.
Roti is a circle.
Bread pakoda is a triangle.
Barfi is a square.
Chakli is a spiral.
Vada is a ring.
Patishapta is a cylinder.Patishapta is a Bengali sweet dish made of refined flour, coconut and jaggery.
Pomfret is a hexagon,when cut from the middle.
Dosa is a cone, when folded from the end.
Halwa has no shape. It takes the shape you give it.
They all come together and become a food monster.
I chase the food monster aroundthe plate.And eat it with a chomp, a crunch, a crackle and a smack!
zho: ﻿煎饼是圆的

eng: The cloud was floating
peacock said, "you start raining. and I shall dance"
The fish said, "You start raining. I need more water."
The farmer said, "You start raining. I will sow the seeds."
Raju said, "You start raining. I will sail my boat."
The cloud started raining.
The peacock danced a lot.
The pond got filled. The fish became happy.
The farmer started sowing the seeds.
splash! splash!splash! Raju somersaulted with his friends.

The cloud moved ahead happily, leaving 

behind

the fragrance of soil.
zho: 一朵云彩悠闲地在天空中飘荡。
孔雀说，“为什么你不下雨呢？我会为你跳舞。”
鱼说，“请下雨吧，我需要更多的水。”
庄稼汉说，“请下雨吧。我要为下一次丰收耕种。”
拉朱说，“如果你下雨，我就可以让我的纸船远航。”
云朵让闪闪发光的雨滴跳起了舞蹈。
孔雀张开了她靓丽的尾巴进行舞蹈。
雨水装满了池塘，鱼儿非常开心。
庄稼汉开始了播种。
哗啦啦，拉朱和他的小伙伴们在水坑里尽情得玩耍。
云朵让愉悦填满了所有人的心房。他继续向前

这种戏是基于一种现代形式的戏剧，称为形体剧场。这种形式的美妙之处在于，它可以在任何地方即兴完成，无论有多少演员都可以方便地使用或不使用道具。你会在书的末尾找到关于如何表演这个剧本的建议。现在是剧本！
Body Theatre
旁白:（走出舞台的一个角落）：一个可怜的女人有一个儿子。她在他们镇上富裕的房子里当园丁，努力工作。他们给了她一些粮食作为回报。一个孩子模仿母亲，而其他孩子则组成小康家庭。母亲去每个小组，并为这些小组模仿园艺。创造了这个 30 秒的场景后，包括母亲在内的所有小组都呆在了他们的位置上。

旁白：但她感觉很糟糕，因为她永远买不起给她儿子买漂亮的衣服或可爱的玩具。
一个小男孩跑过合唱团，唱着歌，玩着哑剧板球。他在舞台中央摆出一个姿势，整个人都僵住了。
旁白：小伙子开朗活泼。没有玩具或漂亮的衣服并没有打扰他。辛苦了一天，妈妈去集市上卖她收到的粮食。妈妈走到男孩身边，剩下的演员都冻僵了，回到合唱团。 
旁白：她问儿子， 妈妈说，我可以从市场上给你买什么吗，小家伙？

旁白：现在这个男孩对鼓声很着迷。
于是他说，
男孩：一个鼓，妈妈，我很想有一个鼓来玩。
在接下来的叙述中，男孩继续固定在他的位置，而妈妈则在舞台上转圈。她遇到了一位走出合唱团的演员，她是向她出售谷物的商人，另一个是她向其购买面粉，并在路上捡起一块木头，然后回到男孩身边。 旁白：母亲知道她永远没有足够的钱为她儿子买鼓。她去了市场，卖掉了她的谷物，买了一些克面粉和一些盐。回到家中，她为自己不得不空手面对他而感到难过。所以当她在路上看到一块漂亮的木头时，她就把它捡起来带回家了。

男孩：Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti -tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot！
我要了一个鼓，看看我得到了什么，一块可爱的木头！我要了一个鼓，看看我得到了什么，我觉得我的运气很好！
Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot！

歌曲快结束时，一位老人从合唱团中走出来。他模仿着试图点燃他的炉子。当他咳嗽时，整个合唱团都在咳嗽，从而放大了他病情的影响。老人正试图用一些牛粪饼点燃他的炉子。火并没有着火，周围都是烟雾。烟熏得男人眼眶湿润，咳嗽不止。
小男孩跑到他面前说，
男孩：爷爷怎么了？有什么可以帮忙的吗？
 老头：啊！小家伙，我正在尝试做饭，但我无法生火。

你看，我的火点不着，我需要做饭。哦！看看我的火永远点不着！有人可以生火吗？我的眼睛红了，我的胳膊累了。我需要吃东西，我需要一些食物。哦！一块干木头！
男孩：来，爷爷，你可以用我的那块木头生火。
下面的动作模仿旁白说话。 
旁白：老人很高兴。他生了火，做了一些面包，给了男孩一块。老人走回合唱团。

男孩一边跳一边唱着他的歌： 
男孩：啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦啦！啦啦啦啦啦啦！
我的木头给了我一些食物。一块可爱的面包。我的木头不是鼓，但它给了我面包。一块可爱的面包。
啦啦啦-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- LaLa-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La! 
旁白：男孩走了，直到他遇到一位陶艺家的妻子。她怀里抱着她的孩子。婴儿在嚎叫，挥舞着她的胳膊。和以前一样，陶工的妻子从合唱团中走出来，好像怀里抱着一个婴儿。当母亲试图安抚婴儿时，合唱团轻轻地哼着摇篮曲。这首摇篮曲可以是一首地区歌曲。

男孩说，
男孩：亲爱的女士，你女儿为什么哭？
波特的妻子：我的小家伙饿了。她从早上开始就没有吃东西。我不能给她任何东西，因为房子里什么都没有。我希望我有一些面包给她。
旁白：好心的男孩把面包给了那位女士。她把面包给了她的孩子，孩子吃得津津有味，不再哭了。她对这个男孩很满意，给了他一个大锅。
上面的动作是在旁白朗读台词时模仿的。动作结束后，带着孩子的女人回到合唱团，而男孩则继续，拿着他的锅。

男孩跟着哼着他有趣的歌：
男孩：Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot！
我把面包送走了，看看我得到了什么！我把面包送走了，得到了一个可爱的锅！ 
Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee -Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot！

小男孩一路跳跃，直到在河岸看到了一个奇怪的场景。
合唱团可以一起移动他们的手，象征着流动的河流。洗衣工和他的妻子从合唱团中走出来，哑着嗓子争吵起来。他们的行为被夸大了，但他们的声音没有被听到。一个洗衣工正在和他的妻子大声吵架。
男孩停下来问，
男孩：亲爱的先生，有什么事吗？你为什么和你的妻子吵架？ 
旁白：
洗衣工说，
洗衣工：你看，孩子，是这样的，我给了她一个锅，我给了她一个锅。她做了什么？我给了她一个锅，它花了很多钱。她还去把它弄坏了！

她打破了锅，这是我最后一次，现在我感觉好痛！我把锅给了她，她打破了锅。我需要煮衣服的锅。没有锅，我的衣服会腐烂。哦，它们会依然那么脏！所以你看，在我洗衣服之前，我没有什么可以煮沸的。因为她，我的生意会受到影响。
男孩：亲爱的先生，不要和你的妻子吵架。请拿走我的这个锅。
旁白：洗衣工对这个锅很满意。小伙子的好脾气让他很满意，还给了他一件漂亮的大衣，全场齐声称赞这件大衣，哇，好漂亮的大衣！看颜色！看起来很温馨！如此柔软和温暖！
洗衣工和他的妻子回到合唱团。

男孩一边跑一边唱着他那搞笑的歌。男孩：我一边走，一边拿着锅，遇到了一个洗衣工。谁给了我这么大的外套！哦，真是太有趣了！人们在寻找东西，而我有他们需要的东西！
旁白：男孩继续走，一直欣赏他的大外套。很快，他来到一座桥前，在那里他被眼前的景象惊呆了。
对于接下来的叙述，合唱发出冷风吹过的声音。一个男人从合唱团中走出来，颤抖着。他坐下，蜷缩成一团。

一个男人在寒冷中瑟瑟发抖，他甚至没有穿衬衫。他似乎受伤了，痛苦地呻吟着。男孩很担心，跑到男人面前说，
男孩：你好像流血了，你好像受伤了！我会试着给你一些帮助。你还需要一件外套。 
旁白：男孩问男人他怎么会变成这样。
男人说，在下面几行中，动作是模仿的。一群演员出现了。他们追逐另一个演员（扮演那个男人），把他逼到角落，抢劫他。
 男人：我骑马很着急。我骑马去城里。

一群小偷，他们来了，抓住了我！他们让我失望，他们让我出去。他们拿走了我的钱包，拿走了我所有的钱。我想好好打架。但他们打了我，打得我很惨。他们让我痛苦，他们让我受伤.他们都拿走了，连我的衬衫都拿走了！
随着歌曲的结束，盗贼团又回到了合唱团。
 旁白，男孩说，
男孩：你的需要比我的大。请拿这件外套。它会帮你保暖。 
旁白：小伙子的好意让男人很感动。他连连道谢，并把骑着的大骏马递给他。

劫匪进入合唱团，整个合唱团用声音模仿骑马。鼓可以伴随节奏。合唱团在现场模仿骑马，男孩骑马过舞台。男孩很高兴，牵着马，唱着他的歌。
男孩：哦，真有趣！人们在寻找东西，而我有什么他们需要！一个人需要一件衬衫，但他只有一匹大马！我给了他我的外套，我得到了什么？当然是他的大马！
男孩和合唱团的“马”都停止了。另一组从合唱团中出现。其中包括新郎、他的亲戚和派对的鼓手。

当他和他的马一起走的时候，他遇到了一大群衣着欢快的人。他们与新郎和音乐家一起参加了一场盛大的婚礼。他们似乎准备参加婚礼游行，但他们都坐在一棵长脸的树下。
此时，新郎派对和剩下的合唱演员都唱着流行的婚礼歌曲，但声音缓慢而悲伤男孩停下来问他们是什么让他们看起来如此沮丧。
新郎的父亲说，新郎的父亲：你看，孩子，是这样的。我们都准备好参加婚礼了。

但是新郎需要一匹马。本来应该带的人还没出现，吉时已过。
旁白：新郎亲自上前对男孩说，新郎：我是新郎。等着见我的新娘，但我我被困在这里 只是希望能搭上一程！我不能站起来。我的马迟到了，时间也迟到了。我的客人都在等着吃饭。我肯定会想念我的婚礼！所以你看，我现在需要的是一匹马！我需要一匹马！一匹真快的马！合唱：他需要一匹马，他需要一匹马！他需要一匹快马！

旁白，于是男孩一如既往地乐于助人，将他的马献给了新郎。新郎很高兴，问男孩可以拿什么来换他的马。男孩在音乐家中环顾四周，很快就找到了鼓手。他说，男孩：他们说一针可以救九针。是什么拯救了今天，绝对是我这匹漂亮的马！我想要的就是你演奏的那只漂亮的小鼓！哦，让我的梦想成真！请让我的梦想成真！
鼓手带着鼓向前走，并在以下几行中将其交给男孩。

新郎请鼓手把鼓交给男孩。鼓手知道他很容易得到足够的钱给自己买一个全新的鼓。他心甘情愿地把他的鼓给了。新郎的演员和其他人回到合唱团的主体。所有人都唱着婚礼的歌，但现在是快乐和快节奏的。
旁白：男孩冲回家唱着他的歌，弹着他的新鼓。他迫不及待地想告诉妈妈她是如何帮他弄到鼓的。男孩和妈妈在舞台中央相遇。

男孩：我的那块木头有很多好处！它让我得到了面包作为食物。我的那块面包没有持续多久，但是给了我一个可爱的锅。我的锅给了我一件可爱的外套。这件外套确实帮助了一个有需要的人。我给我买了一匹漂亮的大马。有了那匹马，我帮了一个新郎和他的新娘！所以你看这确实很简单，一点点给予和索取，很多人都会开心！所以当你今天见到你的朋友时, 努力创造他们的一天！
最后一节由整个合唱团再次演唱，合唱团围绕着男孩唱歌跳舞。最后，演员们全部定格在剧中各个角色的位置上。
-----------幕布-----------
舞台设置：下面的方框建议了该剧的可能设计。把这些盒子中的每一个想象成一张特定场景的照片。你可以把戏的道具、服装和乐器放在靠后墙的长凳上，你可以在合唱后换景时使用它们。

对演员表的建议 该剧可以由 6 到 30 名儿童的演员表演出。有了更多的孩子，除了其他角色之外，叙述者和男孩的角色可以由许多孩子承担。对于四到六个孩子的演员阵容，男孩和母亲的角色可以固定，而其他孩子可以在剧中扮演各种其他角色。剧中给出的舞台方向仅作为建议或可能性。请根据您在可用空间（舞台、教室、大厅等）、道具、布景和服装方面的需求调整剧本。可能的服装：常规舒适服装，如 T 恤和裤子或萨尔瓦和卡米兹，或校服. 可能的道具：鼓、棍子、锅、外套，视情况而定。整部戏也可以不用任何道具，都可以模仿。

简单的乐器：可以使用简单的乐器或合唱团本身可以发出适当的声音。建议约20至30名儿童的舞台方向。建议约20至30名儿童的舞台方向所有儿童都面朝外观众排成三等分。几个叙述者以一种非常戏剧化的方式出现。例如，他们两个可能正在玩接球游戏，突然他们看着观众，欢迎他们，并合唱一些关于该剧的内容：“男孩和鼓的故事，一个关于分享，一个关于价值观的故事，一个关于人而不是事物的故事。”全班人转向观众，大合唱标题。小组保持在三行，现在面向观众。
从现在开始，角色们将走出合唱团走到前面的舞台空间，当他们完成他们在剧中的角色时，然后回到合唱团。母亲可以穿一件彩色的杜帕塔，当她给男孩的时候。她把那块木头给了他。所有其他角色也可以穿着外套，他们在适当的时候与男孩交换。这个动作可以象征分享和给予，尽管这对戏剧的动作来说不是必不可少的。
eng: This play is based on a modern form of theatre called Body Theatre. The beauty of this form is that it can be done impromptu, at any place, with as many or as few actors as convenient, with or without props. You will find suggestions on how to perform this play at the end of the book. And now the play! The Boy and the DrumNarrator/s (stepping out to one corner of the stage): A poor woman had a son. She worked hard as a gardener in wealthy houses in their town. They gave her some grain in return. One child mimes the mother, while other children form groups of the well-to-do families. The mother goes to each group and mimes gardening for these groups. Having created this 30-second scene, all the groups, including the mother freeze in their positions.

Narrator: But she felt bad because she could never afford to buy nice clothes or lovely toys for her son. A young boy comes running through the chorus, singing a song and playing mime cricket. He freezes with a pose at the centre of the stage. Narrator: The little lad was bright and cheerful. Not having any toys or nice clothes did not bother him. After a hard day's work, the mother was going to the market to sell the grain she had received. The mother steps towards the boy and the rest of the frozen actors go back to the chorus. Narrator: She asked her son:Mother: What can I get for you from the market, little one?

Narrator: Now the boy was fascinated with the sound of a drum. So he said:Boy: A drum, mother, I would love to have a drum to play with.During the following narration, the boy continues to be frozen in his position while the mother circles the stage. She meets one actor who steps out of the chorus as the merchant to whom she sells the grain, another from whom she buys flour, and on the way she picks up a piece of wood, and goes back to the boy. Narrator: The mother knew she would never have enough money to buy a drum for her son. She went to the market, sold her grain and bought some gram flour and some salt. While returning home, she felt sad that she would have to face him empty-handed. So when she saw a nice piece of wood on the road, she picked it up and brought it home.

The son did not know what to do with the piece of wood. Yet he happily carried it with him when he went out to play. A happy song sprang to his lips and he went along singing it: Boy moves around the stage while chorus watches him.Boy: Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot! I asked for a drum and look what I got,A lovely piece of wood! I asked for a drum and look what I got, I think my luck is good! Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot!

Towards the end of the song, an old man emerges from the chorus. He mimes trying to light his stove. As he coughs, the entire chorus coughs, thus amplifying the effect of his condition.Narrator: And as he went skipping along on his way, he came across an old man. The old man was trying to light his stove using some cow-dung cakes. The fire was not catching and there was smoke all around. The smoke made the man's eyes water and he was coughing. The little boy ran up to him and said: Boy: What is the matter Grandpa? Can I help you in any way? Old Man: Ah! Little one, I am trying to cook some food, but I am unable to start a fire.

For you see,My fire will just not startI need to cook. Oh! Take a lookMy fire will never start! Can somebody start this fire? My eyes are red, my arms are tired. I need to eat, I need some food. Oh! For a dry piece of wood!Boy: Here, Grandpa, you can use my piece of wood to start your fire. The following actions are mimed as the narrator speaks. Narrator: The old man was very pleased. He lit his fire, made some bread and gave a piece to the boy. The old man steps back into the chorus.

The boy skipped along singing his song: Boy: La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- LaLa-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La! My piece of wood got me some food. A lovely piece of bread.My piece of wood is not a drum, but itGot me bread. A lovely piece of bread.La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- LaLa-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La-la-la-la- La!Narrator: The boy walked on till he came upon a potter’s wife. She had her baby in her arms. The baby was wailing and flailing her arms. As before, the potter’s wife emerges from the chorus, as if with a baby in her arms. While the mother tries to pacify the baby, the chorus hums a lullaby softly. This lullaby can be a regional song.

The boy said:Boy: Dear lady, why is your daughter crying? Potter’s Wife: My little one is hungry. She has not had anything to eat since morning. I cannot give her anything as there is nothing in the house. I wish I had some bread to give her.Narrator: The kind hearted boy gave the lady his bread. She gave the bread to her child who ate it eagerly and stopped crying. She was so pleased with the boy that she gave him a large pot. The above actions are mimed as the narrator voices the lines. After the action, the woman with the baby goes back to the chorus while the boy continues, carrying his pot.

The boy went along humming his funny song: Boy: Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot! I gave my bread away and Look what I got! I gave my bread away and Got a lovely pot! Tum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee TotTum-ti-tee Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee-Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee- Tum-ti-tee Tot!

Narrator: The little boy skipped along until he came upon a strange scene at the river bank.The chorus can move their hands all together, symbolizing the flowing river. The washerman and his wife emerge from the chorus, arguing in mime. Their actions are exaggerated but their voices are not heard.  A washerman was quarreling loudly with his wife.  The boy stopped and asked:Boy: Dear Sir, what is the matter? Why are you quarreling with your wife?Narrator: The washerman said: Washerman: You see, son, it was like this, I gave her a pot, I gave her a pot. And what did she do?I gave her a pot, it cost a lot.She went and broke it too!

She broke the pot, the last of my lot, And now I feel so sore! I gave her the pot, the pot she broke. The pot I need to boil my clothes. Without the pot, my clothes will rot. Oh, they will remain soiled! So you see, I have nothing to boil my clothes in before I wash them. And because of her, my trade will suffer.Boy: Dear Sir, don’t quarrel with your wife. Please take this pot of mine and use it. Narrator: The washerman was very happy with the pot. He was so pleased with the boy’s good nature that he gave him a nice coat in return.The entire chorus praises the coat, ‘Wah, what a nice coat! Look at the colour! Seems very cozy! So soft and warm!’ The washerman and his wife make their way back to the chorus.

The boy ran along singing his funny song.	Boy: As I walked along,With my pot in hand, I met a washerman. Who gave me this coat so grand! Oh so funny indeed! People looking for things, And I have what they need! Narrator: The boy walked on, all the while admiring his grand coat. He soon came to a bridge, and there he was alarmed by what he saw. For the following narration, the chorus makes the sound of a cold wind blowing. A man emerges from the chorus, shivering. He sits down, curled into a ball.

A man was shivering in the cold and he 
was not even wearing a shirt. He seemed to be hurt and was moaning in 
pain. The boy was very concerned and ran up to the man and said: Boy: You seem to be bleeding, You seem to be hurt! I'll try and get you some help. You also need a coat. Narrator: The boy asked the man how he came to be in such a sorry state. The man said:During the following lines, the action is mimed. A group of actors emerges. They chase another actor (playing the man), corner him, and rob him.Man: I was riding my horse in a hurry. 
I was riding my horse to the city.

A crowd of thieves, they came and GOT me! They got me down, they got me out. They took my purse, got all my money. I tried to put up a good fight. But they beat me up, they beat me bad. They left me in pain, they left me hurt. They took it all, even my shirt! As the song ends the acting-robber group goes back to the chorus. Narrator: The boy said:Boy: Your need is greater than mine. Please take this coat. It will help you keep warm. Narrator: The man was touched by the little lad's kindness. He thanked the boy profusely and presented him with the big fine horse he was riding.

The robbed man goes into the chorus, while the entire chorus mimes the riding of the horse with the sounds. A drum can accompany the rhythm. The chorus mimes the riding on the spot, while the boy rides his horse across the stage.The boy was very happy and led the horse along, singing his song.Boy: Oh so funny indeed! People looking for things, And I have what they need! A man needs a shirt, But all he has is a big fine horse! I gave him my coat, what did I get? His big fine horse, of course! The "horsing" of both the boy and chorus stops. Another group emerges from the chorus. These include the bridegroom, his relatives, and the drummers of the party.

Narrator: As he was walking along with his horse, he came upon a large party of gaily dressed people. They were part of a big wedding party with the bridegroom, and musicians. They seemed ready to go in a wedding procession, but all of them were sitting under a tree with long faces. At this point, both the groom’s party and the remaining chorus actors sing a popular wedding song, but in a slow and sad-sounding manner. The boy stopped and asked them what made them look so depressed. The groom’s father said: Groom’s father: You see, son, it’s like this. We are all set to go in the wedding procession.

But we need a horse for the groom. The man who was supposed to bring it hasn’t turned up, the auspicious hour is almost gone.Narrator: And the groom himself stepped up to the boy and said:Groom: I am the groom. Waiting to see my bride, But I’m stuck in here Just hoping for a ride! I just can’t go there on my feet. My horse is late and so is the hour. My guests are all waiting to eat. I’ll miss my wedding for sure! So you see, what I need right now is a horse! I need a horse! A really quick horse! Chorus: He needs a horse, he needs a horse! He needs a really fast horse!

Narrator: And so the boy, being helpful as ever, offered his horse to the groom. The groom was very happy and he asked the boy what he could give him in exchange for his horse. The boy looked around among the musicians and quickly spotted the drummer. He said: Boy: A stitch in time they say saves nine. And what indeed did save the day, Was this splendid horse of mine! All I want from you is That fine little drum that you play! Oh, make my dreams come true! Please make my dream come true! The drummer steps forward with his drum, and hands it over to the boy during the following lines.

Narrator: The groom requested the drummer to hand over the drum to the boy. The drummer knew he would easily get enough money to buy himself a brand new drum. He willingly gave his drum away. The groom's actors and everyone else return to the main body of the chorus. All sing the wedding song, but now it is happy and up-tempo. Narrator: The boy rushed home singing his song and playing his new drum. He could not wait to tell his mother how she had helped him to get his drum. The boy and the mother meet at the centre of the stage.

Boy: My piece of wood did a lot of good! It got me bread as food.My piece of bread lasted not, But gave me a lovely pot. My pot got me a lovely coat.The coat did help a needy man. I got me a big fine horse to ride.With that horse, I got a groom his bride! So you see it is simple indeed A little bit of give and take, Will a lot of people happy make! So when you meet your friends today, Try and make their day! The last verse is sung again by the entire chorus, which sings and dances around the boy. In	the end, the actors all freeze in the positions of the various characters in the play.               ----------- Curtain -----------

Stage setting:The boxes below suggest a possible design for the play. Think of each of these boxes as a photograph of a particular scene. You could have the props, costumes, and musical instruments for the play on a bench placed against the back wall, and you could make use of them during the changing of the scenes behind the chorus.

Suggestions for the cast The play can be performed by a cast of six to thirty children. With more children, the role of the narrator and the boy can be assumed by many children, besides the other characters. For a cast of four to six children, the roles of the boy and the mother can be fixed, while the other children can take on the various other roles in the play. The stage directions given in the play are only meant as a suggestion or possibility. Please adapt the play to suit your needs in terms of availability of space (stage, classroom, hall etc.), props, sets and costumes. Possible costumes: Regular comfortable clothes like t-shirts and pants or salwar and kameez, OR school uniform. Possible props: Drum, stick, pot, dupattas, depending on availability. The entire play can also be done without any props, all of which can be mimed.

Simple musical instruments:Simple musical instruments can be used or the chorus itself can make the appropriate sounds.Suggested stage directions for a group of about 20 to 30 children.Suggested stage directions for a group of about 20 to 30 childrenAll the children are facing away from the audience in three equal lines. A couple of narrators come in a very dramatic fashion. For example, the two of them can be playing a game of catch and suddenly they look at the audience, welcome them, and speak a little about the play together as a chorus: "The story of the boy and the drum, a story about sharing, a story about values, a story about people and not things." The whole group turns to the audience and shouts out the title as one big chorus. The group stays in the three lines, now facing the audience.

From now on, the characters will step out of the chorus to the stage space in front and then back into the chorus when they are done with their part in the play. The mother can wear a colored dupatta, which she gives to the boy when she gives him the piece of wood. All the other characters can also wear dupattas, which they exchange with the boy at the appropriate time. This action can symbolize sharing and giving, although this is not essential to the play's action.
Nothing goes to waste in a forest. Nothing at all!Everything gets cleaned up. Absolutely everything!
When leopards don’t finish their food,Who eats the rest?The vultures and the hyenas!
And the hungry wild boar.GRUNT! GRUNT!
When the vultures and the hyenas waste their food,Who gobbles it up?The flies and the maggots!
And the hungry wild boar.GRUNT! GRUNT!
When elephants poop in the forest,Who snacks on that?The dung beetles!
And the hungry wild boar.GRUNT! GRUNT!
When branches, leaves, and rain fall on the ground,Who feasts on it all?The termites and the fungi!
And the hungry wild boar.GRUNT! GRUNT!
When the air gets dirty with smoke,Who sucks it all in?The trees!
Ummm, but not the hungry wild boar.GRUNT! GRUNT!
zho: 在森林里，什么东西都不会浪费。一点儿也不会。所有东西都能清理得一干二净。绝对是所有的！
花豹没有吃完的食物，谁吃呢？秃鹫和鬣狗！
还有饥饿的野猪。呼噜！呼噜！
秃鹫和鬣狗不吃的食物，谁会狼吞虎咽地吃掉呢？苍蝇和蛆！
还有饥饿的野猪。呼噜！呼噜！
大象在森林里拉的粪便，谁当点心吃呢？屎壳郎！
还有饥饿的野猪。呼噜！呼噜！
落在地上的树枝、树叶还有雨水，谁会尽情享用呢？白蚁和霉菌！
还有饥饿的野猪。呼噜！呼噜！
空气里弥漫着的烟雾，谁会全部吸进去呢？树木！
恩......，饥饿的野猪不会。呼噜！呼噜！

eng: Munia knew that the giant, one-feathered elephant bird had not swallowed the horse. Yes, he was big enough to swallow a horse, but that didn't mean he had! The village of Adhania had only one horse-cart pulled by the two horses Vayu and Drut. And Vayu had gone missing near the lake in the jungle where the bird lived. The villagers had known about the elephant bird for generations.

He was the last of his race, which was considered extinct for hundreds of years. The world did not know that the living 
relic of that race, who had lost all his feathers but one, still roamed 
the jungles of Adhania. The bird and the villagers kept a safe distance from each other. But not Munia. Although she walked with a limp, she was brave of heart. She often slipped into the jungle to watch the elephant bird.

The elephant bird came near the lake in the daytime to bask in the sun or play in the lake alone splashing water. Sometimes he sat half-submerged in water. At other times there was no trace of him. Perhaps he just rested in some corner of the dense jungle. He stood as tall as a tree. He had a long strong neck, huge legs with claws and a heavy spear-like head. His long talons and nails looked scary.

But Munia soon realised he was a shy herbivorous bird. He just munched on leaves by the lakeside. Munia felt she had something in common with him. The elephant bird could not fly and Munia could not run! Other village children mocked her limp and did not include her in their games. That was why she liked staying alone.

Every morning Munia helped fetch three pitchers of water from the village well, and collected wood so that Amma could light the stove. And then she would be out for a long time. Amma believed she went out to play with the kids. Little did she know that Munia went into the jungle to the lake where the elephant bird lived.

One day, gathering courage, Munia stepped in the open near the lake. Without turning his head the elephant bird rolled his eyes towards Munia and then closed them, uninterested by her advance.Getting no more attention than the flies buzzing over his head, Munia stomped her feet. Suddenly the elephant bird lifted one of his claws. Munia cried and fell headlong into the shallow waters of the lake. She came out drenched to see him shaking all over. He was laughing!

“That’s funny, huh?” she asked angrily and turned to leave. Before Munia had walked away from the clearing, something hit her feet. It was a fruit that the elephant bird had thrown at her. The elephant bird wanted to play! Hesitantly, Munia threw it at him. He trotted sideways and caught the fruit in his beak. Thus, Munia’s friendship with the elephant bird had begun. And just when she had finally found a friend, Vayu had gone missing! And everyone’s suspicion had turned towards the elephant bird.

After searching for Vayu high and low, the villagers gathered under the old banyan tree.Everyone agreed that there could be no thief in Adhania. They all trusted one another. The milkman swore that he had seen Vayu gallop away towards the lake. “There is no sign of Vayu anywhere. It must be something in the jungle that got him,” a villager addressed the headman. “Who else can it be but the giant one-feathered elephant bird? He must be destroyed!” said the milkman. “For years he has been lying silent, hatching his evil plans!”

The crowd agreed. Munia watched the proceedings quietly. She wanted to speak, but was scared of being punished for speaking up. Even if she spoke, who would believe her? “Yes, all these years of aimless living has made the giant dangerous,” said Munia’s father. “Today it is a horse, tomorrow it may be our children…”The headman spoke over the villagers’ angry shouts, “Brothers, even though we are facing a giant, we have the strength of numbers. So let us go out and finish him!”

A cheer of approval went up. “The elephant bird did not eat the horse,” Munia said softly but firmly, limping forward. “I was with him when Vayu went missing!” A heavy silence fell on the gathering. “What does this mean?” roared the headman. “That the elephant bird is my friend, and he has not done this!” “This girl has lost her mind!” shouted someone from the back.
