eng: "Dara, it's almost time to go to bed! Where have you been?" Mom asked angrily.﻿
Dara replied, "You know, there is a tall tree outside our school. I climbed this tree. It's too high and it's reaching into the sky."
"I looked down and saw white clouds. I looked up, but I heard the leaves laughing
"I don't think the leaves can laugh! Then I found out that the squirrel hiding under the leaves was giggling."
"The big squirrel asks me to eat a lot of nuts. The little squirrel is playing hide and seek in my hair!"
"We played for a long, long time, until I remembered that it was time to go home. But I don't know how to climb down the tree!"
"The squirrel started calling for help. You should hear these sounds! Haw--chiw--chiw--"
"Fortunately, a purple plane flew across the sky. Can you believe that the pilot heard the squirrels cry?"
"The plane descended from the sky. The pilot picked me up and drove me home."
"Mom, that's why I came back so late.""Dara! Don't make up stories and make excuses," Mom said
"Haw--"Haw--"Haw—"
zho: “达拉，都快到睡觉的时间了！你上哪里去了？”妈妈生气地问道。
达拉回答：“你知道的，在我们学校外面有一棵很高的树。我爬上了这棵树。它太高了，直插云霄。”
“我往下看，只见白云绵绵。我抬头望，却听见树叶在欢笑。”
“我想，树叶是不会笑的！然后，我发现，原来是藏在树叶底下的松鼠在咯咯笑呀。”
“大松鼠请我吃许多的坚果。小松鼠则在我的头发里玩起捉迷藏来！”
“我们玩了很久、很久，直到我想起来该回家了。但是，我不知道怎么从树上爬下去呀！”
“松鼠开始呼救。你应该听到这些声音！唧唧——唧唧——唧唧——”
“幸运的是，一架紫色的飞机飞过天际。你能相信吗，飞行员竟然听到了松鼠们的呼喊？”
“飞机从天上骤降下来，飞行员把我接上了机，并送我回家。”
“妈妈，这就是为什么我这么晚才回来的原因啊。”“达拉！别编故事找借口了，”妈妈说。
“呼～～～～～！ 呼～～～～～！”安娜·玛妮（Anna Mani）吹灭了她生日蛋糕上的所有八支蜡烛。 “生日快乐，安娜！” 她的兄弟姐妹喊道。安娜出生于一个大家庭，住在一个山上的大房子。 但是在她的生日，她只有一个小愿望。
安娜撕开了她的生日礼物，窥视着。 里面有东西在闪闪发光。 “钻石耳环？ 哎呀！”她不想要钻石耳环。 它们既昂贵又无用！你知道安娜真的想要什么吗？书籍，书籍和更多的书籍！
“我们家里有书！”她哥哥说。 但是安娜已经读过了。她的祖父指出：“图书馆里还有更多书籍。” 但是安娜也读过那些书了！她气呼呼地迈步进了房间。 “哼！”
那天晚些时候，安娜的房间门被敲了一下。 但是外面没有人！取而代之的是，在她房间门口放了一个大盒子。“最好不要是首饰！”她大声说。 不是。 这是一套全新的百科全书集！“这么多书。 万岁！”安娜在房子里跑来跑去，拥抱所有人。
多年之后，读过许多书之后，安娜在一位著名科学家的实验室找到了一份工作。“我应该在这里做什么？”安娜问。科学家指着一个盒子。 你认为她在里面发现了什么？
“钻石？ 哎呀！”安娜说。但是这一次，钻石不是拿来戴的。 它们是为了实验。这位科学家希望安娜找出钻石导致发光的原因。 于是她读了有关钻石的书。书籍，书籍和更多的书籍！
果然成为科学家是最棒的！ 安娜可以学任何她想要的东西。 她确实喜欢闪闪发光的东西。 还有什么比钻石更耀眼的呢？ 太阳！于是安娜读了有关太阳，阳光和天气的书。书籍，书籍和更多的书籍！
安娜做了数百次实验。她制造了许多装置来测量一个地方的天气。
孟买有多晴朗？ 安娜制造了一个装置来测量这一点。马德拉斯（Madras）的风有多大？ 安娜为此也制造了一个装置。
她最喜欢的装置花了好几个月才建成。这是一个叫做臭氧探空仪的特殊气球。 它的尾端有一台固定的小机器。机器测量了在空气中发现的一种叫做臭氧的气体。臭氧探空仪飞得很高。看，那就是安娜的臭氧探空仪！
猜猜安娜·玛尼一生中总共建造了多少个装置？ 将近一百个天气装置！她甚至拥有自己的工厂来制造这些装置。 她似乎可以建造任何东西！
安娜·玛妮（Anna Mani）成为印度最聪明的天气科学家之一。即使她长大了并且越来越知名，她最好的朋友仍然保持不变。书籍，书籍和更多的书籍！
安娜的生活和时代：时间表1918年8月23日-安娜·玛妮（Anna Mani）出生在喀拉拉邦的佩尔梅杜（Peermedu）。1940年-她获得了在班加罗尔CV拉曼实验室工作的奖学金。1945年-她前往英国学习气象学。1948年-她回到印度并加入了浦那的印度气象局。
1962年-她开始进行臭氧探空仪项目。1976年-她退休后担任印度气象局副局长。在980年代（确切年份未知）-她创办了自己的公司来生产自己的装置。2001年8月16日-安娜·玛妮（Anna Mani）在喀拉拉邦去世。

关于天气的精彩用语气象学家（发音：'meet-your-all-o-jist'）：气象学家是研究某个地区的天气和气候的科学家。 安娜·玛尼（Anna Mani）是有史以来最厉害的气象学家之一。臭氧探空仪（发音：'oh-zone-sond'）：臭氧探空仪是高高地飞向天空的气球。 气球上有固定装置用来测量空气中的臭氧含量。 臭氧很重要，因为它可以阻挡来自阳光的有害光线。 空中的臭氧太少意味着我们有麻烦了！如果你可以成为一名科学家，你想学习什么？
备注这个故事是根据安娜·玛妮（Anna Mani）的生平创作的非小说类作品。
eng: “Foooo! Foooo!” Anna Mani blew out all eight candles on her birthday cake."Happy birthday, Anna!" shouted her brothers and sisters.Anna had a big family and a big house on a hill.But on her birthday, she had only one small wish.

Anna tore open her birthday gift and peered in. There was something sparkling inside.“Diamond earrings? Aiyye!”She did not want diamond earrings. They were expensive and useless!Do you know what Anna really wished for?Books, books and more books!

“We have books at home!” said her brother. But Anna had already read those.“There are more in the library,” pointed out her grandfather. But Anna had read those too!She marched into her room. “Hmmph!”

Later that day, there was a knock on Anna’s door. But there was nobody outside! Instead, there lay a big box at her doorstep. “This better not be more jewellery!” she said loudly. It wasn’t. It was a brand new Encyclopaedia set!“So many books. Hurray!” Anna ran around her house, hugging everyone.

Many years, and many, many, many books later, Anna found a job in the laboratory of a famous scientist.“What should I do here?” asked Anna. The scientist pointed to a box.What do you think she found inside?

“Diamonds? Aiyyyye!” said Anna.But this time, the diamonds were not to be worn. They were for experiments.The scientist wanted Anna to find out what makes diamonds shine. So she read books about diamonds. Books, books and more books!

Being a scientist was the best! Anna could study anything she wanted.She did like things that shine. And what shines brighter than diamonds?The sun!So Anna read books about the sun, sunlight and weather.Books, books and more books!
Anna did hundreds of experiments.She built many gadgets to measure the weather of a place.
How sunny is it in Bombay?Anna built a gadget to measure that.How windy is it in Madras?Anna built a gadget for that too.

Her favourite gadget took many months to build.It was a special balloon called ozonesonde. It had a small machine fixed to it. The machine measured a gas found in the air called ozone.Ozonesondes fly really high.Look, there goes Anna’s ozonesonde!
Guess how many gadgets Anna Mani built in all?Nearly one hundred weather gadgets!She even had her own factory to make these gadgets.It was as if she could build anything!
Anna Mani became one of the wisest weather scientists in India.Even as she grew older and more well-known, her best friends remained the same.Books, books and more books!

Life & Times of Anna: A Timeline 23 August, 1918 - Anna Mani is born in Peermedu in Kerala.1940 - She gets a scholarship to work at CV Raman’s laboratory in Bangalore.1945 - She leaves for England to study meteorology.
1948 - She returns and joins the Indian Meteorological Department in Pune.

1962 - She starts work on the ozonesonde project.1976 - She retires as Deputy Director General of the Indian Meteorological department.
In the 1980s (exact year unknown) - She starts her own company to manufacture her gadgets.16 August, 2001 - Anna Mani passes away in Kerala.

Wonderful Weather Words Meteorologist (say it like this: ‘meet-your-all-o-jist’): A meteorologist is a scientist who studies the weather and climate of a region. Anna Mani was one of the best meteorologists there ever was. Ozonesonde (say it like this: ‘oh-zone-sond’): Ozonesondes are balloons that fly high up into the sky. The balloons have gadgets fixed to them that measure the amount of ozone present in the air. Ozone is important because it blocks out harmful light coming from the sun. Too little ozone high up in the sky means we are in trouble! If you could be a scientist, what would you want to study?
A Note on the BookThis story is a work of creative non-fiction based on the life of Anna Mani.

Naresh was very fond of animals. Everyday, on his way back from school, he spoke with the different animals on the way and waved to them.His birthday was coming soon, and he wanted to invite the animals for a feast at his home. He saw the frog in the pond. "Dear frog, please come to my home on my birthday," he said.

Naresh said, "Hi Deer. Please come home for my birthday on this Thursday."The deer asked, "How old are you turning? Naresh said, "I'm turning 10 years old on my birthday." "I will surely come," said the deer.
Naresh said, "Hi monkey. You are always eating only bananas. Come home for my birthday. I will give you other fruits like apple." The monkey said, "Sure. I will come."
"Hi sheep. Come home for my birthday on Thursday," said Naresh. The sheep said, "Sure."
"Hi peacock. I want you to spread your feathers and dance on my birthday. Please come home," said Naresh.The peacock said, "Sure. I will."
"Come home for my birthday, Cow."The cow said, "Moo, Moo."
"Dear Buffalo. Come home for my birthday," said Naresh.The buffalo shaked its head in acceptance.
"Hi elephant. I want to ride on you for my birthday. Come home and then take me for a ride, " said Naresh. The elephant raised its trunk and accepted.
Naresh's mom Vaidehi asked, "Who is it?"
Naresh said, "My friends have come home for my birthday feast."
Vaidehi said, "Welcome. Come inside and please be seated. The feast will begin soon."
Friends of Naresh happily went back after eating the delicious food each one of them liked. Naresh waved and said, "Thanks a lot for coming. See you all soon again. Bye for now."
zho: 再見了，青蛙，明天見！
再見了，小鹿，明天見！
再見了，猴子，明天見！
再見了,綿羊，明天見！
再見了，孔雀，明天見！
再見了，牛，明天見！
再見了，水牛，明天見！
再見了，大象，明天見！
誰來了？
我的朋友們！
請他們進來一起吃早餐
我必須去學校了，再會了

eng: ACT-1
Look at me, animals! I am a human being! I know everything!
Look, these are my eyes. I can see everything with them.
So what? We have eyes too. And we can see in the dark!
Fine, but look at my nose. I breathe through my nose.
So what? We also have noses and ours are prettier than yours!
And yes, my teeth. I use my teeth to chew and bite.
Teeth? Ha! Ha! Have you seen our teeth? You can chew. But WE CAN BITE! Hiee..Hiee…Hiee…
Yes, but listen! I can hear a lot with my ears!
Little one! We can hear sounds which you cannot imagine at all!
And I can walk, run and even dance with my feet.
Oh! We have four feet! We can jump, we can dance and we can parade too!
I can plait my hair.
Uh! Our hair is pretty too. We could plait it if we wanted to. Maybe!
Look! I can work with my hands!
Hands! Keep your hands to yourself!
ACT-2
Aha! I told you! I am the best! I know it all!
Really?Have you seen our sharp claws?
Yes! But your nails will pick up dirt!
Now see, these are our lovely tails.
Tails! We gave them up long ago!How else could we wear our shorts?
And we can roar!
Roar? Have you heard my mother?
So then! You are only animals - I know that!
Humans are animals too. We know that!
You may be right. Look at my brother!Mother says he is wild. He is definitely an animal.
Yes! And so are you! Believe us! We are all animals.We all belong here. Just like you.
zho: 动物们，看着我！我是个人类！我什么都知道！
瞧，这是我的眼睛。我可以用眼睛来看东西。
那又怎样？我们也有眼睛。而且我们在黑暗里都能看清楚！
好吧，那你们看我的鼻子。我用鼻子来呼吸。
那又怎么样？我们也有鼻子，而且我们的鼻子更漂亮！
好吧，这是我的牙齿，可以用来咀嚼和咬东西。
牙？哈哈哈，你看到我们的牙了吗？你可以咀嚼，但是我们这才叫咬～ 嘿嘿嘿...
好吧。听！我能用耳朵听到很多声音！
小东西！我们能听到你听不到的声音！你都想象不出来！
我能用我的脚走、跑，甚至跳舞！
哦，我们有四条腿！我们会跳，我们会跳舞我们还可以列队游行！
我会编辫子！
呃！我们的毛发也很漂亮！如果我们愿意的话，我们也可以编辫子，呃，也许！
瞧！我可以用手来工作！
手！把你的手收起来吧！
啊哈！我告诉你，我是最棒的！我什么都知道！
真的吗？你看见我的尖爪子了吗？
是的！但是你的指甲里面全是泥！
你瞧，这是我们可爱的尾巴。
尾巴！我们早就不要了！否则我们怎么穿裤子啊？
我们会吼叫！
吼叫？你听到过我妈的吼叫吗？
那又如何？你们只是动物而已 - 我就知道！
人类也是动物。我们知道的！
你也许是对的，瞧瞧我弟弟！我妈妈说他特别野，他绝对就是个动物。
是的，你不也是吗？相信我们，我们都是动物。我们都属于这里，就和你一样。
看過來. 你願意跟我們交朋友嗎？
我有一雙強壯的腿所以我能夠跑得非常快
我用我強壯的雙臂盪鞦韆
我很喜歡畫畫, 用我的雙手
我能畫一張你嗎？我可以透過我的眼睛看到你
我的耳朵能聽到鳥兒唱歌, 好好聽
我的鼻子聞到好香的味道, 應該是媽媽在煮飯
我的牙齒也很堅固, 可以咬甘蔗
我的舌頭告訴我這個超甜的
我很會唱歌, 你想聽我唱嗎？
媽媽說我有一副好嗓子, 是從喉嚨出來的嗎？
eng: Look at us. Do you want to be our friend?
My legs are very strong. I can run really fast with them.
And my arms... such a nice swing!
I like to draw. I use my hands for drawing.
Should I draw your picture? I can see you with my eyes.
The bird sings a sweet song. I can hear it with my ears.
I think Ma is making halwa. I can smell it with my nose.
Oh! This sugarcane is so tough! But my teeth are strong too!
It is very sweet. My tongue just told me.
I can sing. Should I sing you a song?
Ma says I have a good voice. Does it come from my throat?

zho: 當我早上醒來時，陽光又燦爛了。我環顧四周，想知道我在哪裡。然後我想起來了。我是一隻小海龜——一隻橄欖色的海龜——在一個藍色的大世界中間，我聽到有人稱它為海洋。四面八方都是藍綠色的水，陽光在和雲玩遊戲。我把腳蹼塞在身下，漂浮了一會兒，讓水流帶著我。 我不知道我在哪裡。但這並不重要，當陽光明媚，你的胃已經飽了。 太陽溫暖了我，讓我充滿了新的能量。

就在我開始想我會喜歡在這裡度過餘生的時候，一群魚從我身邊走過。追逐他們是一條非常大的魚。我可以說他也是一條非常餓的魚。他一看到我，眼睛就亮了。 “嗯嗯，”他似乎在想，“小龜湯！” 片刻之後，我以最快的速度游泳，那些大牙齒咬著我的小後鰭。 就在我開始疲倦的時候，我看到了一個海藻筏。海藻筏就是這樣，一團漂浮的海藻和浮木，在海流中隨波逐流。筏子上和筏子裡都是漂流者，所有海洋中的小動物，不那麼小的生物，它們漂浮在海洋周圍，等待著什麼事情發生。謝天謝地，我溜進了木筏。我不會離開這個避風港很多很多年。 在木筏上就像在世界巡遊。我非常喜歡它，但隨著我的成長，我決定是時候探索木筏之外的廣闊世界了。

我聽說過一個叫做珊瑚礁的地方的美妙的事情

許多其他烏龜生活。人人都說珊瑚礁是仙境

的海洋。他們說它充滿了美麗，

顏色鮮豔的生物，都像小丑魚一樣無害

還有像蝎子魚這樣有毒的。 我想知道我怎麼會找到它。
突然，天變得很黑。一個巨大的陰影籠罩著我。我嚇壞了，抬起頭，卻看到了我見過的最大的烏龜。他的背部柔軟而堅韌。我盯著看。烏龜背軟？我認識的所有人都有很堅強的後背。 那隻大烏龜抓住了我的目光。 “吃驚？”他愉快地咕噥著。 “你不應該。我是棱皮龜。”
“好名字，先生，”我咕噥道。 “你要去哪裡，先生？”我繼續說。 “去珊瑚礁和其他海龜一起生活？” “啊，”棱皮龜嘆了口氣。 “我希望我能擁有那種奢侈。但是不，我正忙著尋找水母。它們都是我吃的。” “你在哪裡找到他們的？”我問。
“在很深很深的海裡，”棱皮龜說。 “有時我必須下潛超過 1000 英尺才能到達它們。有時我會一路去加拿大，那裡的水很冷。沒有其他爬行動物可以在如此寒冷的水域中生存。” “如果不是太粗魯的話，先生，”我平靜地說，“我能問一下你的體重嗎？” “將近 600 公斤，小傢伙，”棱皮龜回答說，看起來很有趣。 “我為這一切感到自豪，包括脂肪。因為脂肪幫助我度過了漫長的遷徙。嗯，我得走了……”
“當然，先生，”我說。 “但在你走之前，你能告訴我在哪裡可以找到珊瑚礁嗎？”“那邊，”棱皮龜說，一邊遊走一邊用腳蹼指著。 “謝謝您，先生，祝您狩獵愉快！”當我向礁石游去時，我喊道。
我在礁石上遇到了老綠海龜。我的朋友玳瑁嘴彎得像鷹嘴，他告訴我老格林快 50 歲了。 “我的！那是舊的！”我說。 “她怎麼看起來這麼年輕？” “嗯，”玳瑁說，“綠海龜只吃海草和藻類，所以她花了將近 30 年才長大成人。到我們十歲的時候，你和我都會長大成人。”
“你知道嗎，”他繼續說，“當她想築巢時，她會遷移到海洋中央的島嶼上？清澈的藍色潟湖，白色的沙灘，它們很美……” “你到過那裡嗎？”我問。 “哦，是的，有時你必須爬過珊瑚才能到達海灘，”玳瑁說。
我不寒而栗。我不想爬過鋒利的珊瑚。柔軟的沙子是我喜歡在我柔軟的肚子下的東西。 “你不必這樣做，別擔心，”另一位雷德利告訴我。 “我們只在柔軟的海灘上築巢，比如墨西哥、哥斯達黎加和印度的海岸。不過到時候你會自己看的……”
“我怎麼知道時間到了？”當她遊走時，我急切地問道。 “你會的，相信我，”她只會說。

我在珊瑚礁度過了一些快樂的歲月，遇到了我的許多海龜表親。除了綠海龜和玳瑁，我還遇到了赤蠵龜——它們的腦袋真的很大——還有很多像我一樣的雷德利龜。

然後有一天，就這樣，我長大了，該走了。我怎麼知道時間到了？我不知道。我內心深處的某種東西告訴我。我知道我必須和其他所有的雷德利魚一起向北遊，沿著印度東海岸一直到我們到達奧里薩邦，然後在那裡柔軟的海灘上產卵。我腦海中的小指南針會告訴我如何到達那裡。

“它只有大約 2000 公里，”當他向另一個方向游去時，一個紅頭吸了口氣。炫耀！只是因為像他這樣的蠓蟲有時會游近 15000 公里來產卵（從加利福尼亞，一路橫跨太平洋到日本）！我不理他，繼續大吃飛魚，我最喜歡的食物。

偉大的旅程開始了。

我周圍的水充滿了像我一樣的其他雷德利，

有力地游泳。
這不是一次輕鬆的旅程。一路上，危險重重。雖然我現在比大多數魚都大，但仍有鯊魚可以抓到我們。
但鯊魚並不像我們必須游過的許多漁網那樣危險。 我盡可能小心地游泳，避開所有的網，尤其是可怕的拖網。我設法逃脫了他們，但我的一些朋友就沒那麼幸運了。 最後，我到達了 Gahirmatha 海灘，那裡的雷德利鳥比印度洋其他任何地方都多。是時候安放我的第一個窩了。
我們總是在晚上築巢。我一直等到潮水有點高，這樣我就不會在沙灘上爬那麼遠了。我帶著海浪進來了，自從我出生以來，我第一次感覺到了我的土地。 一開始覺得很奇怪。慢慢地，我拖著自己爬上海灘，尋找一個乾燥的地方。

一旦我越過高潮線，沙子就變得非常乾燥

當我用前腳蹼向前拖著自己時，它在我周圍飛來飛去。

 在陸地上移動非常困難。我停下來喘了口氣，抬起頭來。 海灘又長又黑。

海灘後面是一個巨大的沙丘和一些灌木叢。我聽說這片海灘後面有一片大森林，叫做 Bhitarkanika，裡面到處都是鹹水鱷魚、眼鏡王蛇和各種其他動物。 然後，突然，我在海灘上看到了另一隻動物。它有四隻腳，正在挖龜窩。我以最快的速度回到水中。那天晚上晚些時候，我又爬了起來，爬上了海灘，進入了 Ipomea 爬行者。 在我選擇的海灘上，我清除了乾燥的沙子，用我的後腳蹼做了一個大坑。我對我如何做到這一點非常挑剔。我總是一個接一個地放入腳蹼，舀起一些沙子扔掉。
深約兩尺，形如燒瓶，細頸通入深洞，美不勝收。然後我開始產卵。 1, 2, 3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 然後我就完成了。 我小心翼翼地用沙子蓋住我珍貴的雞蛋，然後用身體把它敲下來。最後我扔了一些沙子，以確保沒有人會找到我的巢穴。 很快，很快，我爬回了我覺得更安全的海裡。
兩週後，我準備再次築巢。我們通常會在一個季節產下足夠的雞蛋來產兩三個巢。我的常識告訴我，在我以前的地方重新築巢是個好主意。這似乎是一個不錯的、安全的地方。 那天晚上，當我在淺水中等待潮汐合適時，我注意到風的輕微變化。它更強大，從不同的方向吹來。突然我意識到有數百，不，數千，其他烏龜都在等待築巢。我知道很多其他的雷德利魚也在 Gahirmatha 水域游來游去等待築巢，但我從未見過這麼多在一起。
然後，我們一起衝上海灘。海灘已經滿了。還有成千上萬的其他雷德利，沙子在空中飛揚，我們都在互相碰撞。 終於，我找到了一個空曠的地方，為自己挖了一個窩。我旁邊的烏龜太著急了，還沒挖完窩就開始產卵了。 我很震驚，我們烏龜從來不會那樣做。

“這是一個 arribada*，女士，”她說，“在這段時間裡，我們都變得有點瘋狂。” 沒有人真正知道我們為什麼要這樣做。但它對我們有用，因為數百萬隻幼龜同時孵化。這樣一來，大多數小傢伙都能逃脫被鳥、螃蟹和豺狼抓住的危險。當然，這些天來，我們也需要擔心人類。
* 在 arribada（西班牙語中的意思是“到達”）期間，成千上萬的橄欖雷德利鳥瘋狂地上岸築巢。科學家們仍然不確定他們為什麼這樣做。

最後，是時候離開並返回我的覓食地了。我將在那裡度過一兩年，吃東西並積累能量，以便再次訪問 Gahirmatha。另一方面，綠海龜有時需要吃五六年才能有精力進行下一次築巢之旅。 當我離開時，我想起了我留下的孩子們。 50 到 60 天，雞蛋將留在沙子下，被太陽加熱。然後有一天，它們會孵化，用它們的吻尖打開它們的殼。他們會擠在一起，一百多隻幼龜在沙子下，等待太陽落山，沙子變涼。 然後，在黑暗中，當安全的時候，他們會一下子出來。他們會看到從海面上反射的月光，就知道該往哪走。希望他們不會是路燈讓他們走錯方向。
他們將逆著海浪游泳，並在迎面而來的浪花下潛入水中。
哦，會有大魚和小魚來抓它們，還有海鷗和鷹，但有些會逃走。在公海中，他們會發現自己的小海藻筏，他們多年來的漂浮家園。 然後他們會長大，也許他們會來到我的飼養場。也許我們會見面，雖然我當然不認識他們。 儘管如此，我很高興知道它們就在某個地方，有一天它們會像我一樣回到這片海灘產卵，重新開始整個美好的生活循環。
OLIVE RIDLEY 給您的信息 海龜在世界範圍內處於危險之中，原因有很多。一些種類的海龜被殺死是為了它們的肉，用來做龜湯。玳瑁的殼用來製作玳瑁製品，如眼鏡架和髮飾。許多海龜蛋和幼龜被狗和烏鴉等捕食者吃掉。但最大的危險來自捕魚。許多海龜不小心被各種漁網夾住，淹死了。 在印度，有許多保護組織正試圖拯救海龜。每個沿海國家都有一個或多個這樣的團體。

你能做些什麼來保護海龜？ 如果你住在海龜築巢的海灘附近： • 幫助保持海灘清潔，以免海龜寶寶和媽媽受傷。 • 教育您當地的成年人了解海灘附近的路燈和其他燈光如何對海龜幼體有害——一旦它們孵化，幼體就會通過尋找月光在水面上的反射來確定大海的位置，因此如果有其他明亮的區域內的燈光，他們可能會感到困惑並朝錯誤的方向遊蕩，並陷入危險之中。 • 了解您所在的州是否有當地的海龜保護組織，看看您是否可以加入他們。 如果您不住在海灘附近： 閱讀更多有關海龜的信息，並與您認識的每個人談論它們所面臨的危險。傳播意識是保護的重要組成部分。
eng:
When I woke up in the morning, the sun was
shining again. I looked around me, wondering where I was. And then I
remembered. I was a baby sea turtle - an olive ridley - in the middle of a big
blue world, which I had heard someone call the ocean. There was blue and green
water in every direction, and the sunlight was playing games with the clouds. I
tucked my flippers beneath my body and floated for a while, letting the current
carry me.
I did not know where I was. But that does not
matter when the sun is shining, and your stomach is full.
The sun warmed me, and filled me with new energy.

Just as I was beginning to think that I would love to spend the rest of my life here, a school of fish went by. Chasing them was a really big fish. I could tell he was a really hungry fish too. When he saw me, his eyes lit up. “Mmmmm,” he seemed to be thinking, “baby turtle soup!” 
Moments later, I was swimming as fast as I could,
with those big teeth snapping at my little hind flippers.
Just when I was beginning to tire, I saw a
seaweed raft. A seaweed raft is just that, a floating mass of seaweed and
driftwood that travels around the ocean, carried along by the current. On and
in the raft are the Drifters, all the sea’s little and not-so-little creatures
that float around the ocean, waiting for something to happen. Gratefully, I
slipped into the raft. I would not leave this safe haven for many, many years.

Being on the raft was like going on a world cruise. I enjoyed it very much, but as I grew up, I decided it was time to explore the big wide world outside the raft.

I had heard
wonderful things about a place called the Reef where a lot of other turtles
lived. Everyone said the Reef
was the fairyland of the ocean. They
said it was full of beautiful, brightly-coloured creatures, both harmless ones
like the clown fish and poisonous ones like the scorpion fish. I wondered how I
would find it.

All
of a sudden, it became very dark. A huge shadow covered me. Frightened, I
looked up, only to see the biggest turtle I had ever seen. His back was soft
and leathery. I stared. A turtle with a soft back? All the ones I know have
very hard backs.

The big turtle caught me staring. “Surprised?” he grunted pleasantly. “You shouldn’t be. I’m a leatherback turtle.”

“Good name, Sir,” I mumbled. 


“Where
are you going, Sir?” I continued. “To the Reef to live with the other turtles?”
“Ah,”
sighed the leatherback. “I wish I had that luxury. But no, I am too busy
searching for jellyfish. They are all I eat.”
“Where
do you find them?” I asked.

“Out in the deep, deep, sea,” said the
leatherback. “Sometimes I have to dive more than a 1000 feet to reach them. And
sometimes I go all the way to Canada, where the water gets very cold. No other
reptile could survive in such cold waters.”“If
it isn’t too rude, Sir,” I said quietly, “can I ask how much you weigh?”
“Nearly
600 kilograms, little one,” replied the leatherback, looking amused. “And I’m
proud of all of it, including the fat. For it’s the fat that helps me get
through the long migrations. Well, I have to be off now...”

“Of
course, Sir,” I said. “But before you go, could you tell me where I might find
the Reef?”
“That
way,” said the leatherback, pointing with a flipper as he swam off.
“Thank you,
Sir, and happy hunting!” I called out as I swam towards the reef.

It was on the Reef that I met old Green Turtle. 

My friend Hawksbill, whose mouth is curved like a hawk’s beak, told me old Green was nearly 50 years old. “My! That’s old!” I said.
“How come she looks so young?” “Well,” said Hawksbill, “Green Turtle eats only
sea grass and algae, so it took her nearly 30 years to become an adult. You and
I will be adults by the time we are ten.”

“Do you know,” he
continued, “that when she wants to nest, she migrates to islands in the middle
of the ocean? Clear blue lagoons, white sand, they’re beautiful...”“Have you been there?” I
asked.“Oh yes, sometimes you
have to crawl over the coral to get to the beach,” said Hawksbill.

I shuddered. I would hate to crawl over sharp coral. Soft sand is what I like under my soft belly.“You won’t have to do it, don’t worry,” another ridley told me. “We only nest on soft beaches, like the ones on the coasts of Mexico, Costa Rica, and India. But you’ll see for yourself, when it’s time...”
“How will I know it’s time?” I asked eagerly as she swam away.“You will, trust me,” was all she would say.

I spent some happy years
on the Reef, meeting many of my turtle cousins. Apart from green turtles and
hawksbills, I met loggerhead turtles - the ones with the really big heads - and
plenty of other ridleys like me.
And then one day, just
like that, I was all grown up, and it was time to go. How did I know it was
time? I don’t know. Something deep inside me told me so. I knew I had
to swim north with all the other ridleys, all along
the eastern coast of India until we reached Orissa, and lay my eggs on the soft
beaches there. The little compass in my head would tell me how to get there.

“It’s only about 2000 kilometers,” sniffed a loggerhead as he swam off in a different direction. Show off! Just because loggerheads like him sometimes swim almost 15000 kilometres to lay their eggs (from California, all the way across the Pacific Ocean to Japan)! I ignored him, and continued gorging on flying fish, my favourite food.The big journey began. The water around me was full of other ridleys like me, swimming powerfully.

It wasn’t an easy journey.  Along the way, there
were many dangers. 




















Though I was now bigger
than most of the fish, there were still sharks that could catch us.

But
the sharks were not as dangerous as the many fishing nets that we had to swim
past.
I swam as
carefully as I could, avoiding all the nets, especially the terrible trawl
nets. I managed to escape them all, but some of my friends weren’t so lucky.
Finally, I reached the
beach of Gahirmatha, the place where more ridleys nested than anywhere else in
the Indian Ocean. It was time to lay my first nest.

We always nest at night.
I waited until the tide was a little high, so that I wouldn’t have that far to
crawl on the beach. I came in with the surf, and felt land under me for the
first time since my birth. 




















It felt very strange at
first. Slowly, I dragged myself up the beach to find a dry spot.

Once I had moved past the high-tide line, the sand became very dry and flew all around me as I dragged myself forward with my front flippers.  It is very difficult to move on land. I paused to take a breath and looked up. The beach was long and dark.

Behind the beach was a huge dune and some bushes. I had heard there was a
large forest behind this beach called Bhitarkanika which was full of saltwater
crocodiles, king cobras and all kinds of other animals.

Then, suddenly, I saw another animal on the beach. It had four legs and it
was digging up a turtle nest. I went back into the water as fast as I could.
Later that night, I crawled up again, and went up the beach into the Ipomea
creepers.
At
my chosen spot on the beach, I cleared away the dry sand, and made a big pit
with my hind flippers. I am very fussy about how exactly I do this. I always
put one flipper in after the other, scoop up some sand and throw it out.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

Two weeks later, I was getting ready to nest
again. We usually make enough eggs to lay two or three nests during a season.
My common sense told me that it would be a good idea to nest again where I had
the previous time. It seemed like a good, safe place.
That
night, as I was waiting in the shallow water for the tide to be right, I
noticed a slight change in the wind. It was stronger and blowing from a
different direction. Suddenly I realised that there were hundreds, no,
thousands, of other turtles all waiting to nest. I knew a lot of other ridleys
were also swimming around in the Gahirmatha waters waiting to nest, but I had
never seen so many together.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

And
then, we were all rushing up the beach together. The beach was already full.
There were thousands of other ridleys, sand was flying in the air, we were all
bumping into each other. Finally, I managed to find a clear spot, and dig a
nest for myself. The turtle next to me was in such a hurry, she started to lay
her eggs even before she could finish digging her nest. I was shocked, we
turtles never do that.

“It’s an arribada*, lady,” she said, “we all get a little crazy during this time.”
Nobody really knows why we do this. But it works
for us, because millions of hatchlings hatch at the same time. That way, most
of the little ones escape being caught by birds, crabs and jackals. These days,
of course, we have humans to worry about as well.* During an arribada - which means ‘arrival’ in Spanish - thousands of olive ridleys come ashore in a frenzy to nest. Scientists still aren’t sure why they do this.

Finally,
it is time to leave and return to my feeding ground. I will spend a year or two
there, eating and building up the energy for another visit to Gahirmatha. Green
Turtle, on the other hand, sometimes needs to eat for five or six years before
she has the energy to make her next journey to nest.
As I leave, I think of the little ones I have
left behind. For 50 to 60 days, the eggs will remain under the sand, warmed by
the sun. And then one day, they will hatch, breaking open their shells with the
tips of their snouts. They will huddle together, over a hundred hatchlings
under the sand, waiting for the sun to set and the sand to cool. Then, in the
darkness, when it is safe, they will come out, all at once. They will see the
moonlight bouncing off the sea, and know which way to go. Hopefully they will
be no streetlights to make them go in the wrong direction.

They
will swim against the waves and dive under the oncoming breakers.

Oh, there
will be big fish and small fish out to get them, and seagulls and eagles, but
some will get away. Out into the open sea where they will find their own little
seaweed rafts, their floating homes for many years. Then they will grow up, and
perhaps they will come to my feeding ground. Perhaps we will meet, though of
course I will not know them.
Still,
I am happy knowing that they are out there somewhere, and that someday they
will return like me to this very beach to lay their own eggs, and start the
whole wonderful circle of life all over again.

A MESSAGE FROM THE
OLIVE RIDLEY TO YOU
Sea turtles are in danger worldwide, for many reasons. Some species of
turtles are killed for their meat, which is used to make turtle soup. The shell
of the hawksbill turtle is used to make tortoiseshell products like eyeglass
frames and hair accessories. Many turtle eggs and hatchlings are eaten by
predators like dogs and crows. But the biggest
danger comes from fishing. Many sea turtles get accidentally caught in a
variety of fishing nets, drown, and die. In India, there are many conservation groups that are trying to save sea turtles. Each coastal state has one or more such groups.

What can YOU do to protect sea turtles?If you live near a beach where turtles come to nest:• Help keep the beach clean so that baby and mother turtles do not get hurt.•

Educate the adults in your locality about how streetlights and other lights near the beach can be harmful to turtle hatchlings – once they hatch, hatchlings figure out where the sea is by looking for the reflection of moonlight on water, so if there are other bright lights in the area, they can get confused and wander off in the wrong direction, and into danger.• Find out if your state has a local sea turtle conservation group and see if you can join them. If you don’t live near a beach:Read more and more about sea turtles and talk to everyone you know about the dangers they are facing. Spreading awareness is a BIG part of conservation.
Cheekoo was the unhappiest girl among her friends.She was certainly the unhappiest girl in her entire class. She was perhaps the unhappiest girl in the world.

Friends? Cheekoo had no
friends anymore.


No one wanted to play with
Cheekoo.

Because she had a cloud
hanging over her head.


A cloud of TRASH.

Orange peels and biscuit
packets,

Broken toys and pencil
shavings,

Twisted plastic bottles and
colourful plastic bags,

All surrounded by a swarm of
buzzing flies.

No one wanted to play with a
girl who had a cloud of trash hanging over her.


What if a rotten banana peel
fell on your head? YUCK!

Cheekoo couldn’t even play
hide-and-seek anymore.


The cloud would always give
her away.

"Let’s walk to school
together," she said to Sona.

Sona ran off in the opposite
direction.


"May I borrow your pencil
sharpener?" she asked Sweety. Sweety made a face and changed her seat to go sit with Asha.

Cheekoo even had to eat her
lunch alone.Cheekoo knew that she should have listened to her Amma. Amma always told her not to litter.
"Don’t throw the banana peel on the road!""Throw the empty biscuit packet in the dustbin." But Cheekoo never listened. She only laughed and kept littering.

Then one day, Amma became very angry. "Soon, all this trash will start following you!" she said.Cheekoo just laughed.

The next morning, Cheekoo woke
up to a foul smell and the sound of buzzing flies. The cloud of trash was hanging over her head.




Amma’s words had come true!
And then, Cheekoo was unable to laugh.

Cheekoo tried to run away.  

But the trash cloud followed
her everywhere.


Cheekoo took a broom to sweep
the cloud down.


But the trash could not be
swept away.

Cheekoo tried EVERYTHING.


She screamed and asked the
cloud to leave her alone. She even tried throwing the cloud into the dustbin.


But the cloud of trash just
wouldn’t go. So
Cheekoo became very unhappy.

Then something happened!

Cheekoo saw Bala throwing a
banana peel on the road.


Cheekoo was annoyed. Could he
not see the cloud over her head?




"Oye silly boy!" she
yelled. "Don’t throw the peel on the road. Someone will slip!"

Bala, scared of the trash
cloud, threw the peel in the dustbin.

The next day, the trash cloud
had become smaller!


"How did that happen?"
Cheekoo wondered.




Then, Cheekoo saw Reema
Aunty throwing away
plastic bags.

"Aunty!" Cheekoo said.
"Please pick up these bags and reuse them."


Reema Aunty picked up the bags
and left.


The next day when Cheekoo woke
up, the cloud was much smaller.


Cheekoo smiled. She knew what
she had to do.

When someone threw away
a biscuit packet or pencil shavings, Cheekoo stopped them.


She picked up every twisted
plastic bottle and put it in the dustbin.





The village became cleaner and
cleaner. And Cheekoo’s cloud became smaller and smaller.


Until one day, it was gone. COMPLETELY gone.


Cheekoo
was now perhaps the happiest girl in the world.
Cheekoo never littered again.  Secretly, she liked living in a clean village.But she was also scared that the trash cloud would come back, some day.  Who knew!

Let’s Talk About Trash

Ever wondered what happens to
trash once you throw it away? No,
it doesn’t become a cloud on your head. The trash ends up in a big garbage bin near your home.
When you litter, the trash collects by the side of the road. Some of it goes into the drains that carry waste water from your house. This clogs the drains and attracts flies which spread nasty diseases! UGH! Nobody likes living in a dirty environment. Ask Cheekoo.

Here’s how NOT  to make a
cloud of trash - We
can start by not littering our surroundings. - Always,
always throw waste
into a dustbin – look around for the nearest one.

- After you eat a banana, don’t throw it on the road. Put the peel in a small bag until you find a dustbin. - There are many things that you may think are useless, like the paper bag into which you put the peel. But not everything is waste. So don’t throw the bag with the peel! Take it home and reuse it. - Cover dustbins so that flies can’t get inside.
zho: 琪酷是她朋友中最不开心的人。她也绝对是她整个班级里最不开心的人。她可能是世界上最不开心的人。
朋友？琪酷根本没有朋友。没有人愿意和琪酷一起玩。因为她的头顶有一团云。
橘子皮和饼干包装盒，坏的玩具和铅笔屑，扭曲的塑料瓶和彩色的塑料袋，这些全部都被一群吵闹的苍蝇包围着。
没有人愿意跟一个被一团垃圾包围的女孩。想象下如果一个烂的香蕉皮掉到你的头上？恶！ 琪酷根本就不能玩捉迷藏游戏。
“我们一起走去学校吧，“琪酷对松娅说。松娅从相反的方向跑掉了。“我可以借你的转笔刀吗？“她问甜心。甜心做了个鬼脸然后坐到了爱莎旁边。
“不要忘路上扔香蕉皮！”“把空的饼干袋扔到垃圾桶！“不过琪酷从来不听。我只是笑然后继续扔。
有一天，安马变的很生气。“很快，松油的垃圾都会跟随你！“她说琪酷只是笑。转天早上，琪酷在难闻的气味跟吵闹的苍蝇声中醒来。垃圾云已经在她头上了。
琪酷试着逃跑。可是垃圾云总是跟随着她。琪酷用扫帚把垃圾云打下来。不过垃圾还是不能被扫下来。
琪酷试了所有的办法。她尖叫着让垃圾云离开她。她也试着把垃圾云扔进垃圾箱。不过垃圾云根本就不离开。所以琪酷变得很不开心。
然后有些事情发生了！琪酷看到芭拉在路上扔了一个香蕉皮。琪酷很着急。他看不到她头上的垃圾云吗？
转天，垃圾云变小了！“这是怎么发生的？”琪酷问。然后，琪酷看到瑞玛阿姨在扔塑料袋。
当有人扔饼干袋或铅笔屑的时候，琪酷阻止他们。她捡起了每一个扭曲的塑料瓶然后把它们放进垃圾箱里。城镇变的越来越干净。琪酷头上的垃圾云变的越来越小了。
琪酷再也不乱扔垃圾了。慢慢的，她开始喜欢住在一个干净的城镇里。不过她也担心垃圾云有一天会回来。
让我们说说垃圾吧！有想过当你把垃圾扔掉的时候它们会怎样吗？它们不是在你的头上变成垃圾云。垃圾会在你家附近的大垃圾箱里。当你乱扔的时候，垃圾会集中到道路的两边。有一些垃圾会渠道你家收集废水的水渠。这样会在水渠中造成一些障碍物，然后吸引苍蝇造成疾病的传播！恶！没有人愿意生活在脏的环境里。问问琪酷。
这是怎样预防制造垃圾云- 我们不要随便乱扔垃圾-总是把垃圾扔到垃圾箱里 （四周看找最近的垃圾箱）
吃完香蕉以后，不要把皮乱扔在路上。把皮放到一个小袋子里，然后扔到垃圾箱。-有许多你可能觉得没用的事。像是把皮放到纸袋里。不过不是所有的东西都是没有的。不要把袋子跟皮一起扔掉。把袋子拿回家，重新使用它。- 盖住垃圾箱，然后苍蝇就不能飞进去了。
我們是一家四口。我到哪裡都跟著晴古。
我必須照顧晴古，因為我比他年長。
有時候晴古很粗心，守護房子便成了我的工作。
我們做什麼都在一起。我們一起工作。
我們一起玩。
甚至一起被媽媽罵。
每當晴古去上學，我會幫忙媽媽。我會趕走烏鴉，不讓它們接近印度薄餅。
今天晴古是我的老師。我終於可以學到新東西了。
我是一隻乖狗狗。我不會把貓咪嚇跑。
你是晴古的朋友嗎？那麼你也是我的朋友。
閱讀下列句子。以下的活動，哪一個是你喜歡的活動？我喜歡跳舞。我喜歡游泳。我喜歡跳繩。我喜歡畫畫。
我喜歡騎腳踏車。我喜歡攀爬。有時候我們說：「跟狗一樣的忠心。」這是因為狗狗總是跟主人很親近。如果狗狗去了很遙遠的地方或是走失了，它總是能找到回家的路。
eng: ﻿There are four of us in the family. Miguel is my favorite,                              and I follow him everywhere.
I have to keep an eye on Miguel.                                 I'm older than him.
Sometimes Miguel is not careful,                         so I had to guard the house.
﻿I am with him in everything. We sympathize with everyone.
We play with each other.
And Mother scolded us too.
I help Mom when Miguel is busy.   I pimp the birds away from our wares.
Today, Miguel will teach me. Finally, I will learn something new.
I am a kind dog. I'm not chasing cats.
If you're Miguel's friend, I'm your friend too!
Read the following sentences. Which of these do you like? I love to dance. I love to swim. I love jumping rope. I love to draw.

I love cycling. I love to climb. There is a saying “Nothing is more loyal than a dog”. This is because the dog does not leave his master. Whether he goes away or gets lost, he can definitely return to his master.

zho: 這是一項巨大的任務，它是首要的任務，第二也是非常重要的，因為你永遠不能忽視大自然的召喚。 所以當你得去的時候你就得去！有些人可以在家裡做這些事情，有些人需要外出。 有些人在倒完成後需要倒入些水來清洗，其他人不需要。 在世界不同的地方有所不同，就像在歷史中的不同時期一樣。
廁所的歷史很久以前，大約3000多年前，印度河谷的人們都有美麗的房子，裡面裝有廁所。 人們可以在隱密地完成他們的事情，然後倒入一桶水，將廢物沖洗至溝渠裏去。 這樣他們可以保持房屋和街道的清潔。
印度河谷位於當今的巴基斯坦和印度，是除了古埃及和美索不達米亞之外我們所知道的三個最古老的文明之一。 從今時今日我們所看到的廢墟中，印度河谷人民的建築技術水平很高，他們擅長製作金屬和陶瓷製品，並且非常精心的策劃了城市排水系統。

大約在同一時間，世界其他地方都有類似的廁所安排。 在埃及和巴比倫，廁所是安裝在家園內的，而蘇格蘭的斯卡拉·布萊（Scara Brae）和地中海的米諾克里特島（Minoan Crete）的遺跡顯示了許多管道，這些管道顯示出那裏的廁所應該是安裝於家裏。大約在二千年前的羅馬，人們都是使用公共廁所的。 一塊長長的石塊裏每隔一小段就有鎖眼形的切口。 人們會坐在這些開口處，一邊上廁所一邊和他們旁邊的人進行友好的交談。我已告訴你那是“公共”廁所！
他們事後是怎麼清理自己的，你知道嗎 ？在我告訴你後你可能希望你從來沒有好奇過。他們會以一條長長的棍子把一塊海綿貼在一端，然後將海綿浸入水中，用它擦拭屁股。 在他們感到乾淨後，他們只是把棍子交給坐在一旁的鄰居，然後他們會把它浸在水中，再次使用它。 讓我給你一個友好的提示 - 如果你到這個地方，請確保你選擇第一個座位！
在羅馬，不是每個人都不得不在公共場合如廁。 如果你是超級富豪，你會在家裡有一個便壺讓你如廁。 一旦完成，您只需清理到外面的街道上。 如果當時有人偶然經過那只能說他們倒霉了！大約500年前，英國的伊麗莎白女王在她家裡建了一座廁所。 那座廁所有一條管道通向外面的污水坑。 但是她沒並什麼機會使用到，因為下水道的臭氣充塞了廁所，臭味難聞直至令人無法呼吸。 所以她又回覆使用原先的便壺。
現在的廁所現今的廁所不臭，這是如何辦到的？1775年，英國發明家亞歷山大·康明（Alexander Cumming）發現了一種方式。 他不用直管將馬桶連接到污水管，而是將其做成S形。 這樣做可以確保在糞便和尿液排放下來時，氣味不會上升。 你有沒有註意到在沖洗後，馬桶總會保留有一點點的水？ 這就是以密封方式防止臭味通過排水口進入廁所。
就像古時代一樣，現今社會中，世界各地的廁所都各有所不同。有些地方根本沒有廁所。 一些廁所是坐式的，有些是蹲式的。 有些是以水桶用於沖洗，有些則是裝有一個充滿水的大水槽和一個可以釋放水的手柄。 有些廁所還備有衛生紙，有些廁則有一個水龍頭或一桶水讓人沖洗乾淨。

有一些廁所根本不用水。 就如飛機上的廁所，隨著飛機動盪，馬桶裡當然不適合存有任何水！ 那些廢物通過強大的真空被吸入並儲存在下面的槽中。那些廢物將在飛機降落後被清理。除此之外，陸地上有些廁所也是沒有水的。 他們是為了有些不容易獲得水的地方所設計和建造的，比如泰米爾納德邦（Tamil Nadu）和馬哈拉施特拉邦（Maharashtra）的偏遠村莊。 既然那些廁所一直運作良好，那把我們都建類似的廁所是不是一個好主意呢？ 如果我們使用的水越少，我們制造的廢物及污水就越少，那也對地球越好不是嗎？
未來的廁所怎麼建造無水廁所？第一步是確保不要讓尿液和糞便混合。 不，它不像聽起來那樣噁心 - 它只需要一個巧妙的設計。 就像有一個篩子，讓廢水通過，但可以擋住糞便並傳送到不同的坑。
既然尿液本身是無害的（只有聚集在尿液上的細菌會引起臭味和危害），這樣我們便能將它們安全地流入地面或廢物利用。 方法如下：氫氣我們可以從尿液中分離出氫氣來，並用於燃燒發電機。 尿液中還含有氮，磷，鉀，浙西是肥料的重要成分。 現在我們處理了尿液，那我們將如何處理那些糞便呢？ 嗯，如果將其與灰和草混合併放置在坑中，數以百萬計的細菌會將其分解成可用於農業的有用的堆肥。
這些廁所將幫助我們建設一個沒有“浪費”的世界。 相反的，它可以讓我們廢物利用，變成一些有用的東西。如果一個城市的所有房屋都建有這樣的廁所，就不會有污水，也不需要昂貴的污水處理廠，更不會將污水通過排水渠流到湖泊和河流！ 那將會是個美好的未來！
第18頁是一個棋盤遊戲。 你需要和幾個朋友玩，並需要一個骰子。 以下是一些指示說明：在3女王的便壺：非法的使用女王的便壺。處罰：被懲罰待在她的廁所2圈。在6羅馬廁所的第一座位：對你有好處！第一位使用海綿！向前移動7個空格。

在9待在廁所排隊！只有在您獲得2或4時才移動。在12羅馬廁所最後座位：呸。 不想使用那個海綿？ 好吧，我們會讓你消磨时间時間。 停止轉一圈在15摩亨佐 - 達羅（Mohenjo-daro）：恭喜！ 你已經進入了所有時間最好的廁所之一！ 所以你可以再次投擲骰子。 如果你獲得2,4 或 6，那就移動相應的格子數量吧。 如果你獲得1,3 或 5，那你可以選擇板上的任何棋子（除了你的），並將它往後移動相應的格子數量。
在19哎呀。 把廁所弄髒了移回3個空格。在21無水馬桶：恭喜！ 你剛剛使用無水廁所！ 拿快捷吧！在23空中廢物！噢親愛的！ 你被飛行的廢物擲中了！ 只有當您獲得1或6時才移動。
eng:
It’s a big job, it’s number one priority and number two is
pretty important too, because you can never ignore nature’s call.
So when you gotta go, you gotta go! Some people can do this business
inside their houses, some have to go outside. Some pour water after
it’s done, others need not. It’s different in different parts of
the world, just as it was different at different times in history.

Toilets of the past

A very long time ago, more than 3,000 years ago,
the people of Indus Valley had beautiful houses with toilets built
inside them. People could finish their business in privacy and pour a
bucket of water which would flush the waste down a drain. This way,
they managed to keep their houses and streets clean.

The Indus Valley, situated in present day Pakistan and India, is one of the three oldest civilizations that we know of, the other two being Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia. From what we can see of the ruins today, the people of Indus Valley had great building skills, were good at making metal and ceramic products, and planned their city-wide drainage systems very elaborately.

Around the same time, similar toilet arrangements were present in
other parts of the world. Homes in Egypt and Babylonia had toilets
built in, and the ruins in Skara Brae in Scotland and the Minoan
Crete in the Mediterranean show plenty of pipes leading out of what
definitely seems like a toilet inside a house. 


A little later, about 2,000 years ago in Rome, people used public
toilets. A long slab of stone had keyhole-shaped cuts at intervals.
People would sit on these openings and do their toilet business while
having a friendly chat with the person next to them. I told you it
was a “public” toilet!

How did they clean themselves, do you wonder? After I tell you, you
might wish you had never wondered. 



They took a long stick that had a sponge attached to one end and
dipped the sponge into water, and then used it to wipe their
backsides. After they felt clean, they simply handed the stick over
to their neighbour, who dipped it in water and used it again. Let me
give you a friendly tip here – if you ever find yourself in this
place, make sure you pick the very first seat!

Not everyone had to poop in public in Rome. If you were super-rich,
you would have a chamber pot at home into which you would do your
business. Once done, you would simply empty the contents onto the
street outside. And if someone happened to walk by at the time, well,
too bad for them!

About 500 years ago, Queen Elizabeth of England had a toilet
constructed inside her house. It had a pipe leading out into a sewage
pit outside. But she never used it much because the stench from the
sewer filled the toilet and she could not even breathe. So back to
the chamber pot she went.

Toilets of the present
Toilets these days don’t stink. How did they achieve that? In 1775,
the English inventor Alexander Cumming figured out a way. Instead of
using a straight pipe to connect the toilet to the sewage line, he
made it S-shaped. This made sure that while poop and pee and water
can go 

down
the drain, no
smell can come back up. Have you noticed that a little
water always stays in the toilet even after flushing? This is what
creates the "seal" and prevents the foul smell from entering the
room through the drain.

Just like olden times, different parts of the world today have
different kinds of toilets.Some places don’t have toilets at all.
Some toilets are made for sitting, some are made for squatting. Some
have a bucket with water for flushing, others have a tank filled with
water and a handle that releases the water. Some toilets have paper
to wipe the backside, some have a tap or a bucket of water to wash
up.

There are some toilets that don’t use water at all. Like the ones
on a plane. With all the turbulence, you certainly don’t want any
water in the toilet bowl! The waste is removed by a powerful vacuum
and stored in a tank below. After the plane lands, the waste is
disposed of.

There are also waterless toilets on the ground. They were designed
and built for places without easy access to water, such as remote
villages in Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra. They have been working well,
so wouldn’t it be a good idea to have such toilets everywhere?
Because the less water
we use, and
the less sewage we create, the better for the planet, right?

Toilets of the future

How do you make a waterless toilet?

The first step is to make sure that you don’t let the urine and the
faeces mix. No it’s not as gross as it sounds – it just needs the
pot to be designed in a clever way. Like having a sloping bamboo mat
act as a sieve that will allow the waste water to pass through, but
can hold the poop and send it to a different pit.

Since urine by itself is not harmful (it’s only the bacteria that
collect on open urine that cause the smell and the hazard), it can be
safely let into the ground or put to use. Here’s how: Hydrogen can
be separated from the urine and used to fuel a generator.Urine also has nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium that are great
ingredients for fertilizers.Now that urine is taken care of, what do we do with the solid waste?
Well, if it is properly mixed with ash and grass, and allowed to rest
in a pit, millions of bacteria will break it down into perfectly
useful compost for agriculture.

These toilets will help us build a world where there is no "waste." Instead it is turned into something of use. If
all houses in a city have such toilets, no sewage comes out of them,
no expensive sewage treatment plants are necessary and no sewage will
flow through the drains into lakes and rivers! What a great future for everyone!

On pg 18 is a board game. You’ll need a few friends to play with and a die. Below are instructions on what to do if you land here: 


	
	
	
	


At
3
Queen’s chamber pot:
Illegal use of Queen’s chamber
pot. Punishment: Banished into her toilet for 2 turns. 

At
6
Roman toilet first seat:
Good for you! First use of
sponge! Move ahead 7 spaces.

At
			9
Stuck in the toilet queue! Move only if you roll a 2 or a
			4.

At
12
Roman toilet last seat:
Yuck. Don’t want to use that
sponge? Okay, we'll let you kill the time. Lose a turn. 

At
15
Mohenjo-daro:
Congratulations! You have entered one of
the best toilets of all time! So you get to roll the die again. If
you roll 2,4,6 move that many spaces forward. If you roll 1,3,5 you
can pick any pawn on the board (other than yours) and move it that
many spaces back.

At
19
Oops. Left the toilet dirty. Move back 3 spaces. 

At
21
Waterless toilet:
Congratulations! You just used a
waterless toilet! Take the short-cut! 

At
23
Flying waste!
Oh dear! You got hit by flying waste! Move
only if you roll a 1 or 6.

Today,
we will climb up a ladder together. It is a rather unusual ladder. In
this ladder, the distance between the rungs gets bigger and BIGGER and BIGGER as you climb up the steps, growing 10 times at each step. Sometimes we will climb one step at a time and at other times we will skip many steps at one go.


The
funny thing is that we are not even sure which the last step is or
whether the steps go on forever. Let the exciting journey begin!

Step
0: 1 metre
What
do a five year old boy, a cricket bat and a newborn baby elephant
have in common? All of them have a height of about 1 metre (or 1m for
short)! It would be awkward to say that the ceiling of a room is 3
baby elephants high. So we make the sensible choice of saying that
the height of the ceiling is 3 metres.

Step
1: 10 metres
Now
that you have a feel for the size of one metre, we are ready to climb
to the next step of our ladder, at 10 metres. A three storey building
or a mango tree is roughly 10 metres high. A cricket pitch is about
twice that length. 
Can
you think of other objects that are about 10 m long or high?

Step
2: 100 metres
Have
you noticed that with every step we add a zero to the right of the
number we had before and the step number matches the number of
zeroes? Keep track of that as we climb along. 
If
you have run the 100m race on school sports day, or watched sprinters
do it on TV, you know exactly how far that is. Now imagine if the
100m track stood up! That would be about the height of two Gol
Gumbaz*-es. 
*The
Gol Gumbaz in Bijapur, Karnataka, is the tomb of Mohammed Adil Shah.
When it was built in 1656, it had the largest dome in the world. It
held the record until 1881!

Step
3: 1000 metres
Thousand
metres has a special name - it is called 1 kilometre or 1 km. You
would cover this distance if you ran the 100 metre race 10 times -
phew!  You would need to climb about 9 km to reach the top of Mount
Everest.

Step
6: 10,00,000 metres 

Now
let's skip 2 steps and go to step 6, which has six zeroes to the
right of 1.
The
distance from the northern tip of India in Kashmir to the southern
tip at Kanyakumari is about 4 times this distance, or 4 times
10,00,000 m, or 40,00,000 m. Because 40,00,000 m is quite a mouthful,
we usually say 4000 km, which is the same thing.

Step
8: 10,00,00,000 metres
How
far away is the bright, beautiful moon? It is right there on the 8th
step of our distance ladder at about 4 times 10,00,00,000 m, or
4,00,000 km away from the earth!

Step
11: 1,00,00,00,00,000 metres
Let
us skip two more steps and race to the blazing hot Sun. How far away
is it? It is about 10,00,00,000
 km PLUS another
5,00,00,000 km. That is very, VERY far away indeed!
But
the far, far away sun still lights up the world and makes us sweat in
summer. Amazing, isn't it?

Last
Step???
Is
there a last step on the ladder? We don’t know yet!  But with
powerful telescopes, scientists have been able to see way beyond the
sun. The farthest object that they have been able to spot is on the
26th
step, 10,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,000 m away! That is SERIOUSLY FAR!


Maybe
when you grow up, you can discover something even further away, on
the 28th or 29th step. Isn’t that an exciting thought?

Fun with MeasuringThe following activity done in a classroom setting is a great
way to give children a feel for large distances and can engage the children
either in a single group, or in teams.
 
1. Ask the children to cut long strips (each about an inch
wide) from old newspapers. 
 
2. Ask them to stick the strips end to end with tape or glue
to make longer strips, until they get a strip that is 1 metre long (they can
use a measuring tape for this). 
 
3.  Now ask the
children to use this 1 m long strip as a measure and make 10 similar strips and
stick them end to end to make a 10 m long strip. They can lie down next to this
strip, head to head and feet to feet, and see how many of them it takes to make
10 m. 
 
4. They can then stick ten 10 m strips together to make a 100
m strip that goes round the classroom many times. 
 
5. What about a 1 km strip? How many times does that go
around the classroom? Which team was able to create a 1 km long strip fastest?

Notes for Parents & Teachers:

 - 

When writing down big numbers with lots of zeroes after the 1, it is very easy for children - and adults! - to make mistakes. That is why the 'Powers of 10' notation is such a useful thing. Through this book, children can be taught how to use it - all they need to do is to count the number of zeroes to the right of the 1, and write that number as a superscript of 10. For instance, 1000, which has 3 zeroes after the 1, can be written as 103. And 10000000 (7 zeroes after the 1), can be compactly written as 107. Simple!
 - 

In this book, we stopped our 'How far is far?' game at the Sun. If you want to take the game further, you may want to bring in the nearest star beyond the Sun, Proxima Centauri, which is 1016 m away from the Sun. Or the distance from one end of the Milky Way to another, which is 1,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,000 (or 1021) m!
 - 

One thing you should know is that the distances that are given in the book are approximate, not exactly accurate. For example, 3984 km is given as 4000 km. This is not 'unscientific'. Rough estimates are very useful in science! Maybe you can do an activity with the kids to emphasize this. Is the length of a pencil closer to 101 cm or 102 cms? Is the weight of the school bus closer to 103 kgs or 104 kgs? Let the children come up with their own questions for their classmates too.
zho: 今天，我们一起爬梯子。这是一个相当不寻常的梯子。在这个梯子中，当你爬上台阶时，梯级之间的距离变得越来越大，越来越大，每一步增加 10 倍。有时我们会一步一步爬，有时我们会一次跳过很多步骤。       有趣的是，我们甚至不确定最后一步是哪一步，或者这些步骤是否永远持续下去。让激动人心的旅程开始吧！
第 0 步：1 米   五岁的男孩、板球棒和新生的小象有什么共同点？   它们的高度都在1米左右（简称1m）！说一个房间的天花板有 3 头小象高是很尴尬的。所以我们做出明智的选择，说天花板的高度是 3 米
第一步：10米   现在您已经对一米的大小有了感觉，我们准备爬到我们梯子的下一步，在 10 米处。一栋三层楼的建筑或一棵芒果树大约有 10 米高。一个板球场大约是这个长度的两倍。   你能想到其他大约 10 m 长或高的物体吗？

第 2 步：100 米   您是否注意到，每一步我们都会在之前的数字右侧添加一个零，并且步骤编号与零的数量相匹配？在我们攀爬时跟踪它。   如果您在学校运动日跑过 100 米比赛，或者在电视上看过短跑运动员的比赛，您就会确切地知道那有多远。现在想象一下，如果 100m 轨道站起来了！那大约是两个 Gol Gumbaz*-es 的高度。   *位于卡纳塔克邦比贾布尔的 Gol Gumbaz 是穆罕默德·阿迪尔·沙阿 (Mohammed Adil Shah) 的坟墓。它建于 1656 年，拥有世界上最大的圆顶。它一直保持到 1881 年！
第 3 步：1000 米   千米有一个特殊的名字——它被称为1公里或1公里。   如果你跑 10 次 100 米比赛，你就会跑完这个距离 - 呸！您需要爬上大约 9 公里才能到达珠穆朗玛峰的顶部。
第 6 步：10,00,000 米   现在让我们跳过 2 个步骤并转到第 6 步，其中 1 的右侧有六个零。   从克什米尔的印度北端到 Kanyakumari 的南端的距离大约是这个距离的 4 倍，或 10,00,000 m 的 4 倍，或 40,00,000 m。因为40,000,000米是一大口，所以我们通常说4000公里，这是同一个东西。
第 8 步：10,00,00,000 米   美丽的月亮离我们有多远？   它就在我们距离阶梯的第 8 级台阶上，距离地球大约 4 倍 10,000,000,000 米，或 4,00,000 公里！
第 11 步：1,00,00,00,00,000 米   让我们再跳过两步，奔向炽热的太阳。它有多远？大约是 10,000,000,000 公里加上另外 5,00,00,000 公里。那确实非常非常遥远！   但遥远的太阳仍然照亮世界，让我们在夏天出汗。 很神奇，不是吗？

最后一步？？？   梯子上有最后一步吗？我们还不知道！但是借助强大的望远镜，科学家们已经能够看到太阳以外的地方。他们能够发现的最远物体在第 26 步，10,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,000 米！那太远了！

也许等你长大了，你会发现更远的东西，在第 28 或第 29 步。这不是一个令人兴奋的想法吗？

有趣的测量   以下在课堂环境中进行的活动是让孩子们感受到远距离的好方法，并且可以让孩子们以一个小组或团队的形式参与其中。   1. 让孩子们从旧报纸上剪下长条（每条约一英寸宽）。 2. 让他们用胶带或胶水将条带首尾相连以制作更长的条带，直到他们得到一条 1 米长的条带（他们可以使用卷尺来做这个）。 3. 现在让孩子们用这个 1 m 长的条作为量尺，制作 10 个类似的条，并将它们首尾相连，制成 10 m 长的条。他们可以在这条带子旁边躺下，头对头，脚对脚，看看需要多少人才能达到10 m。 4. 然后他们可以将十个 10 m 的条带粘在一起，制成一个 100 m 的条带，可以绕教室多次。 5. 1 公里长的地带怎么样？它在教室里转了多少次？哪支球队能够最快地创造出一条 1 公里长的带状体？

给家长和老师的注意事项： ﻿ - 写下 1 后面有很多零的大数字时，这对儿童和成人来说非常容易！ - 犯错误。这就是“10 的幂”符号如此有用的原因。通过这本书，孩子们可以学会如何使用它——他们需要做的就是数一数 1 右边的零的数量，然后把这个数字写成 10 的上标。例如，1000，它有 3 1后面的零，可以写成103。而10000000（1后面的7个零），可以简洁地写成107。简单！  - 在这本书中，我们停止了“还有多远？”在太阳的比赛。如果你想更进一步，你可能想要引入离太阳最近的恒星——比邻星，它距离太阳 1016 米。或者银河系一端到另一端的距离，即 1,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,00,000（或 1021）米！  - 你应该知道的一件事是书中给出的距离是近似的，并不完全准确。例如，3984 公里被指定为 4000 公里。这并非“不科学”。粗略估计在科学上非常有用！也许你可以和孩子们一起做一个活动来强调这一点。铅笔的长度是接近 101 厘米还是 102 厘米？校车的重量是接近103公斤还是104公斤？让孩子们也为他们的同学提出他们自己的问题。
“我每天都只吃生胡萝卜,” 兔子对自己说到。
"我厌倦了生胡萝卜!"
“我能做些什么让它们更好吃呢?"
那天下午，她经过农夫家的房子，看到火上烧着一口锅。
正当她开始有点子了，农夫的狗跑出来叫着追赶她。
“嗯," 兔子思考着. "我现在该怎么做呢?"
兔子试着把胡萝卜放在阳光下烤。但这些胡萝卜还是和以前一样生。
然后,她试着把它们放在火里烧 。她尝了尝, 它们变苦了!
她想啊想啊想，思考该怎么办。
终于，她想到了一个点子！首先，她找到一个旧的乌龟壳。
然后, 她捡了一些木材
和三块石头。
耶！兔子终于找到办法煮她的胡萝卜！
她很兴奋邀请了她所有的朋友。
大家一起吃了一顿美味的煮熟的胡萝卜。
eng: Once, a rabbit thought to itself, "I have been eating raw carrots so far...
"Let me cook and eat it. "
"How do I cook?"
"Let me ask for help in this house"
But, there was a dog that started barking . He also chased the rabbit.
"Oh dear! What do I do now?" thought the rabbit.
He kept the carrots in the sun. The carrots didn't  cook.
He cooked the carrots in the fire. The carrots became too bitter!
"How do I cook and eat this? " Thought the rabbit furiously to himself.
He found a tortoise shell.
He gathered twigs.
He also found stones!
The rabbit lit the stove.
He also invited his friends to eat.
Everybody enjoyed eating the finely cooked carrots!
﻿We love going to Grandmother's village!
In Granny's garden stands a big mango tree.So many birds come and perch on it.
I like hiding on this tree.Nobody can find me here.
Dad searches for me near the well, and Mom searches near the cowshed.However, none of them find me.
Oh no!Granny's dog has found me.
Now I must climb down.Granny hugs me tightly.
zho: 我们要到村子里找奶奶。
奶奶的果园里有一颗很大的芒果树。有很多鸟喜欢到芒果树上。
我喜欢躲在芒果树里。这里没有人看得到我。
爸爸到井边找我。妈妈到牛舍边找我。没有人能找到我。
不好了！奶奶的狗找到我了。
我爬下芒果树。奶奶给我一个大拥抱。
蓝舌头黑舌头
长舌头强舌头
尖尖的舌头粘粘的舌头
粗粗的舌头滑滑的舌头
分叉的舌头快速的舌头
沉重的舌头毛毛的舌头
你的舌头是什么样子呢？
我们来谈谈舌头你知道舌头是由肌肉制成的，并能够做很多不同的事吗？ 然而，舌头永远不会感到疲倦或疼痛！北极熊的蓝舌头吸收太阳的热量来保暖。长颈鹿的舌头是暗色的，可以保护它免受非洲大草原的晒伤。穿山甲把它长长的舌头放入蚁丘，以啜饮蚂蚁 - 它最喜欢的零食。
蝾螈射出强大的舌头来抢夺蟋蟀和果蝇。鹅用尖尖的舌头抓住草，把它撕下来来吃。青蛙用它粘粘的唾液和有弹性的舌头捕捉苍蝇。
猫的粗粗的舌头帮助它刷毛皮。当狗太热时，狗把会肿起来的舌头伸出来。蛇用它分叉的舌头闻周围的气味。
变色龙的舌头以闪电般的速度飞出来抓住蚱蜢，然后才跳起来。蓝鲸是地球上最大的动物，拥有最重的舌头，有助于捕获它喜欢吃的微小磷虾。火烈鸟的毛毛舌头有助于过滤蓝绿藻和虾，它最喜欢的食物。
eng: Blue tongueBlack tongue

Long tongue
Strong tongue

Spiky tongue
Sticky tongue
Rough tongue Smooth tongue
Forked tongue Fast tongue
Heavy tongue Hairy tongue

What is YOUR tongue
like?

Let’s talk about tonguesDid you know that tongues are made of muscle and are able to do many different things? Yet tongues never get tired or sore!Polar Bear’s blue tongue absorbs the sun’s heat to keep warm.Giraffe’s tongue is dark, which protects it from sunburn in the African savannah.Pangolin puts its long tongue into anthills to slurp up ants
–
its favorite snack.

Salamander shoots out its powerful tongue to snatch crickets and fruit flies.Goose grips grass with its spiky tongue and tears it off to munch.Frog catches flies with its sticky saliva and stretchy tongue.
Cat’s rough tongue helps it brush its fur.Dog cools off by sticking out its tongue that swells up when it gets too hot.Snake uses its forked tongue to smell its surroundings.

Chameleon’s tongue darts out with lightning speed to grab that grasshopper before it leaps away.Blue Whale, the largest animal on Earth, has the heaviest tongue that helps trap tiny krill that it loves to eat.Flamingo’s hairy tongue helps filter blue-green algae and shrimps that are its favourite food.

zho: “我们最好赶在晚饭前回去。”马达夫说。“我们不想惹妈妈生气。”过了整整十一分钟后，他们迷路了。
“请问月亮在哪里呢？”他们向一只闪闪发亮的独角兽请示方向。“你为什么会闪闪发亮呢？”“你知道月亮是由什么制成的吗？”“而你又是由什么制成的呢？”
那只独角兽没有时间回答他们的问题。 吧唧吧唧！滋滋！啧啧！“如果我不继续吃东西的话，那么我就永远都无法变成一头漂亮的犀牛。”它说。 奈娜和马达夫还没来得及反应，就听到远处传来响亮的啜泣声。哇！嗷嗷！
“我好苦哇！”那个声音哀嚎着。“我会不会永远被困在这里呢？”“别再呻吟了！”另外一个声音怒吼。“看来有人需要我们的帮助。”奈娜说。 “我们可以成为天空中的英雄。”马达夫说。“小心前方的天鹅。”独角兽提醒他们，然后再继续吃东西。
奈娜和马达夫看见令人吃惊的一幕。一位愤怒的女王正守着一座已经上了锁的高塔。一条正在哭泣的龙把头探出窗外。“你为什么要绑架那条龙呢？”“因为它是个可恶的贼！”女王大声地谩骂。“它趁我睡着的时候偷了我的头发，一直不肯还给我。”
“我根本无法还给你！”那条龙哭着说。“实在是太危险了。” 奈娜眼睛为之一亮。“每一个危险的地方，都是一个可以探险的地方。” “而每一次的探险，都需要一位勇敢的英雄！”马达夫说。 “不只是一位。”奈娜说。“我们俩会帮你拿回你的头发！” 那条龙答应告诉他们那一束头发的所在地。但是，它不愿意靠近。
“一条会喷火的龙竟然害怕一只天鹅。”奈娜一边说，一边摇头。“那只天鹅或许根本不知道头发已经被偷走了。”马达夫说。 “我们直接叫它归还吧！”奈娜说。 他们的计划并不顺利。 扑棱！忒儿！砉！
那只天鹅张开翅膀后便袭击了飞船，然后追着飞船在空中绕。 当他们成功摆脱了天鹅的时候，马达夫和奈娜的肚子已经饿得咕咕叫了。 他们看了看天空中的时钟，然后倒抽了一口气。“我们已经迟到了，我们已经迟到了！”马达夫说。
他们让飞船加速航行。轰轰！轰轰！ 飞船的引擎发出了一声巨响，然后熄火了。嗒嗒！嘟嘟！
那两姐弟惊慌失措。 “我们被困在这里了！”“我们该怎么回家呢？”  “妈妈一定会很生气的！”“我好饿啊！” 他们向星星求助。
那条龙已经哭到鼻塞了。因此，他们不能乘着它的火焰回家。一只飞马已经把它的翅膀送到干洗店了。因此，它无法载他们回家。太空中最强壮的人发生了意外，他手臂的骨骼已经断裂了。因此，他不能把他们抛回家。 “我们完蛋了！” 不过，那条龙想到了一个办法。
他们俩爬上了一个像箭一样的东西。那一艘人马火箭瞄准了方向，把他们带到家门前 。
eng: “But we better get back in time for dinner,” Madhav said. “We don’t want to find out what Aai’s anger is made of.”It took them exactly eleven minutes to get lost.
“Where’s the moon?” They asked a glowing unicorn for directions. “How come you’re so shiny?”“Do you know what the moon is made of?” “What are you made of?”

The unicorn didn’t have time for their questions.Chomp! Crrunch! Gulp!“If I stop eating, I'll never turn into a gorgeous rhinoceros,” she said.Before Naina and Madhav could say anything else, they heard loud sobs in the distance.Waaaaaaah! Aiyeeeee!

“WOE IS ME!” the new voice wailed. “Will I be trapped in here forever?”“Stop moaning!” growled another voice.“It sounds like somebody needs our help,” said Naina.“We can be heroes of the sky,” said Madhav.“Look out for the swan,” warned the unicorn, before going back to her food.

Naina and Madhav found a surprising sight. An angry queen was guarding a locked tower. A weeping dragon peeked through the window."Why have you kidnapped a dragon?” Naina asked the queen."Because he is a no-good thief!” the queen snapped. "He stole my hair while I was sleeping and now he won’t give it back.”

“I can’t get it back!” the dragon cried. “It’s too dangerous.”Naina’s eyes lit up. “Where there’s danger, there’s adventure.”“And every adventure needs a brave hero!” said Madhav.“Heroes, you mean,” said Naina. “We will rescue your hair!”  The dragon agreed to tell them where the hair was. But he refused to go near it.

“A giant fire-breathing dragon is afraid of a harmless swan.” Naina shook her head.“The swan probably doesn’t even know that the hair is stolen,” Madhav replied.  “We should just ask him to return it,” Naina suggested.Things did not go according to plan.Hiss! Snort! Flap!

The swan spread his wings and attacked the spaceship. Then he chased them across the sky.  By the time they escaped the swan, Madhav and Naina’s stomachs were growling with hunger.They looked at the clock in the sky and gasped.   “We’re late, we’re late!” Madhav said.
They revved the engine of their spaceship. vooRRR! vooRRR!The engine sputtered and came to a halt. Vwomp! Pssssh!
The siblings panicked.“We’re stuck!”“How do we get back home?”“Aai will be so angry!”“I’m so hungry!”They turned to the stars for help.

The dragon had a blocked nose because of all the weeping. They couldn’t ride his flames home.The flying horse had sent his wings to the dry cleaner. He couldn’t fly them home.The strongest man in space had fractured his arm. He couldn’t throw them home.“We’re doomed!” But the dragon had another idea.
The two children climbed aboard an arrow. The centaur took careful aim and shot them right to their front door.

zho: 一隻大象要去喝水
兩隻長頸鹿要去喝水
三隻水牛與四隻鳥也要去喝水
五隻羚羊與六隻疣豬正走向水源
七隻斑馬正跑向水源
八隻青蛙與九條魚正在水裡游泳
一隻獅子吼叫，他也想要喝水。誰害怕獅子呢？
一隻大象在與獅子一起喝水
eng:
One elephant is
going to drink water.
Two giraffes are going to drink water.

Three buffaloes
and four birds are also going to drink water.
Five antelopes and warthogs are walking to the water.
Seven zebras are running to the water.
Eight frogs and nine fish are swimming in the water.
One lion roars. He also wants to drink. Who is afraid of the lion?
One elephant is drinking water with the lion.

zho: 妈妈的歌，软软的，甜甜的。小常杜听着听着，睡着了。在梦里，他飞了起来。
飞呀飞呀，飞到了一个花园。看！一只蝴蝶，好漂亮啊！蝴蝶说：“嘿！你好吗？”“好极了，谢谢！”小常杜说。
小常杜飞得更高了。飞呀飞呀，他遇到了一只小麻雀。“嘿！你好吗？”她问。“好极了，谢谢！”小常杜说。
小常杜飞得更高了。飞呀飞呀，他遇见了一只老鹰。“嘿，朋友！你好吗？”老鹰说。“不错”小常杜说。
小常杜飞得越来越高，这好像还挺容易的。飞呀飞呀，他碰到了一架飞机。“嘿，小常杜！你好吗？”飞机问。“很好！祝你顺利”小常杜赶紧说。
慢慢的，小常杜飞得更高了。飞呀飞呀。一个火箭过来迎接他“嘿，先生！你好吗？”火箭喊道。“很好”小常杜说。”
小常杜飞得越来越高。现在星星在他身边眨着眼睛，他们向小常杜展开了微笑，好像他也是他们中的一员似的。“嘿！你好吗？”一个星星问他。“棒极了！”小常杜说。突然，星星开始摇晃起来，然后好像有人在使劲晃他。
哦，是妈妈，她把小常杜摇醒了：“早啊，你好吗？”他紧紧的抱着妈妈，说：“哦，我从来没有感觉这么好过！”
eng: Mother's song was soft and sweet. Chandu was listening to it. Chandu fell asleep. In his dream, he was flying.
Flying, flying into a garden. Look! A butterfly, so pretty.The butterfly said, “Well, hello! How are you?”“Fine, thank you,” Chandu replied.
Chandu flew a bit higher. Flying, flying. He flew into a sparrow.“Hi there! How do you do?” she asked.“Very well, thank you,” Chandu said.
Then Chandu soared still higher. Flying, still flying, he met an eagle.“Hello friend! How are you?” the eagle asked.“I feel good,” replied Chandu.

Chandu was flying higher and higher. It seemed so easy. Flying, flying. So high that he came up to an aeroplane.“Hey, Chandu, how do you do?” the aeroplane asked.“Fine. And safe journey!” Chandu quickly replied.
Soon Chandu climbed higher than before. Flying and still flying. A rocket came to meet him. “Hello sir, how do you do?” the rocket shouted.“Very well,” Chandu smiled.

Still, Chandu was flying higher and higher. Now the stars were twinkling all around. They were smiling at Chandu, as though he were a part of them.“How are you feeling Chandu?” one star asked him.“I am feeling great!” he said. Suddenly, the stars began to wobble. And shake.
It was Mother, shaking Chandu awake. “Good morning, how are you?”He hugged her hard and said, “Oh, now I feel better than ever before!”
Hi! I am Neema. Just like you, I love to eat. Here are are some things that I eat: Dhokla , Panipuri and Jalebi.
Yum Yum! Where is this noise coming from? Oh! it's Neema who is eating.
Neema loves mangoes.
She loves all fruits.
It is raining. What is Neema doing? Let us see.
Oh! Neema is eating jamuns, pineapples and corn.Yummy! She says.
Oh! it is winter.Let us see what Neema is doing.
Oh! Neema is eating custard apple , beetroot and imlis
Neema loves to eat. Just like us.
zho: 这是尼玛跟你一样，她喜欢吃这就是为什么她总是不停的吃
吭吭，吭吭哧哧，哧哧嗯嗯，嗯嗯哎呀，尼玛吃东西时闭上嘴！
夏天的时候白天又开心又长而且外面很暖和今天尼玛吃什么？
夏天是吃芒果的好时节黄的，绿的，还有红的又白又滑的荔枝藏在鲜红的果皮里绿黄条纹交织的西瓜一咬满口汁的桑葚哎呀，尼玛的手又粘又脏啦
雨季的时候黑云滚滚而来外面雨下的好大今天尼玛吃什么？
雨季是吃玉米的好时节黄的，白的，还有紫的新鲜又多汁的甜玉米带着皇冠的菠萝紫色的软软的玫瑰果哎呀！尼玛的舌头全变蓝啦！
冬天的时侯白天变短了外面变冷了今天尼玛吃什么？
冬天是吃亮叶子的蔬菜的好时节甜菜根，红的像落日鼓鼓的青苹果快看，快看，尼玛在爬树哎呀，她摘了所有的酸溜溜的褐色的酸角！
尼玛喜欢吃但是她不同季节吃不一样的东西呢！吭吭 吭吭！哧哧 哧哧！
世界上有五种不同的季节，春天，夏天，雨季，秋天，和冬天。但是在尼玛生活的印度的一些地方，有三个季节： 夏天，雨季和冬天。
应时而吃就像尼玛一样，你在一年当中可以吃很多颜色鲜艳，香甜可口的水果和蔬菜。这里有一个季节表，这样你就知道什么时侯有什么水果和蔬菜可以吃啦酸角：一月到二月
菠菜： 三月到五月， 十月到一月
荔枝：五月到六月
甜柠檬：七月到八月

eng:
Today is my first day of school. Mother held my hand and walking with me. "Now I have grown up," I say. "Come...come!"
Mother held my hand tightly.

There are many children near the school.
Some come by bus. Some come by car.
Some come by rickshaw. Some come by bicycle and some come on foot, like me.

We reached to the gate.
Mother left my hand.
She stopped on gate. I have to go alone inside.
Many unknown faces are around me.

I moved one step. I moved another step.  
I looked behind. As I move forward, mother looks smaller. Would she disappeared? I ran to her. I don't think I've grown up. I hold her hand and say, "don't go".

All had gone inside. Only I was outside. Teacher came outside.
She smiles after looking me. I also smiles. Mother says," Rani I will meet you here when you come out". I leave her hand. She waive her hand.
I ran inside. Mother would meet there on leave.
zho: 这是我第一天上学。妈妈拉着我的手，跟我一起走着。“我已经长大了，”我说，“放开我吧!" 妈妈的手抓得很紧。
学校附近有很多小朋友。有人是坐巴士来的，有人坐车，有人坐了三轮侧。有的骑车，有的走路，比如我。
我们到了门口。妈妈放开了我的手。她停在了门口。我自己走进了学校。周围有好多新面孔啊。
我向前迈了一步，又迈了一步。妈妈的身影越来越小。她会不会不见了啊！我跑回去，抓住她的手。“不要走啊，妈妈”，我说，突然间我不觉得自己长大了。
大家都进去了。只有我一个人还在大门外。老师走了出来，她冲我笑，我也冲她笑着。妈妈说，“Ranni, 你放学的时候我就在外面等你啦。”我慢慢放开了妈妈的手。她冲我招手道别。
我跑进了校园。放学的时候妈妈就在外面啦！

eng: Meera lives in a small village. It is right on top of a mountain in Himachal Pradesh. From her kitchen window, she can see snowcapped mountains. Huge eagles with golden wings often fly over their house. One day, when she is older and taller, Meera wishes to climb up to the highest peak and look down at the other side.

But today, Meera, her brother Rajesh, and Ma are walking downhill. They are going to the market to buy new shoes. The town is far but Meera does not mind. She walks an hour every day to go to school. They set out at dawn. They have to walk for two hours to reach the main road. Then they will take the bus.
Sometimes, the path disappears and they slide down the rocks. “Whee!” say Meera and Rajesh as they jump over the stones.
Crunch crunch, go the twigs and dry leaves under their feet."Cree ..ckrr..ckre!" a small green barbet calls from the shrubs. A gang of langurs watch them quietly from the pine trees.

Meera stops to drink water from a spring hidden behind rocks and ferns. Suddenly, she sees a little bird. It is lying in the ferns.“Poor thing. He has injured his wing,” says Ma. She gently picks up the bird.“Should we take him with us?” asks Meera.The bird is a spotted forktail. The bird watches them with his tiny eyes. He is scared. “Do not worry,” Meera tells him softly.
“First I must mend the wing,” says Ma. They put some wet earth on the wing and wrap the bird in a big leaf. Meera puts the bird in her cloth bag.

On the main road, the bus has just arrived. In the bus, Meera can feel the bird moving about in her bag. “Maybe he is hungry,” says Ma. “So am I,” says Rajesh. They eat some roasted gram. Meera crushes a few and gives it to the bird.


The old bus rumbles along on the winding mountain road.
The town is noisy and crowded. “Stay close to me, Meera and Rajesh!” Ma calls. They hold hands tightly.

When they reach the market, they buy Meera’s shoes. Ma also buys some hot jalebis for them from the sweet shop.Meera gives the bird a tiny piece but he does not like it. He instead tries to peck at the cloth bag.

Soon it is time to take the bus to go back home. As the bus sways from side to side, Meera can hear the little bird chirping in her bag.“We will soon be at the spring,” Meera whispers to the bird. When they reach the spring, Meera lets him out. He hops a bit, drinks some water and then sits on Meera’s feet. The bird likes the new shoes, too!
It is almost dark when they get home. Meera makes a soft bed with some straw for the bird. The bird goes to sleep in his new bed.
Meera and the bird become good friends. Meera gives him tiny rice and chana balls to eat. After a week, the bird suddenly flies away.
Now, every time Meera walks down the hill, she sees a black-and- white bird with a long tail.The bird always nods and chirps at her. Do you think he is the same bird?
zho: 米拉和家人一起住在一个小村庄里。 这个村庄坐落在印度喜马偕尔邦的一座山上。 从米拉家厨房的窗户往外看，她能看到一片片被白雪覆盖的山脉。 有时候，米拉也经常看见一只只拍打金色翅膀的巨大老鹰从他们的家飞过。有一天，当她长大又长高时，米拉许了一个愿望。她希望自己可以爬上山的最高峰，然后俯视山的另一侧。
然而今天，米拉和她的弟弟拉吉什与妈妈一起走下山。他们打算到山下小镇的超市购买新鞋子。 小镇离米拉住的村庄很远，但米拉并不介意。 这是因为她每天都花一个小时步行上学。米拉一行人在黎明时出发前往超市。他们必须步行两个小时才会抵达通往小镇的主要道路，然后再乘坐公共巴士前往小镇。
有时他们找不到小路时，他们会靠着石头往下滑。 “ 唷！”米拉和拉吉什跳过石头时兴高采烈地叫喊。
他们穿过丛林。小树枝和脚踩到的干树叶会发出嘎吱嘎吱的声响。 “ 斯克里，斯克里！”他们听见灌木中发出绿色的热带巨嘴鸟的叫声。 松树上有一群叶猴静静地看着他们。
米拉停止从藏在岩石和蕨类后面的泉水中取水来喝。 突然，她看到一只受伤的小鸟。 小鸟静静地躺在蕨类中。“可怜的小东西。 它的翅膀受伤了，”妈妈说。 她小心翼翼地捡起那只受伤的小鸟。“我们应该把它带上吗？”米拉问。这只鸟是斑背燕尾。 小鸟用它的小眼睛看着米拉他们。 它很害怕。 “别担心，” 米拉轻声地安慰它。
“我必须先治疗小鸟的翅膀，” 妈妈说。 他们在小鸟的翅膀上放了一些湿泥土，然后用一片大叶子包住。 然后，米拉小心地将小鸟放入她的布袋。
这时，公共巴士刚刚到达前往小镇的主要道路。 在公共汽车上，米拉感觉到小鸟在她的书包里移动。 “也许它饿了，”妈妈说。 “我也饿了，” 拉吉什说。 他们吃了一些烤豆。米拉压碎一些烤豆然后喂给小鸟吃。那辆老旧的公共巴士在蜿蜒的山路上隆隆作响。
小镇人山人海，非常喧闹和拥挤。“米拉和拉吉什，离我近一些！”妈妈说。 他们紧紧握住彼此的手。
抵达超市时，他们买了米拉的新鞋子。 妈妈还在甜品店买了一些刚出炉的蜜糖炸甜圈。米拉给小鸟一小块炸甜圈吃，可是它不喜欢。 相反的，小鸟一直在啄米拉的布袋。
很快，已经到该乘公共巴士回家的时间了。 公共巴士转弯非常摇晃，巴士从一边摇去另外一边。米拉可以听到小鸟在她的布袋里吱吱叫。“我们很快就要到泉水附近了，”米拉对小鸟低声说。 当他们到达泉水边时，米拉把它从布袋放了出来。 小鸟跳了一下，喝了些泉水，然后飞到米拉的脚上坐了下来。 小鸟也喜欢米拉的新鞋！
当米拉一行人回到家时，天已经快黑了。 米拉用一些稻草为小鸟做了一张柔软的床。 小鸟开心地飞到它的新床上睡觉。
之后，米拉和小鸟成了好朋友。 米拉每天喂它吃米饭粒和烤丸子。 一周后，小鸟突然飞走了。
现在，每当米拉步行下山时都会看到一只长尾巴，黑白色的鸟。那只鸟总是向她点头和对着她叫。 你觉得它和小鸟是同一只鸟吗？
Sarla喜欢观察鸟飞翔。有一天，在自然科学课上，她望向窗外，看见了一只鹰 划过了天空。她能感觉到那只鸟是那么的幸福快乐。她也喜欢看着飞机飞行。"注意这里，你叫什么名字？你不是应该看着黑板吗？" Sarla她们班新来的老师问道。Sarla犹豫地站起来说， "对不起，老师，我在看一只老鹰。我希望我们能像鸟或者飞机一样可以飞翔...""你叫什么名字？""Sarla."
"哦，多好听的名字呀！你知道吗，第一个印度女飞行员的名字也叫Sarla？我的名字，Hamsa，意思是天鹅。你知道，天鹅是最大的飞行鸟类之一，”老师说. "你应该花点时间去图书馆，Sarla. 我很肯定那里有很多关于鸟类和飞行的书，也有关于飞行机器的书比如飞机." 接下来的几天里，Sarla很高兴地学到了很多关于鸟类和飞机的知识。
Sarla学到了人类也是可以飞的，但是不像鸟那样。我们可以坐飞机飞到世界上的任何一个城市，飞机是人类最伟大的发明之一。有了这个伟大的机器的帮助，我们可以体验到飞行旅行的乐趣。鸟类是天生的不需要外界机器帮助就可以飞行的生物。通常，一个鸟的翅膀比它的身子还要大很多。鸟的翅膀非常轻，有助于鸟类飞行。
飞机很大并且很重。像鸟类一样，飞机两边也有翅膀来帮助它们飞行。飞机的翅膀形状和鸟类的非常像--末端有翘起的曲线而根部很平整，这样可以帮助飞机向上飞向天空。
鸟儿上下煽动它们的翅膀来飞行，但是我们从来没有见过飞机可以拍打翅膀！鸟儿煽动翅膀来利用风把它们的身体向上推。 飞机其实也是利用风的力量来让自己飞行的。这个机器利用它身体里的引擎来制造向下的风力。
引擎是一个很强大的机器，它就像飞机的大脑一样。和鸟儿用它们的头脑和逻辑来引导它自己的飞行一样，引擎帮助飞机把自己推离地面并且向上飞。当飞机的引擎燃烧燃料的时候，它们产生速度很快的热气来推动引擎后方的空气从而使飞机向前移动。
汽车和其他的带有引擎的交通工具也会往前移动。但是它们不能像飞机一样飞上天空。风流过形状像鸟儿翅膀的飞机翅膀上方和下方，把飞机向上抬升上天空并且保持它不会掉下来。像鸟儿一样，飞机也有尾巴来保持它们稳定和改变方向。
飞机需要很长的路来起飞和降落。这些长长的路叫做跑道，在起飞进入空中以前，飞机需要在跑道上非常快速的移动。飞机需要一定的速度才能升到空中。大部分的飞机需要速度足够快才能起飞。跑道是机场非常重要的一部分，因为跑道为飞机提供了足够的时间来提升速度以达到最终的起飞。

飞机知道它们应该飞去哪里因为它们被飞行员操控。飞行员在一个位于飞机前端的叫做机长室的舱内控制飞机。他们通过很精密很先进的设备和机场（飞机起飞降落的地方）保持联系。就像在路上有交通信号灯和警察帮助我们一样，空中交通指挥员会告诉飞行员飞行的时间和目的地；以及什么时候可以安全的起飞和降落。一架飞机其实就是一只巨大的鸟儿。它不仅仅是形状像鸟，它也实现了人类的飞行，虽然并不像鸟儿那样飞！Sarla长大想成为一名飞行员并且驾驶飞机。
你知道吗？印度的第一架飞机叫Harlow，它第一次飞行是在1941年的六月。印度的第一个飞行员执照在1929年二月由印度和缅甸飞行俱乐部颁给了JRD Tata。
世界上最快的飞机是Lockheed SR-71 黑鸟，它飞行的速度比声音还要快。Sarla Thakral是印度的第一个女性飞行员。她也是第一个飞行时间超过1000小时的女性飞行员。

让我们起飞吧！和朋友们一起完成下面这些活动：1.做纸飞机，然后看看谁的飞机飞得最远。制造飞机的纸还是制作飞机的方法哪一个可以让飞机飞得更快？观察每一架飞机飞出以后发生了什么。如果你扔出飞机前吹飞机的上方，或是吹向飞机，或是飞机的下方会不会有什么不同？2. "飞还是不飞"游戏：找一群朋友来绕着教室“飞行”，不能互相碰到 。主持人站在一个角落，说出可以飞和不能飞的物体的名字。如果一个不能飞的物体（比如桌子）被喊出，“飞机们 ”就必须“降落”（坐下）。谁要是错了谁就成为下一个主持人。
eng:
Sarla liked to watch birds fly. One day, during science
class, she looked out of the window and saw an eagle gliding in the sky. How
happy the bird must be! She also liked to see planes flying.
 
“Here, what's your name? Should you not be looking at the
board?” asked the new teacher in Sarla's class.
Sarla got up hastily and said, “Sorry Madam, I was watching
an eagle. I wish we could fly like a bird, or like an aeroplane....”
“What is your name?”
“Sarla.”

“Oh how nice! Do you know that Sarla was the name of the
first Indian woman pilot too?  My name,
Hamsa, means a swan. Swans are one of the largest flying birds, you know,” said
the teacher. “You must spend some
time in the library, Sarla. I'm sure there are many books about birds and
flights, and machines that fly like aeroplanes.”
 
Over the next few days, Sarla happily learnt a lot about
birds, and about aeroplanes.

Sarla learnt that  human beings can fly too, but not like
birds. We can  fly to any city in the
world in an aeroplane, one of mankind’s greatest inventions. With the help of
this great machine, we can also experience the joy of being airborne. Birds are
aerial creatures that do not need an external machine to fly. Usually, a bird's
wings are bigger than the rest of its body. 
The wings are very light, making it possible for birds to fly.

Aeroplanes are huge and very heavy. Just like birds,
aeroplanes have wings on both their sides which help them to fly. The wings of
the plane are shaped just like those of birds - curved on the top and flat on
the bottom which helps them to fly high up in the sky.

Birds flap their wings to fly, but of course we  have never seen an aeroplane flapping its
wings!  Birds flap their wings as they
use the wind to push their body upwards. Aeroplanes also fly with the help of
the force of the wind. This machine uses the engine inside its body to create
wind that flows below the plane.

An engine is a very strong machine which acts like the brain
of the plane. Just like a bird uses its mind and logic to navigate its flight,
engines help planes to push them above the ground and to help them move
forward. When the plane’s engines burn fuel, they release hot gases at high
speeds which push on the air behind the engine, moving the plane forward.

Cars and other vehicles with engines move forward too. But
they cannot go up in the sky like planes. The wind flows over and under their
wings which are shaped like birds’ wings and lifts the plane into the sky and
keeps it there. Planes also have tails, just like birds, to keep them steady
and help them change direction.





ٴ

Planes need big long roads to take off and land. These long
roads are called runways and planes need to travel very fast on the runway
before they can take off into the air. Planes need to gain a lot of speed to
lift off in the air. Most aeroplanes can take off only if they are moving fast
enough. The runway is an important part of the airport as it gives aeroplanes
enough time to increase their speed and ultimately take off.

Planes know where they have to go because they are steered
by pilots. The pilots control the plane from a place in the front of the
aeroplane called the cockpit. They keep in contact with the airport (a place from
where the planes take off and land) through very accurate and modern devices. Just like there are signals and police to help us on the roads, there are air traffic controllers who tell pilots when and where to fly; and when it is safe to take off or land. 
 
A plane is actually a giant bird. It is not only shaped like
a bird, it also allows us to fly, though not like birds!  Sarla wants to be a pilot and fly aeroplanes
when she grows up.

Did You Know?
 
India’s
first aircraft was the Harlow which first flew in July 1941.The first
pilot license in India was awarded to JRD Tata in February 1929 by the Aero
Club of India and Burma.

The fastest jet aircraft in the world is the Lockheed SR-71
Blackbird which flies at a speed faster than the speed of sound.
Sarla Thakral was
the first Indian woman to fly an aircraft. She was also the first
woman pilot to accumulate over 1000 hours of flying.

Let's take off!
Have fun with friends with these activities:
1. Make paper planes and see whose plane goes the
farthest. Is it the paper or the way it has been made that makes a paper plane go faster?  Observe what happens when each  plane is launched. Is there a difference if
you blow over, or into or under the plane before you shoot it off? 
 
2. Fly-Don't fly Game: Get a group of friends to
'fly' around the room, without touching each other. The den stands in a corner
and calls out the names of flying or non-flying objects. When a non-flying
object (like table)  is called, the
'planes' must 'land' (sit down). Whoever makes a mistake is the next den.

I can run with
it.

I can jump with
it.

I can dance with
it.

I can swim with
it.

I can skip with
it.

I can kick with
it.

I can escape with
it.

But I can never
fly with it.
zho: 我能跑。
我能跳。
我能跳舞。
我能游泳。
我能跳绳。
我能踢球。
我能逃跑。
但是我永远不能飞。

la, la, la, la, la…”
“Is it from somewhere?” “Is it from everywhere?”“It is from there!”

“La-la,
la, la, la, la, la…”
“Is it from the sky?”“Is it from the tree?”“It is from the bush!”
“La-la, la, la, la, la, la…”
“Is it black?”“Is it white?”“It is brown!”
“La-la, la, la, la, la, laa …”
“Is it a prayer?”“Is it a poem?”“It is a song!”
“Is it a koyal?”“Is it a myna?”“It is a…”
“La-la, la, la, la, la, la…”
“It is a donkey!”“It is a donkey!”“It is a donkey, sing on!”
